reviews.review: Derelict weapons from the past 50 years . The tour guides will tell about the recent history of Cambodia with a sobering personal touch.The museum has a collection of weapons found in Cambodia after the Civil War. Some of the pieces (and some of the bigger ones) were still active only 17 years ago.Includes a shack of light weapons that can be held, but for the love of God don't point them at anyone anyway.

Graveyard of war toys. A short trip out of town toward the airport. You could even check it out enroute to or from the airport. Allow about an hour, more if you want to really read and absorb the displays and artifacts. A free guide is provided, if wanted. We were lucky enough to be taken around by "the cat" - so named as he's had a fair share of hospitalisation visits during his involvement in the conflict, starting as a young boy soldier aged 14. He'll happily show you his shrapnel wounds from land mines, some of which are still lodged in his body. Feel it! He invites. Wander at your leisure around the graveyard of vehicles, armaments, tanks, field artillery, and even an old jet and Russian helicopter, and various personnel carriers, some of which the guide tells us, his friends died in, captain this, colonel that, general too. Look, he explains, you can see his shoes and his femur, and other bones still in the skeleton body of the tank. Not to sure about that. Looked a bit staged, or at least unnecessary. Take time to read a little around the history of the conflict from the French departure circa 1960, through the turbulent period of conflict fuelled by the world's opposing warring nations, to the very recent late 90's. The deaths from land mines still making their toll on the war torn country. 1000 years ago they built "the Wat" kingdoms here, and slaughtered each other to destruction. Not much change there then.

Humbling. Very humbling tour with guide, not a big flash museum but a very honest look at some of the weapons and stories of the Cambodian conflicts. Glad we took the time to visit, keep up the good work

Great place to visit . It's not your ordinary museum of things inside glass windows and walking indoors. Everything is outside and you get to see it. Some things you can touch as well such as the land mines and old bombs. That was pretty awesome on top of learning about the history of the country! Definitely worth a visit while you're here even if you're not crazy about history like me.

Glad to meet "the cat". Everyone should visit this museum to help the Cambodian veterans. Our guide "the cat" was inspiring and a great man. Only wish we could do more to help these brave men and women.

Story Behind Cambodia. 5USD per person to visit this outdoor War Museum in Siem Reap. Tour guide is available for free (can tips them if satisfied with the service).Read through the stories and walk through the garden sized museum to know more how they gone through during the wars. A few victims and even some one their family members of the land mines even working in this museum and for sure thy can tell you more about their real experiences during the war century.
War enthusiasts. A very confronting place to go. It gives you perspective and opens your eyes at just what the Cambodians went through. Not for the faint hearted.

Good Insight Into The War. Visited the museum after reading some online reviews. It's about 20 minutes by tuk tuk from the City but well worth the visit. $5 entry fee person and a free guide although ours was so good we gave him some tips which seemed much appreciated. A good learning experience into what was only a few years ago.

Worth a visit. The museum is not very flashly, but having a guide to talk with who had been through the war and all it did to their country and people was moving. I think anyone who is interested in what the country has endured would find it worth the visit.

Good Information. This Museum is good if you want some background on the history of Cambodia. It is not a flashy place but does the job. you can have a free guide who will explain the way it was and show you the different guns, bombs and landmines that they have on display.

Emotionally shaken. We came here to feel and understand what conflicts in Cambodia brought about.
They have free knowledgeable guides. We did have only thirty minutes on the last day of our visit to Siem reap, but was happy to go there as it is not far from the city.
Definitely worth a visit!

Eye opening. We were lucky enough to have a guided tour by 'the cat' - what an amazing morning!! He lived through the war and was full of information and experience, I can't even imagine what he has witnessed yet he is still so upbeat and such a laugh. This tour definitely put life into perspective and is a must do while in siem reap.
war museum. really wasn't what i expected non the less interesting , pay your respects to museum and people who's lives were effected
Great guide. We hd a great guide whose name I have unfortunately forgotten but we learned about the conflict and got to walk round and see many impressive machines and weaponry. Well worth a visit.

Must see for those who are interested in Cambodias history. . Have been told by a few friend's back home that we had to put this on out to do list when in Cambodia. We have to say that we were glad we did have the opportunity to visit this museum. It is set in an open field, and there isn't much cover from the elements, but that's what makes this museum unique. Our guide spoke English quite well and was very knowledgeable and willing to pass on his knowledge about Cambodias history to us. There are quite a few exhibits in the museum and you are given the opportunity to look around as you please after you've been taken around by the guide. If you're in the Siem Reap area, add this to your list of thing's to do.

Compelling insight . We struck Sanh as our guide through this outdoor museum. At 26, he's got an insight into the history, present and future of Cambodia that is well worth the price of admission alone. We were lucky to get extra information after the official tour from this wonderful young fellow. The museum itself has a few must sees. For one, the helicopter defies physics - or at least it would seem it did all those years ago. It's only four kms from the heart of Siem Reap, costing about $6US for the ride there and back in a tuk tuk. I'd say if you want further insight into this complex country and it's people, definitely visit this museum.

Simple museum but it is a stark reminder of damage war can inflict. Our tour guide, Lim, made this experience a memorable one. The museum is simple but nicely laid out and well presented. The displays, I would guess, have been carefully written but spend an hour with the guide to really understand the unfortunate modern history of Cambodia and the part foreign nations played.

A waste of time. This was the worse museum I’ve ever been. It only has rusty airplanes and weapons displayed in a mosquito and fly infested field. Besides that, the reading material is poor. I learnt much more about the Cambodia war reading Wikipedia rather than reading the information available in this place. I was told that there would be guides there but none was available when I arrived. After a while, I saw a guide with an Australian couple and asked politely if I could join them. They all agreed I could join them. However, the guide (who apparently was a war veteran) would not say anything about the war. Instead, he kept showing the scars he got during the war period. Apart from showing his scars, he also kept saying every two minutes that Australia was the greatest country in the world. Actually, I didn’t understand why he was so obsessed in repeating this. So, I just gave up, walked away and took a tuk-tuk back to the city centre. This so called museum is a completely waste of time. I don’t recommend it.

Everyone should go!. A bit out of the way but worth the visit. Our guide was excellent and shared first hand personal experiences of the war with us. I don't know how he recounts the painful atrocities everyday. Such sadness. I strongly recommend visiting.

Place to review History of Cambodia. It a place to show Cambodia war history at 1975. Photo , used weapon , landmine are show in the museum. Have a free guide service to give a info for all display items and photo.

Impressive!. We were one of the first ones there at opening, and we received a free tour guide. He had been through the war and had stories to tell that would bring a tear - or two - to your eye. They have various types of machinery and weaponry that is sitting on top of an old landmine field. The only issue we had was getting a tuk-tuk back.. It's nestled away in Siem Reap. We should've had our tuk-tuk stay, but we weren't thinking about it and they weren't able to call one.

History worth seeing !!. We spent a couple of hours here, it was very interesting. The guide we had was very knowledgeable and had great English. And definately brought the museum to life for us. Worth a visit to get up close and personal with the artifacts. My husband was impressed as he got to hold the guns.

A must.. Tucked-away outdoor museum with former soldiers as compelling guides recounting the horrific years of civil war. No bells, whistles or high-tech, hands-on displays, just military vehicles in their original state., weaponry and often troubling images. A must-see in Siem Reap but not for the fainthearted.
Wonderful. Our tour guide was full of knowledge spoke great English and was very helpful. Thank you so much for such an insightful tour.
Good to see history. Good place to go and see what the Cambodian people went through . You are able to look and touch weapons of war and hear the stories .Excellent to see

Worth a visit. A short tuk tuk ride from the city will soon bring you here. A guided tour is best, then after you can walk around at your own pace, the guides english was very good. If the guides are busy walk around then go with the guide latter. Theres plenty to see, old helicopter, jet, artillery,tanks,hand weapons ,mines,you can climb on the vehicles for photos and handle the weapons ie ak47 etc. Take an umbrella if it's the rainy season as most is outside, Well worth visiting.

Small but worth it.. It's small outdoor museum, with many vehicles and mines and artillery, but it's worth it just to read the stories from a non-US perspective. While a guide is not necessary, and you can look round in about 30 minutes, the guides are very inexpensive and can answer questions you may have (also, some of the exhibits are affected by time and weather and the explanations of what they are isn't always clear) and has interesting little comments.

SHOCKINGLY good.. Driving up we were worried that we had wasted a drive out to the museum. It isn't a traditional museum...more of a backyard full of astounding military relics. The guide made it completely worthwhile, educational and informative. If you miss this while you are in Siem Reap you have missed out on a great historic visit.

HERITAGE. Will see a lot of old weapons that have been used to kill innocent people.Heritage. Some really good displays. Thank you to one of the guide for all the information. Sympathy with the victims of war disabled.

Must Visit. First time i am seeing the large variety of guns in real. We can see weapons, few old trucks and tanks in the property that we see only in movies/TV shows. Get a Tuk-tuk to reach this place, not far from the city.

Get a guide to really understand the horror. The guides were busy so we wandered about and posed with the guns and took pictures. It wasn't until we spoke to the guide we really felt the gravity of what they endured and the horror of their lives during that period.
Some really good displays and make sure you speak to one of the guides.
Difficult emotionally. A well set out museum, out of doors.,Keep remembering that 33% of the population were killed in this civil war. Interesting to those who like military rusty memorabilia

War history. I travelled to this out door museum located in a mango plantation on my own purely out of interest about the past conflicts in Cambodia. A small well cared for museum of large motorized armored vehicles and small arms. The museum is not well patronized and is in jeopardy of closing if it does not attract more visitors.

Deeply moving. The museum was really good. There's a small entry fee but it's worth it. It's a minefield covered with tanks used in battle, and surrounded by information huts. GET THE FREE GUIDE! He told us so much about the war and moved us with his own experiences and scars. A real feel of cambodia and what the war did to its people. Unique experience.

Good museum great tour guide! . The tour guide really made it, very informative and gave his experiences about being a child solider in the Khmer rouge time period. The man has an incredible yet emotional life story, hes made of something stronger than steel. "The cat" is a legend.

Great museum for the warhistory of cambodja. We went by bike and paid 5usd entrance fee. They offer a free guide and we suggest to take one as they can give you a lot of extra information. The tour was interesting and we could hold the guns and climb the tanks. It was worth the money.

a great war museum. Congratulations to the curator...a well set up museum with plenty of interesting exhibits and photos in English. You can climb into the tanks and handle the weapons. Well documented and gives you a good handle on the history. Well done.

Interesting to a war buff. The primary value to this visit was talking with the guide who had been a boy soldier in the Khmer Rouge and the author of a book about that experience. The "museum" was small; more of a set of displays than a museum. Only thru the guide did I learn that the rusting hulks of military equipment had all been involved in the Cambodian civil war. The few personnel carriers on display had been so stripped that they were only the shell of the body. Unless you have a real interest in Cambodia's recent military experience, this should not be high on your list.

Unless you have nothing to do.. Handful of gutted tank/military vehicle skeletons. Mortar, ammo and landmine displays. Hands-on small arms. The fake minefield is somewhat interesting. Not worth it, but they have knowledgeable guides so if you want to help them, go ahead and visit.

Amazing- do not miss!!. The museum is mostly outdoors (although some is undercover), so keep that in mind the weather when planning your visit-(bring sunscreen, hats, or raincoats if necessary). People with children should be aware that the museum features some quite gory images of injuries and our guide even pointed out human bones remaining inside a blown out tank. It is possibly not suitable for very young children.This museum is very visual- as a civilian, you will probably never see so many tanks, weapons, bombs, guns, land mines, cannons and artillery in one place. You have a guide take you around for free (although tips are encouraged, and our guide was well worth it). Our guide was a survivor of the war, gun shots and land mine explosions and kind enough to show us his numerous scars, injuries, prosthetic limb and shrapnel in his body. He was very knowledgeable and interesting. We really enjoyed our visit and learned a lot.

Worth the money. It's only 5USD and you can have a tour guide to share the history about the war in Cambodia and also their personal experience. The best thing is that this museum allows you to hold and take picture with the exhibits such as grenades, rifles and many more without any restriction but must put it back in the right place.

Very interesting. A great background to recent Cambodian history. The informative tour guide told us all about his wartime experiences. His personal accounts made the history come alive and were very emotional, but also, at times, quite humorous. A very interesting museum.

A must visit museum. The reality of the futility of war close up and personal.. This was by far and away the museum I will remember most from our travels in Vietnam and Cambodia. The guide who showed us around, just our family of 4, was a victim of the war and was humble, forgiving and honest. He spoke reasonably good English. It is in a field, was not busy when we visited and some of the images and stories you see and hear during your visit are shocking and hit home the futility of war. Definitely worth a visit. We went by Tuk tuk.

landmine. Its a great place to know more about the history of war in cambodia. Landmines, plane, guns and even tank used during the war are all here. It explains everything from the goverment leaders and to the cambodia victims. Pictures of the actual killing of victims are here. It will take you just 35 minutes from angkor with an entrance fee of USD 6. worth the visit

Really worthed!. We arrived early after opening, one of the best things to do and know about this Country. Free tour guide which is a must. You get to know those people closely. You can touch and manipulate the amrs. Great museum.

Great. If you are interested in war history this place is a must, it is not huge or the usual sterile museum environment, it is hands on our guide was a former child solider and one of the most interesting people I have meet in my travel, it is only a short tuk tuk ride away.

The cat is awesome!. My fiancée and I went early in the morning right after they opened and ended up getting the "free" tour by ourselves. They do ask for tips at the end but I guarantee its way worth it. We were guided by Moun Sinath who is nicknamed "the cat" because he has died 13 times and lived to tell about it. I did not know much about Cambodian history related to the Khmer Rouge just that there were child soldiers and a lot of land mines. The cat lived through this horrible time in Cambodian history and will show you the physical memories he has scarred onto his body including his prosthetic leg from encountering a land mine and the shrapnel he still feels under his skin. You will also be taken to a tank where one of his friends died and his bones are still able to be seen. This museum is amazing and you would be upset to miss it. Learning about history from someone who lived through such a horrible time was amazing and I felt honored that he shared his story with us.

Wheelchair accessibility. Interesting attraction, with fee entry for people with disabilities (normally $US6). Museum is mostly accessible, but there is some steep ramps and tricky pathways. Tour guide is free, offering interesting, sometimes humorous, stories. Worth a visit.

A museum of historical value. It is not a sight seeing tour but a place to reflect on what happened to the people of Cambodia. War buffs will admire the extensive collection of guns and large military equipment

Simple Museum. It's a very simple museum. There is a vast array of vehicles, artillery, weaponry and equipment on display, such as T-54 tanks, a Shenyang F-6 fighter, aMil Mi-8 helicopter and the D-44 85mm divisional field artillery gun. The collection on display was gathered since 1999 from provinces in which the most savage fighting took place (Siem Reap and Odor Meanchey) and is a mix of Chinese, American and Soviet hardware. Competition from scrap dealers was not the only problem the museum faced as it gathered its collection: most of the machinery was very heavy and it was difficult to gain access to dense jungle areas to remove the items. Before being used during the various conflicts that raged across Cambodia, some of the war machines have seen action during World War II. Among the collection there are also many sorts of landmines and photographs from the defined period of time in Cambodia.

Worth a visit just to hear the amazing story of Cat!. This is an interesting place to visit, but more so as a result of our tour guide who has just had the most interesting life, literally having lived through so much. Cat had such a good spirit despite having been through so much!

War graveyard. The museum was an interesting place to visit. The tour guide provided by the museum had excellent English (by Cambodian standard), though he is not a veteran, he was very familiar with both the history and the weapons.  Firstly, the articles and history provided about the war with the Khmer Rouge were pretty brief but were clear enough to understand. I think the museum can improve in this aspect as there can be more information provided, which would further the visitor's understanding of the war. Secondly, there were a large variety of weapons and vehicles and the number was actually quite astonishing. I'll write a brief list of weapons I saw (I'm not too familiar of model names so it might not be too clear):-AK47-M16-PPS, PPSH5-M1 Garand-A variety of light machine guns-A variety of rocket launchers and grenade launchers-Landmines-Bomb and artillery shells-A jet and helicopter-A variety of tanks and artillerySuprisingly, all these were also accessible, for example, you are allowed to pick up rifles and climb on tanks, compared to other war museums where everything is locked up or fenced in. The tanks were lined up neatly, which created a creepy atmosphere. I would definitely recommend this museum to others as it is suitable for all ages and the content is fascinating. I would say this is a must go in Siem Reap and it would not take up too much time.

Sobering but fascinating. Every visitor to Cambodia should visit a museum or monument dedicated to the effects of war on the country and this museum, in some ways, was even better than the Killing Fields or S-21 in Phnom Penh, because we had a private tour from a real war veteran. Sinath, the Cat with nine lives, shared his personal experiences of war with us, giving us a far deeper understanding of the horrors of war than a pre-recorded audioguide or book could have. Seeing and hearing about the horrors that happened less than a generation ago was terrible, but necessary so that no such atrocity can ever happen again.

Must See. We saw roadside advertisements for this museum and decided to give it a quick look. We were positively surprised! A really informative spot that teaches you a lot about Cambodia's very recent history. It really makes you think!

Enticing experience. The journey there took us a bit time. But the experience and what we saw there is absolutely worth it. If you have not seen landmines, guns and weapons of war, this is where you should visit apart from temples.

tour of the war museum. visited the war museum as son is interested in the history of the war. he found it very interesting and he enjoyed his time there. I enjoyed it as well but not as much as he did

Very much a history lesson, real eye witness account by a veteran of the conflict. We went to the War Museum today as I had read a lot about the museum on Trip Advisor. Quite the history lesson and we were lucky enough to have met the "Cat" as he is know by the locals. His true name escapes me but I think Siroth is close.He guided us around the exhibit and gave his account as a solder fighting against the Khmer Rouge after they wiped out his family. Who can know the horrors of war better than those who lived it, suvived it. Not unscathed though as he has the wounds of 3 bullets and those of shrapnel along with some bad burn scars from a mate who wasn't careful enough to check around him as he launched a rocket powered grenande in the heat of battle. Fascinating. Well worth doing for the story from a real life veteran of the conflict. Shocking stories of 'Child Soldiers' brainwashed by Propoganda and conscripted into the Genocidal reign of Pol Pot - not his real name though you'll find. And find out who funded and backed this scrap, who committed arms and machinery and enough mines that today there is 2.5 mines for every man woman & child in Cambodia. There is around 2-3 deaths / casualties per month through land mines that remain in the landscape....

A must see, use the guide . If you walk around without the guide you will just see the remnants of tanks rusting away without getting any real information. I visited this museum 10 years ago as well and the guide is the same chap, but what he tells you will vary on the day. He cannot always talk about the same issues as it gets too emotional for him. Yes the tanks are not well maintained and polished, but that's not the message that is conveyed here, where else would you see human bone and footwear from a corpse left in a tank? The plane on show belonged to Pol Pot, but such information is not written anywhere, which is why a guide is recommended. This museum portrays the futility & horror of war.

OK, but better in Phnom Phen. Everything is old - obvious. but the issue is that is badly maintained. In PP much better. If you think weapons that kill are good....I just visit because this is a major history of this wonderful contry

Solemn. The war museum is a very solemn experience. Our guide had lost his family to the war and certainly knew the history very well.There is a good collection of artefacts from spent landmines, to guns, to tanks and planes.Well worth the trip.

The War Museum at Angkor Wat. We went to this “museum” on 16 July. It was a complete waste of money and time. The “guide” was not able to communicate effectively and may have known little except to pull up his shirt and show his scars. He was quite interested in his tip and once this was accomplished he was gone on to the next group. The “curation” as such is ridiculous. Rusting guns and armored vehicles placed around a mosquito infested field with little backstory to help make this experience come alive. While my wife and I wanted to understand the history of the war in Cambodia, it was not to happen here.
A suggested visit. Please visit the War museum to get a full understanding of the genocide that was carried out against the Cambodian people.

Insightful, educational, enjoyable. . I really had no idea what to expect when arriving at the war Museum. We were told to visit so we took the advice. I thought we were going to look at tanks and guns but it turned out to be so much more. Our guide, Lim, took the time to really educate us on the wars and other challenges faced by the Cambodian people. We learned things from Lim that we'll never read in a text book and he really opened my eyes. I am so happy we visited the museum and highly recommend getting a guided tour. Don't be afraid to ask questions. We bought a book, a beer, and made a donation before leaving, nobody was asking which always makes giving feel nicer.

well worth a visit. A truly amazing experience that will stay with me forever. It is very confronting and quite surreal to think such a thing could happen not so long ago. If you want to learn more about Cambodia's past this is the place. You can get a free tour guide (highly recommended) who explain their own personal heartbreaking experiences as you walk through the place - it is a no brainer to tip them at the end.Our guide was Sinarth (or the "Cat) and he was truly inspiring. There is an Aussie there who has written a biography on Sinarth so make sure you check that out as well.

The part of my Cambodian trip I am still talking about and glad I know about.. This museum is one of the best I have been to and one of the most sobering experiences. The museum is outdoors in a field and exhibits all kinds of arms, landmines and machines used during the war in Cambodia. The tour guides are war veterans and are open to talking about their experiences during the war and while some stories are tough to listen to, our tour guide really wanted us to understand what went on in Cambodia and what the Cambodian people went through – and possibly most interestingly, how the war has shaped the Cambodia of today. I would say that please if you go here, be respectful – people lost their lives in the tanks and aircraft in the museum. People died from the guns on display – DO NOT play with them for photo opportunities like a stupid tourist did while we were there – it is extremely disrespectful. I was truly fascinated by the War Museum – PLEASE VISIT – if in Cambodia I feel we all owe it to understand the Cambodians people history as much as we can. This is not an entertaining activity, but it is educational and emotional. I urge you to visit.

Important part of a visit to Siem Reap. Its hard to even comprehend the events in Cambodias recent history and what the people have been through, but as a time out from temples and ancient history it is interesting and important to get an insight into the events that are a major influence on Cambodia today and something the country is still suffering from. Moun Sinath's tour was what made the museum, with his first hand stories about the exhibits and unbelievable life during war times giving context to everything we were seeing. The museum is very hands on and features genuine hardware from years of conflict, it isn't about shiny exhibits but rather raw, sobering reminders of war. Should be part of every itinerary, but visited with respect (leave the selfie stick at home).

A sobering experience. I watched the movie "The Killing Fields" When it was released and will never forget those haunting scenes and the feelings of shock and disbelief that people can intentionally carry out such atrocities! Ever since I wanted to learn more about the civil war in Cambodia and this visit to the War Museum was an incredible experience. We took a tuk-tuk from our hotel. I can really recommend this to all visitors. The driver was a lovely young man who communicated well in English. In the tuk-tuk you really get to see a bit of the countryside on the way to the museum and we took lovely pictures of the paddy fields and rural scenes.Arriving at the War Museum, entry only $5 per person, we met a guide at the gate who showed us around and shared his experiences as a child during the civil war. I believe that this personal account of what had happened in Cambodia contributed to making the experience. One hesitates to say "fantastic", since it is a museum that gives testimony to the horrors of the war. I do believe, however, that a visit to the museum was a highlight to our visit to Siem Reap and a must to all tourists. It is more than mere sightseeing. It is an experience that makes you reflect on humankind! Do take the time to visit and do ask one of the guides to take you on a tour. It wouldn't be the same without listening to their personal recounts of the war.A bonus to the visit is the incredible photo opportunities.

Honest and strong museum. This museum is one of the best I have ever been to. Not because of the arms exhibited, but because of the message it is sending. The museum is build on a former landmine field where people were hurt or killed. All the tourguides (offering free tours) are war veterans or were children during the khmer rouge time, they incorporate their personal experiences and stories in their tour which makes it honest and really makes you understand how much they have been through. Go here to understand the impact the history of Cambodia has on their current society. Don't go here to get entertained, the museum (like it should) focusses on making you understand how something like this could have ever happend and how a war has the power to destroy an entire country and it's population. For me, all the negative reactions do not make any sense, obviously, the museum is not making a lot of profit and has to provide a living for these war veterans. A museum that is trying to teach you all the negative impacts of a war is not going spend the little money they make on expensive restauration of rusty tanks. The point is that something like this is never supossed to happen again, not to entertain. Please visit this museum and join a tour, you won't regret it.

Informative, and very good tour guide. I would definitely recommend to check out the history at the war museum. Only costs $5 to get in and there are guides that can show you around when you get in there if you choose. I would recommend doing this as they give you more information on the history and information that you wont get from just walking through the museum ourselves. We were lucky enough to have 'Cat' be our guide. He is called this as he has used over 9 of his lives! He even let us feel the shrapnel that is in his legs after all of these years!!

Guide essential. As others have said, this is an attraction that has lots of armour in a field which is quite basic and doesn't flow. I'm glad we went to it though as the guide that took us around had lots of stories about his time in the army and the fact that he had endured a lot during his lifetime.

History lesson. Well worth a visit if you are interested in history. Free guides are available at the entrance, but you shuold tip them at the end of the tour. The museum itself is outdoors, and the guided tour takes about 30 min(depending on your questions). You will get information about the history of the Khmer people, the civil war and Khmer Rouge. Walk among the weapon used during the civil war, get information about land mines and take pictures of tanks and artillary used by the Russians and later used by the Cambodian people.

Informative and insightful . It's still shocks me the atrocities see in this country just a few short years ago. Whilst some of the commentary was hard to stomach for kids (11 and 9) it wasn't too graphic that it wasn't good for them to hear some of it. The military representatives were wonderful. $5 entry pp with free guide - obviously tipping at the end is recommended.

Fantastic. Be sure to get a guide- free but please please tip them. Every guide has some experience of war time in Cambodia and will share their experiences and stories with you. A difficult listen but so worthwhile. "The cat" is a fantastic guide if you can find him

War museum visit. Another sobering experience of the perils of war. Definitely recommend the tour guide who has experience of the war. The artefacts are old but demonstrate the the repercussions of war - very sad

Eye Opening. As someone who loves history, this museum is fascinating. We opted to have one of the guides at the museum take us around. The guides are free, but make sure you have some extra small bills to tip. If you don't use the guide there is not much to the museum except some old artillery and tanks. However, having a survivor of the Khmer Rouge talk about the history is eye opening. They also sell some interesting books in the little shop. I bought one about Killing Fields as told from children survivors and the book is amazing.

Not to be missed when you visit Siem Ream- Eye opening experience. The entrance fee was 5USD per person. The guide service is free but please tip them as they are amazing. Our guide , Meng Ratha was a walking encyclopedia full of information and immense knowledge about the Khmer rouge period. He also shared his personal stories to us. The tour takes about an hour and you are free to explore the exhibits on your own after that. As it is an open/outdoor museum concept, I would suggest to plan the visit accordingly. It was drizzling when we visited, but we managed with umbrellas.The entire visit was very eye opening and a valuable experience. Do not miss out this museum when you visit Cambodia. It

Worth a Look. I visited the museum on a hot humid July day. The trees provide welcome relief. The entry fees is reasonable. Guided tours are available but you can also wander about at your own leisure. Most of the recovered implements of war are rusty former shadows of their original form. It could be better if some displays were restored especially the tanks.

Take a guided tour. The museum itself is not worth it but the free guide (the Cat) made it more worthwhile. Hearing about how life was for the Cambodian people and what the soldiers had to endure was a valuable experience. The tour takes about an hour and then you are free to walk around the exhibits yourself -probably allow 2 hours all up.

the tour guides are incredible!. we loved the war museum, the tour guides are free (Tip Them!) and incredible with great stories of there own experiences, you get to hold and touch everything unlike some museums that lock it all away behind glass. well worth going to.

Very interesting. The museum in itself is not worth it. Not much to see and most of it is outdoors. But the experience of learning from the people how they lived trough those times is worth it. Very eye opening.

Take a guided tour.. Very interesting to walk around. Most of the exhibits are outside, so unless you don't mind the rain, stick to a dry day. Make a donation and go with a guide, they are informative and have really interesting stories to tell of their experiences. Our guide was "The Cat" a great guy with an amazing story. There's even been a book written about him.

Eye opening experience . Not so much the museum, but the free guided tour was very eye opening to what the Cambodian people have gone through and what the soldiers have had to endure. Talking to our guide (the cat) makes it much more real than looking at guns and tanks. This was a really cheap but great experience at 5USD entry fee and whatever tip you want to give to the veterans while you're there. Not to miss if you're in Siem Reap. I'd probably allow 1 to 2 hours to enjoy the tour.

Bad choice. Before visiting this museum, I though it would be an interesting visit, but was not so happy after the visit. You have the guide there, but they will only target the European looking people. You have to look around your self. With some rusted tanks, riffles, a helicopter and a plane, there is nothing to see. If you are a war fan and want to see those thing, you can have a try.

For what it is, 5-star. We opted to use our own guide and not the guy waiting at the ticket counter. Easy outdoor museum close enough to the airport for a quick trip. Get up close and personal with all the weapons, guns, mines, tanks to get a sense of history.

Old but not forgotten. Taking a stroll and learning about history is a good activity but if that bores you guess what? you can touch and take picture with the exhibits ie, grenade, machine gun, landmines and some old guns war stuff. How cool is that?

A Braod Range Collection. This museum reflects the range of soviet weapons and equipment used in the Khmer wars after PolPot. It is not a large area to traverse but it is easy to get around. It is not covered and will not suit visits during rain. An enjoyable sojourn.

Make time to see this important part of this country's history . The exhibits themselves are basically old, rusted munitions and weapons and vehicles. But the tour guides and their personal stories are an incredible part of this country's amazing and heart breaking story. And as we found across this whole country, people want to tell their stories because it is the a way to pay tribute to everyone who lost so much and it is a way to hopefully avoid it ever happening again.

Small but Powerful. As an American, war is a distant thing for me most of the time. For these people, they are still dealing with the mess left behind from the last war. The field full of old battle machinery is interesting. The guide was a veteran and explained everything well. It's a memorial as much as a documentation of all of the weapons and destruction caused by the Communists.
More evidence of the futility of war. The provided guide details their own experience and explains the different players in the Cambodian conflicts over the years.

Sombre . Interesting place. Smallish and the exhibits are in poor condition because they are exposed to the elements. However they are still worth seeing. The free tour is a must. The guide explained much of the history of the war and told anecdotes. It wasn't that long ago. Pretty tough times for the country but Cambodians seemed to have pulled through and are now working to make it a better place.

Get the first hand account of the modern and sad, bloody Cambodia history.. Get the first hand account of the modern and sad, bloody Cambodia history. We learnt a lot from the in house volunteer guide (I supposed they live on tipping).

Definitely worth a visit . Not far from the heart of Siem Reap and worth a visit, but you need to engage one of the guides to bring the experience to life. They're free but you tip them what you think they're worth at the end, which we thought was quite a bit. Very interesting insight into what these people have been through and the amazing spirit that sees them generally so happy and positive today.

Interesting place. $5 US entry free which is money well spent. There are free guides available to take you on a tour around the museum and explain the different aspects of the display . Our guide was very young however was still very knowledgeable about the history of the war. You can tip the guide if wished (as we did) and there are also donation boxes available for different charities. Was interesting learning about the amount of active land mines still in this country and the effects they are still having. The week before we visited the museum, a 15 year old boy had lost a limb but standing on an active mine. So sad that they continue to bear the brunt of this.
interesting. war museum was in siem reap city it very nice one ,entrant just 5usd had free tour guide explain about history .

Average. This museum cost $5 per person, which is a bit pricey by Cambodian standards given what they have on display. There is an assortment of rusting tanks, artillery and smaller weapons with fading signboards. There are also some more interesting covered areas with many mines, artillery shells and rifles and small arms with explanatory flyers. Free guides are available to walk you round and explain the exhibits. In my view the landmine museum is better.
Guns, tanks, artillery and mines.. You can see here the remains of war and the history that goes with it. Old tanks, worn out plane, land mines and many more.

Ramshackle, depressing but necessary. I took a tuk tuk out to the War Museum: Cambodia on a hot weekday afternoon. Handprinted signs, fading photographs and rusting machinery of war in a tended garden grove. The typewritten summaries of the 20th century wars dispassionately painted the contributions of the main players to the series of catastrophes that characterised the 1960s - 1980s in Cambodia. (although to say "players" minimises the guilt of individuals, groups and whole national administrations.)$5 entry for non-nationals. Tour guides are free (and passionate) and a novelist was on hand to talk about his book detailing individual experiences of the war.I left feeling that the Killing Fields were the worst, but only one of a series of crimes inflicted on this gentle people. The ramshackle nature of the museum is a reminder of the challenges that Cambodia still faces.

interesting. Great place to spend a couple of hours walking around learning a bit about the war in Cambodia, some of the exhibits look a mess, but you have to understand, these have been dragged here directly off the battlefield. This isn't just poorly maintained stuff. This is real battle damage. There are also plenty of different weapons and munitions to get hands on with and lots of information boards. The museum is on the site of an old minefield.Great place to visit if you are into this type of thing. Even if you aren't, it's worth a visit, just to learn what happened.
Relive the war. Even if you know only a little about the Cambodian/Vietnam war, strolling in between the used war vehicles is a very special feeling.

Confronting, but definitely worthwhile . Our ten year old decided she wanted to visit the war museum on a whim. It turned out to be one of the most interesting and confronting parts of our trip to Cambodia. I wouldn't have brought the kids here if they hadn't asked, though.

Personal and informative. As many have said taking one of the guided tours is a MUST not just an option. We were lucky to be shown around by Sinarth the 'cat' so named because he has conquered death so many times. As a veteran of the war he could bring the conflict to very personal level. There are many things to see but to gain an understanding you the history don't pass up the chance of hearing from those that still live it. Admission is $5 and guides are free but a tip is much appreciated. There is a small bookshop where you can also buy a book of Sinarth's life story.

Interesting. Lots of old Guns and tanks and other war memorabilia with pictures of the Pol Pot era. The guides are maimed with many wounds which they are happy to show. Entry was free with a donation expected to your guide. Not far from centre of Pub Street, short tuk tuk ride.

The best war musuem I have ever seen. This was a real surprise. I didn't expect to find a battlefield filled with dozens of tanks and armored car. My guide Sinart lost his leg in the battle. He was part of gov and Vietnamese forces that defeated Pol Pots Khmer Rouge in 1979. He was open and talked freely about the battle that most of us in the west have no knowledge of. I was in the Vietnam War and knew nothing about this part of history. I want to help support this site and keep as is to add to the missing history that stopped the most terrible period in modern time.

Khmer Rouge. Depressing as the Khmer Rouge era was and as depressing as the lack of justice and prosecutions in the post UN period is for Cambodia this collection of Soviet (Chinese) weapons and munitions and mines from all over the world are a reminder of the carnage still being wrought on the people from the 20% of mines still unaccounted for and the UXB's from B52's that are all killing and maiming every week. keeping history alive! Go, see,learn.

An Educational Visit. I had the chance to visit this museum at the end of May as a reprieve from all the temple touring. I'm glad I did! This was a very educational experience for those who are unaware of Cambodia's modern history. Upon arriving at the museum, be sure to get connected with a free tour guide! It's the guide that really makes the experience. You'll see lots of real life war memorabilia, from vehicles, to weapons, to clothes. After the guided tour, which was I think around 1.5 to 2 hours, you can free roam the museum. For those who are sensitive to heat, be warned, as the museum is outdoors, and on a hot day, it can get really hot!

Worth the visit. We didnt even know about the war museum, but after speaking to some other visitors they recommended going and it was very interesting and informative especially to guided tour. Gives a good insight into Cambodia's troubled past.
Filled with history. Advise is to get one of the tour guides to be able to give you the history of the site, as to just walk around does not give you an insight to the meaning to the local history.

Important to Visit. This small intimate museum is worth an hour of your time to see and pay tribute to the memory of the Camodian people who are still experiencing the pain of their suffering. Their war ended within our generation and it's amazing to think that any Cambodian you meet older than 30 was an elementary school aged child during the war - it ended only ended 17 years ago. Only a 10 minute tuk tuk ride from our hotel (your driver will wait for you to finish the tour). The entrance fee is $5 each and the guides are free but plan to provide them with a tip for the tour. You will see military equipment, ammunition, and land mines. It's not fancy but spending an hour to remember and reflect on the genocide they experienced will provide a different perspective for you on this country that you are vacationing in. Teens really enjoyed it as well.

Recent History. This museum is as much a part of Cambodia's history and any of the temples.When you look at the exhibits you think its just a rusted out old tank etc but when you read the papers in the exhibits you realize they were still in a civil war as recently as 1999.To visit this museum and not be amazed would be hard to do.
Thought provoking. This is a very short trip but still worth making. It is mainly manned by ex-soldiers earning a wage from taking you around. Very basic but gives you the facts

Sad but good to see! . Went today. Such a peaceful setting under trees with such a sad story! I learnt so much today. Our guide was friendly and gave so much details. I am happy to have gone and to now know more of what these amazing people have endured! Nobody wins a war...everybody loses!

History and inspiration. Boys will be boys is what I always say. Although the boys in my family enjoyed the temples, they had an equal interest in the War Museum which had a good collection of tanks, ammunition, with a helicopter and plane on display. Admission is free (donations welcome) and a free tour guide is available. We, however, went around on our own, read about the fate of Cambodia in the displays, and even met a ok author (Karl Levy) who wrote about the life of Sinarth (who was there in person) who survived Khmer Rouge. The visit was informative, reflective and inspiring.

Good sight to see en-route to the airport. This museum was definitely insightful, and it was fascinating if at times a bit jarring to hear the war being spoken about by a former KR boy-soldier who later defected and joined the Vietnamese. The exhibitions had a great number of artifacts, and well-written explanations in English. The tanks in particular effected me as the signs all indicated when they had been destroyed or found and some were within the 21st century - which just reinforces just how recent Cambodia's tragic past was. It is a quick one though, we were there for about an hour and a half and that was at a very slow pace. It's on the way to the airport though, and worth the stop if you are going to be going by. I would say, if you feel like you only have time for one war related museum, my personal preference was the Landmines museum - the War Museum did have a larger variety of war artifacts (more than landmines) but the Landmine Museum was more unique and moving experience for me.

Confronting, sad and inspiring all at the same time. My husband and I made the trip out of this museum based on the reviews in TripAdvisor and we were not disappointed. A tuk tuk from our hotel was US$10 and he waited for usThe day we went was hot and still which added to the experience. When we arrived we were greeted at the gate by a young man who told us a guide would be with us in a few minutes. Our guide when he arrived was a young man whose Grandfather had been detained and later executed simply for being an academic. His Father died fighting against the Khmer Rouge and his Mother died of a broken heart. He was raised by his Grandmother. I really wish I could remember his name.We were taken around the museum grounds by this young man who talked non stop about what we were seeing and told us so much about the conflict and the dreadful things that happened to the Cambodian population. The photographic displays combined with the history and the stories were very confronting and incredibly sad. It was also inspiring to see how the people who has survived this horror were working to rebuild their country and did not take anything for granted.There are many guns and landmines and other implements of death that can be handled and examined if you wish to.Once our guided tour was finished we wandered around looking at the various different tanks and guns as well as the MIG jet and Sikorsky helicopter. The tanks, guns etc are displayed exactly as they were found. Bullet holes, mangled metal and gaping holes all very much in evidence which really made everything so real.We also got to meet and talk at length to Karl Levy, an Australian author who has penned the biography of Sinarth who fought in the Cambodian Army against the Khmer Rouge. Sinarth is also a guide at the museum but unfortunately was not rostered on the day we were there.A visit to this museum has to be included on the Must Do list for Siem Reap. All of the guides are either Cambodian soliders or the children of deceased soldiers so they have a very personal connection with everything they are telling you about.

Such an interesting attraction!. We went there in the late morning and I was worried about the heat. Even though its an outdoor museum, it was well planted with trees, making it a lovely place to stroll around. Very interesting being able to view armoured tanks, mines, etc as we only usually see these in the movies. A great outing. Its on the same road heading for the airport. The entry fee is 5 USD. Bring some mosquitoe repelant. You may need it.

Must visit. Good insight of what Cambodia went through in achieving the Independence... The tales of sacrifice and pain well captured in pictures. The guide there was very knowledgable and gave good details.

Feel the ghosts. You see touch and feel sadness as history unfolds before you...you look at it as rusted old weapons or you can see it as a horrific war that many people sacraficed their lives for and appreciate that history is restored so people will see "war is hell "

Very sad. Our tut tut driver took us we paid a very small amount to get in and asked for a guide wich is free , it was very interesting but sad the guide gave us a good in sight into everything that had gone on. We tipped him at the end and found this was a place of interest

Worth a visit if you have time . We hadn't planned on going but our trip to the killing fields was such a quick one and our tuk tuk driver recommended we go (wanted more money). We got a tour guide who didn't cover the whole area which we were glad for to be honest as it meant we had our own time to take it all in. There wasn't really any information anywhere, just old tanks and grenades etc so the tour guide is needed if you are interested at all in what happened. Our tour guide was really sweet, quite young and told us that only his father, mother and grandmother had survived, he made me cry.

A moving experience. The museum is outside of Siem Reap, just off the road to the airport. It has a large collection military vehicles and artillery, as well as a MIG19 plane and MI-8 helicopter. There is also a large collection of mines, shells, rifles and machine guns. The setting is quite serene and peaceful with plenty of shade. It was worthwhile taking a guided tour as the guides were Cambodians directly affected by the various wars from the 1970's until the 1990's. Guides are free of charge but a tip is appreciated, as is a donation to land mine victims who are no longer supported by the Cambodian Government. I had the opportunity to meet Sinarth a guide who was a child soldier under the Khmere Rouge in the 1970's and Karl Levy, an author who has written a biography of Sinarth and was selling it at the museum. Karl also has alternative views on the rise of the Khmere Rouge and their ultimate defeat. In all an interesting time.

Well Worth a Visit!!. We were on a tour by Tuk Tuk of Siem Reap and our driver suggested we visit this museum. Having just finished looking at the killing fields memorial in another part of town, we thought this may be interesting but we knew nothing about it beforehand. It was a most rewarding and interesting experience. So glad we took the free guide option. Our guide was very knowledgeable as well as interesting to talk to and spoke very good English. Learnt much about the tragic war history of this beautiful country of Cambodia. Came away wanting to learn more as it is amazing what has happened in this country, particularly during the horrific Khmer Rouge rule 1975 to 1979. Interesting to see transport helicopter and aeroplane up close as well as see & learn about land mines that have caused so much pain & trouble, even today. Relatively small entry fee and we were happy to give our guide a good tip. No pressure to give donations, or even tip and, unlike many other places we visited there was no-one near entrance hassling us to buy something. Highly recommended if visiting Siem Reap
Taste of War. Can't help but feeling sad over what war can do to the human! The arms and the exhibits strengthens my belief in war should be avoided at aa cost.

Great for young kids. Visited here with my 5 year old on 2nd day in Siem Reap. It was extremely hot and after a full day temple visiting the day before I needed somewhere different and a little cooler for her. This place is mostly under trees so lots of shade and lots of things to look at and clamber on. Also raised a lot of basic questions for her about war, Pol Pot etc. She's a little young for getting too deep into these things but she came away knowing more than she had entered with. Older kids will grasp it better. There's a basic little refreshment place where you can grab a cold drink.

free guide is not free. i guess this museum running by private organization or company.Some guide was a victim of khmer rogue during 1975 to 1980 civil war .They explained what happened and experience of war.finally,they will asked donation to him privately.So a guide is not free and you needed to paid for admission for 5 dollars.

Good, but get a guide. We had a your tour guide who didn't seem as dramatic as some of the others but we still massively enjoyed it. Won't take any longer than an hour. Tuk tuk there and back from Khmer Pub Street was about $4 and entry with guide was $5. Little bit of pressure at the end to tip but he deserved a little something.
Good to see. WAR museum is from Red Khmer about 37 years ago had many thing old Helicopter but interesting just 5$ for ticket including tour guide explain ,

Excellent museum - certainly worth a visit. I am surprised that this isn't higher up on Tripadvisor's list of activities for Siem Reap. The museum was well worth the visit. It is a little way (maybe 10 minutes from Pub Street). We hired a tuk tuk who waited there for us. 6 dollars return (May 2016). The cost for entry is 5 dollars and the tour guide is free. Our tour guide was superb. Very informative and really brought to life the whole thing. I would suggest that without a guide you wouldn't get much from the visit, as the about of written displays is minimal. The tour guide spoke from personal experience, which really bought it home. Sadly, not a history I knew much about, but the guide explained everything very well and I am left humbler, and far more knowledgeable. I would suggest that this should be on everyone's list for Siem Reap. You can handle/climb on any of the exhibits, which I didn't much like the thought of, but everyone who was there when we were, were very respectable - maybe holding a gun to feel the weight, but not posing with an AK47 that quite likely was used to kill. The fact that they are so happy for you to handle/play with all of the exhibits just brings home how normal, horrible and prevalent guns etc are in everyone's memory. I am surprised by a previous reviewer saying about pressure to donate. We had none - not even a mention. There was just a collection box at the gate which I left some money in through personal choice. A must see!

Worth a trip . Had a spare morning and thought we would have a look and really glad we did. Interesting to hear the stories of our guide who was only 35 and some of the things he witnessed was unreal. Very informative free tour and allowed us to learn more about the history of the country. We didn't have a chance to go to the land mine museum but this had a section on how this has impacted the country and the local areas which gave us more then enough information. Some of the old tanks, guns and helicopters were interesting to see up close and I would recommend a visit.

Not your average museum. Before visiting the museum one needs to throw out the notion that this is your normal war museum and comparable to those in Vietnam and the such. To me this was more of a bare bones museum with little fan fare and few displays to show, however that doesn't take away the experience and what the museum is really meant to be about. The tour guides put things into perspective and give you an insight of how things we're, which is usually done by a a veteran soldier so you're at least getting some first hand information and not something out of the history books. FRIENDLY TIP: the tour guide is free and they wont charge you any set fees or the such, the guide also won't be solicit you for money. Instead they may ask for a small donation and the amount is really up to you.

Worth a visit. You will see a lot of military equipment scattered around. There is one helicopter and one fighter jet on display. Worth a visit if you are interested in war history. Take a guide as there are not much explanatory panels.

A must see for all who visit Siem Reap!. Take a break from the temples and pub street and be humbled by the terrifyingly recent history of the people and land you are visiting. After reading some negative reviews by people saying this was an inferior war museum, I couldn't disagree more. The free tour guides are extremely personal and informative and unlike what other reviewers have written, they do not try to solicit money from you. One review said they asked for $20 at the end of the free tour - that couldn't be more wrong. They simply imply that a small donation will help preserve the museum and keep it running as it is seeing a decrease in visitors each month.Wear long pants and/or bug spray and with the guided tour, two hours is more than enough time. Visit and support the museum and keep the memory of those lost, alive.

Fun experience. If you have a little free time and into guns and tanks this is definitly a very fun activity! Entrance is $5, A veteran soldier will be your guide for the museum and he will tell you his experiences in the civil war,the exhibits are very cool and you can carry the guns for pictures and if you can ride the wrecked tank then its allowed! I definitly enjoyed here!

A surprisingly comprehensive museum. This museum is a display of some of the hardware used in the Cambodian civil war but also very much more in that there are personal stories to be told by survivors who work at the site. It certainly brought home to me the hideous cost to the Cambodian people of that terrible "Killing Fields" war.
Mankind. A visit to this place was quite sad after hearing the story from the soldier who had passed through the real situation of the war. But a place must visit.

Not as expensive as other Siem Reap attractions and interesting. If you're not interested in learning about Cambodia's war history or seeing old metal war relics, then this is not the place for you. Before you go, its important to understand that this attraction is cheaper because there is not much there to see. The enjoyment you get from the visit is in the tour guides. They each have a personal connection to the war and tell all sorts of stories during the visit. At the end they give you a sad story about something and ask for money. You're free to not donate but there is a bit of awkwardness if you don't. Just keep in perspective that even 1000 riel ($0.25 usd) is a decent donation in this country.I enjoyed the visit but I wasn't expecting the same calibre as other more expensive attractions in Siem Reap.

Appreciate a visit as a educational and humbling experience.. If you have any interest in the history of Cambodia and how it has affected real people then you must visit this museum. Yes it is not the fanciest, however it used to be a landmine field and has survivors of the war working as guides who are only informative as they have lived through this very recent history. Be interested, respectful and leave a tip. You may just realise how lucky you are!

Interesting and informative . This is a small, community-run museum, with an emphasis on employing disabled land mine survivors and veterans of the civil war and Khmer Rouge period, which sets it apart from other war museums in Cambodia. It is quite newly-opened and while the exhibits may seem sparse at first glance, there is actually a wealth of information to learn. Our guide, son of a veteran, was very knowledgable and shared with us known facts about the war but also his own opinions about the causes and effects. He spoke unusually candidly, and we felt we could ask him whatever questions we liked. A very interesting experience, and one that can easily be combined with a trip to the temples, to give you an overview of Cambodia's more recent history.

Terrifying, Intriguing, Heartbreaking, Fascinating. I cannot speak highly enough of this place.We ended up doing the tour with both Meng and again with Sinarth after we bought Sinarths book which has been authored by an Australian, Karl, who devotes much of his time to the venue and its people.The significance of this place and its story to the Cambodian people is incredible and difficult to even comprehend but it was an excellent follow up to our time in S.21 and Cheung Ek in Pnomh Penh.All the best to Sinarth, Meng, Karl and the team at the War Museum. May the Cambodian people never again have to suffer through the devastation of war.

Sas. These last few weeks, we've been doing a trip all throughout Southeast Asia, including Vietnam which saw the renown Vietnam war. We went to all of the war remembrance museums and this one in Cambodia is sadly not up to par with any of them. I'm aware of the financial limitations exposed on properties like this, but aside from the grass upkeep it seems like nothing else is being done to conserve many of the artifacts which is sad. Little to no information is provided on the artifacts. We were very disappointed.

Great Learning Experience. I visited this war museum on my second last day in Siem Reap. After spending 2 weeks here and trying to understand the culture, history and people. This was an interesting place to visit. Learning more about the Khmer Rouge, what happened, who did it and how it affected the country as a whole. It was interesting to think that the entire grounds were covered in Landmines and today is an outdoor Museum. We had a guide who was amazing - I am sorry I forget his name! Meng - Something I believe. Anyways, he was great and I got some great understanding of what happened. I know a bit more about Cambodian History and how resilient their people are and how much the country has flourished since everything happened only 40 years ago. I cannot wait to go back and see how much more they have accomplished and grown. My only suggestion is just that, to end the tour with something positive, to show some pictures of a war torn area during the war and then after. To show tourists how amazing Cambodian people are and how they have moved on and started all over again.

Worth to visit. It is not kind of clean and neat museum. But this museum is about helping victim of war. Their disabilities made them hard to make a living. This is about reminder that war should not happen anywhere else.
You will get a free guide so will be much easier to understand the story behind.

The guides stories make the place. The museum is open air graveyard of old war machines, photos and weapons. the very interesting part is the stories from the guides. The guide Sinath shared some heartbreaking stories with some surprising humour as he lived through the Pol Pot regime and was shot many times, had a leg blown off from land mine and showed us pieces of shrapnel still in his body. Boy has he had a tough life. Left him a good tip. They call him the cat because he has had more than 9 lives. Cambodia still has over 100 land mine casualties per year.very sad part of this countries history and to hear it firsthand and to see some of the blown up vehicles is worth the price of addmission.

Informative and interesting museum. This museum is outdoors and the simple layout is quite different from other museums I have been to. It has rows and rows of different tanks, vehicles, etc. that were used and discovered in parts of Cambodia. My favourite part of this museum is that they provide free guided tours around. The guide that showed us around the museum, sorry I forgot his name, had a very detailed explanation about everything and also talked about the history of Cambodia. It was very informative and I learnt a lot from him.

Scary and really made me think.... Received by an Australian man and guided either by people directly involved or whose forebears were directly involved in the war, it was interesting and thought provoking to see the hardware and the suffering brought about by it.

Worth your time if you are interested in the war period of Cambodia. This is an overall good Museum if you are or aren't familiar with the war that Cambodia went through. It is worth it to find out what the Cambodians went through, not that long ago. It will open your eyes to terrible truths that people experienced here.

Incredible experience - heart wrenching. We visited the museum which costs only $5 per person and includes a free tour guide. They have lots of old guns and tanks and land mines and relics from the war. They also have posted up a holistic description of what happened in the war for those that come not knowing too much. They have guns and weapons that you can hold to get a feel for what it must have been like for those impacted in war time.But the real part that made our visit was our free tour guide - "the cat" because he has died 13 times. His story was unbearably heart wrenching and at point had me nearly in tears. His entire family killed when he was a child and he joined up to the army because they would feed him and it was the only way to get food. He told us stories of seeing his friends die in front of him, bullet wounds, showed us the shrapnel still stuck in his body. He lost a leg from a land mine and also his wife to lung cancer from the uranium used in the weapons. Truly a remarkable man who has been through so much horror in his life, he was so kind to us despite the hurt and anger that he so clearly and rightfully still feels.

A sad piece of history. A War Museum is not a "must do" thing when you are traveling, but I think that visiting this place will make understand part of the history and the suffering of the cambodian people.
History. Was great to get to learn about the history and the guide was very informative. Was great that after the guide was finished we were left alone to wander around and have a good look
Fascinating. Go and talk to "The Cat" about his experiences fighting the Khymer Rouge, and how many times he's been shot, blown up, died etc. Eye-opening information!
Interesting Place. A place that hold the sadness of the Cambodia civil war where you can see the military equipment dated back to WW1 yet still prove to be deadly to the locals.

A salvage yard. The war museum is a neatly arranged salvage yard of antiquated military hardware. The equipment used during the war is quite amazing, only in that it was so incredibly outdated. Utilizing WW1 canons during the war is in itself impressive. There is very little information about the war or the purpose for the exhibits. Tour guides are an additional fee.

"Very fascinating place". The stories and photos tell a thousand words. "The Cat" tells his story and it is quite unforgettable. We could only imagine what it was really like and appreciated what these people had to endure and how young they were. Certainly worth the trip there, Recommend as it is all part of Cambodian history.
Interesting Place. Love hearing the war stories shared by the guide and it was a great experience to see and touch the landmines.

Important history. The war museum is about a 15 minute tuk tuck ride from central Siem Reap and it's worth it. It cost me $10 for RT ride (and my driver waited while I was there).I'm not as educated on Cambodia's own internal conflicts and it was devastating to see how war-torn the country is, and the fall out they still suffer from. This museum has artifacts like lanes and tanks that littered the country. The guides have very personal stories to share and it was tough to be an American witnessing from their POV what they have been through. By no means did they make me feel uncomfortable! They were very welcoming and friendly; it was just an interesting perspective and I am glad I took the time to visit.There's a $5 US ticket fee and then tips are encouraged for the guides.

Humbling and Informative. I recommend everyone that visits Siem Reap should not miss this museum. We had a personal tour guide (included in the small price of admission) that is a survivor of the horrible atrocities these people have had to endure, so we were able to get a small glimpse of what this country has experienced. He also threw in some humor throughout to keep things as light as possible, given the content. The collection of artifacts are wonderful to walk around and learn about, but the stories from our guide were very humbling and put things into perspective about what is really important in life. We were sad and somber during our visit here, but so thankful we were able to visit and learn so we can hopefully do more to help.

Good place to know about Vietnam War. "The Cat", which is the guide who tells the story of Vietnam War and also the very own experience during the war. He is a good story teller which will let you to really feels you're in the war. A goof place to remind us how terrible the war is and how blessing we are is we are to born in a war free country.

Use a free guide and get "the cat" if you can!. The guides at the Museum are what makes this place great. Honestly, if we didn't have a guide and just walked around on our own I probably would have rated this place as a two instead of 5. There are a lot of old tanks and memorabilia. Our guide "the cat" was excellent. He had been in the war himself. He had his leg blown off by a land mine, only had one eye and showed us all of his scars from bullet wounds. He even let us touch the shrapnel that is still underneath his skin. He was able to get us to climb up one of the tanks and show us the bones of his friend that still lay inside. Something that we would have had no idea about if we didn't take the guide. Guides are free too, so really there is no reason why you shouldn't get one. It only takes about an hour out of your day. Definitely worth it!

Thought provoking. The Museum itself is quite small and you can be round it in less than an hour, but the best part for us was our guide "Cat" who told us many stories as he had been a child soldier. The visit was then made better by meeting Karl Levy and chatting with him - he has written a book based on Cat's life and knows even more stories. Definitely a thought provoking trip and, as others have already said, a change from Temples!

Mournful Museum. Of course a very sad museum to visit. The mango orchard is littered with rusting war machines, helicopters and guns. A "free" guide called The Cat - because he has many lives - who has survived the terror of the Khmer Rouge tells his story. And there are plenty of texts explaining the conflict. Well worth a visit.
Great tour. This is worthwhile visiting. It was great to spend time with a soldier who could explain to us about the war. There are plenty of exhibits and machinery. It makes the war very real.

The tour guide was a war survivor. This place gives you a reflection on how awful the war was. The tour guide (free of cost) is included in the entrance fee. Our tour guide was a war survivor, which made it more interesting and realistic. Many sad stories.

One guide was explained us history of war.uses of guns & other wapons.. That is the place for Cambodians remind the war & terrible period
We have seen many type of weapons are made some of country's for Human-rights,Ha Ha ha just joke. who visits able to get idea about war. Entrance charge 5 US Dollar.

confronting shocking and insightful historical summary of cambodia's recent history. took a guided tour with cambodians who had first hand experience with the khmer rouge. horrific, confronting and necessary information about the horrors of war and struggle. a lot of historic war relics like tanks, rifles, landmines, helicopter and plane. recommended you play with the guns first before the tour because afterwards you will not want to touch them after hearing the horror stories of peoples tragedy and struggle
Not really worth going. There are guides in the museum go in a group so you can hear some history, but not really worth the effort to get there.

Amazing place!!!. A guide showed us around and told us many stories that gave me goosebumps. It's worth a visit. This place is really strange like a war graveyard with rusted tanks and helicopters scattered across the field

Well worth the time to visit.. For a break from the temples, this was a great place to visit. Shady grounds full of tanks and guns used through many Cambodian conflicts, information on the landmines used, and some Khmer Rouge genocide information. Best thing was a very informative and interesting talk by the Australian writer Karl Levy who spends time here and provides guided tours of the grounds. He will tell you to take the tour with one of the Cambodian guys, which I am sure is also a good choice for the local input they provide, but Karl is a great speaker, and his run down of the Khmer Rouge and political shananigans of this time in laymans terms was very interesting and informative. He has also written a book based on the real-life accounts of a young Cambodian boy growing up in those tumultuous years, which I bought a copy of and is proving to be a great read.I recommend a visit to the War Museum Cambodia for a break from temple hopping and a relaxed way to spend an hour or so in Siem Reap.

A must visit when in Siem Reap. Most people would go to visit Siem Reap for temples, but this place is great to learn the history of Cambodia and what it went through. Great stories from the guides, a really good day there.

Collection of old weapons and tanks, but the Cat was good. A small museum containing old weapons, tanks, mines, etc from the war against the Khmer Rouge.We were lead around by the Cat, a local who was wounded 9, 10, 13 (he eventually settled on 13) times, including being attacked by hornets in the museum. Was very interesting and provided info we were unaware of before re: the war.

Guide's story a highlight. I visited the museum early in the day and the exhibits were interesting but the guide was definitely the highlight. I had 'the cat' as a guide and he showed us his war wounds and told us the stories associated with the wounds. A real character.The land mines and hardware were very interesting and make sure you take the time to read the informative sheets on the history of Cambodian wars.

A must visit in Siem Reap . Fantastic experience. The free guides all have connections to the war whether they were part of it or their family members were. The personal stories were so touching and the guides were very knowledgeable. We spoke to an author Karl who wrote a book on one of the guides and he gave us a clear cut history lesson regarding the inner complexity of Cambodian war. Absolutely would recommend especially if you are going to to Phnom Penh.

Great Museum . Why isn't this museum in any guides of 'must' see places in Siem Reap! I'd noticed it by reading TA but hadn't seen it in any guides.Don't expect a flash museum this is down to earth and tells the Cambodian war story how it really was.The museum is set out in a mango grove with all the displays dotted around.
