You can hold the guns and touch the tanks if you want. There are huts that contain pictures and a story board to explain the exhibits in the huts.You can wander around on your own but to understand more you can take a free guide, please tip him after as they are volunteers and this is how the make a living. All the guides have a good knowledge and pass on experiences of fighting and it effects.Our guide was a young man called Meng. He didn't fight as was too young but knows first hand through the suffering of his family. He tells a heart breaking story of his school friend killed by a land mine when they we're walking home from school. He also passes on experiences told to him by the other guides.The tour took about 30 mins then we wandered back around the exhibits for another hour. It's about a 15 minute tuk tuk ride from the pub street area, the tuk tuk driver will wait while you visit. Entrance fee is only $5.

Very history lesson.. Overall this was a nice place to visit. The guides were a little busy as there was a rather large Chinese tour in the place. We had the owner show us around and he gave us a fantastic insight into the different guns and tanks there. It's a little rustic to say the least but the museum is helping wounded war veterans earn an honest living. I would have liked a Cambodian guide but we just arrived at the wrong time.

Cool. Great place to visit , we had the privilege to meet a great tour guide from the war! Told us some great story's everyone was so nice, so cheap aswel,lots to see loads to learn! Take a tuk tuk out or even hire a bike it's 15 mins from town!

Really worth a visit. On my last day in Siem Reap I had a few hours to kill before going to the airport and I found this museum wasn't far from my hotel. I decided to pay a visit since I'm interested in history and I have no regrets. A guide showed us around and told us many stories that gave me goosebumps. It's worth a visit if you are in the area, it's on the way to the airport so even if you pass by before you leave you won't regret it.

Ask for a guide to hear the fascinating history of cambodia. This place is really strange like a war graveyard with rusted tanks and helicopters scattered across the field however we followed a guide who took us through explaining the wars Cambodia had been involved with and, of course, the Pol Pot Khmer Rouge regime and its atrocities. It was really fascinating stuff and helped us understand a bit more of the country and its people. Hardly anyone there when we visited but I would say it is worth it.

Fascinating. We got a tour around by a local who has family connections to the war museum, and it certainly helped to give a much wider perspective to the visit. To just walk around a bunch of rusty military relics would have been a challenge without a guide. The guide helped us to better understand the recent (50 years) history, which turned into a fascinating hour or so tour. There is an entrance fee but the guide was free, although tips are always welcomed.

Best Tour. This was one of my favourite tours in Cambodia because we had a tour guide who could give us real-life accounts of what had happened. It was a heartbreaking tour, but I think it's necessary to get such a personal view of the war and its aftermath. The tour is free, and each guide gives his own account and personal story. It was moving to hear our guide tell us about his family.

Beautiful ! . Beautiful experience... An eye opener to Cambodian history and Khmer Rouge ruling. Very fortunate to get Mr. Sinnarth as our guide, speaking on his life experience during the war and he himself being a victim of landmines. Touching stories....amazing collection of tools from war times. Do not miss the chance to experience this place!!!!

Ethical tourism tip. Worth a visit if you have not seen landlines, guns, tanks and weapons of war. Some quite good photos of life during the Khmer Rouge terrors. Strongly suggest if you want to tip the guide then do it at the main building to be upfront with the organisation as money is shared. This way we be ethical tourists and show open and transparent appreciation.

Great tour!. The War Museum was excellent! Make sure you take the free guided tour the first hand account of the Kmer Rouge and Vietnam conflict was very compelling. This is all outdoors so make sure you are ready to spend some time outdoors.

A hidden jewel in Siem Reap. When we go there, we were the only ones there. I wasn't sure why but discovered later that the museum isn't on the list of things to do in Siem Reap of most of the visitors. Collection of military equipment ranging from pistols and guns to tanks and even a MilMi8 helicopter and a Mig19 is interesting (even if it is rusting away out in the open) but it is not as interesting as the stories you will here from your free (tip them at the end, they deserve it) guide. The guides are all connected to the war in some way. They are war veterans, war survivors, land mine victims... Our guide was a war veteran who was drafted in the army at the age of seventeen and got his arm amputated following a shrapnel from a grenade. His story was really touching and eye opening.There is a 5$ admission fee and you will need a Tuk-Tuk to get there. We had a Tuk-Tuk driver for the day of Angkor exploration so I can't say anything about what should be a reasonable price to get to the museum from the city.

Siem Reap War Museum - Very sobering. Wasn't sure what to expect and it was confronting but well worth visiting. Entry $5 USD. Free guides although a tip is expected at the end of the tour. Kyle Levy, an Australian, is currently working there and has written a book about the Cambodian boy soldiers, and specifically about Sianath (spelling probably incorrect), who is now 59 and also working there. He has so much shrapnel in his body from bullets and lost the lower part of one leg to a land mine yet he has an amazing spirit and willing to share some of his story. We were amazed that people could pick up the guns. Kyle is currently cataloging all the weapons so they are accurately identified by country of origin etc. The museum is relatively small with several huts displaying photos, equipment and clothing. There are many tanks and other pieces of large equipment set out in the grounds along with a couple of aircraft. Suggest that this is somewhere to spend an hour or two especially if you are looking to go somewhere away from crowds. Sobering and confronting but worth the visit.

A hidden treasure. Whilst it is interesting the rusting collection of mostly Russian military hardware, a lot of it war damaged and displayed in a former minefield, is not the main reason for visiting this museum. Your USD 5 entry includes a free tour from someone who was either involved in and/or injured by the fighting in Cambodia or otherwise has personal experiences which they will share with visitors. The visit is worth it for this alone.The museum is a bit off the beaten track but is only a short Tuk-Tuk ride from Siem Reap or any of the hotels. The driver will wait for you so negotiate a return fare up front.

Don't miss!. Most visitors to Cambodia are probably familiar with the Khmer Rouge period of the late 70s, as described in the movie, "The Killing Fields." But most are probably unaware that this was followed by 20 years of brutal civil war, much of it in the region that includes Siem Reap and along the Thai border. You will learn about that history here. What makes it special are the guides, each of whom has a personal story related to that civil war. The actual items in the museum, all of which are outside, are not that impressive by themselves, but when placed in the context of the guides' personal stories become quite powerful. Those items are mainly old weapons, but also a number of photos and historical documents.

Worth a visit. We weren't sure about this museum but it was great. You need a guide and they are available at the entrance. Entrance fee $6. Guide free but donation can be given. Stories are horrific and the displays are pretty good for the uninformed. Displays of mines, guns, bombs, tanks, etc. some photos are around the displays to add to the guide descriptions. It's all outdoors but mango tress provide shade. Not far out of city.

A past often ignored or overlooked. While we came to Siem Reap to visit the Ankgor temples, we thought it important that our 12 and 15 year old daughters also learnt about the modern history of Cambodia and the atrocities that happened here. We took a tuk tuk from Pub street and the driver waited for us while we spent time here to drive us back to town. Our guide was exceptional and the personal stories about the impact the war had on him and his family were very powerful and emotional. Well worth the visit!

Worth a visit. We initially wanted to see the landmine museum after having lunch in the pub street area, but were told it was at least a 30-45 drive. So the driver offered to take us here instead. When we arrived, we waited a few a minutes along with other visitors, for the free tour guide, who took part in the war. The guide was very knowledgeable having first hand experience and told many tragic stories along the tour. There were a variety of battlefield mines, tanks, weapons and other artillery vehicles to see. Not really knowing anything about the Vietnam and Cambodian war, we took away a lot from this experience and it really put into perspective the sad realties of war. Definitely worth a visit!

One of the highlights of our trip. Learned about this from the author Karl Levy, who also hangs out here in the day. Meeting him and hearing him speak along with the tour guides was fascinating and one of the highlights of our trip!

Good experience, but only because of the guides. After some good reviews on TA, we called here after a morning seeing some of the outlying temples. It is a great Idea, and a good way to recall the atrocities that the Cambodian People have been through. Lot's of old armaments, and land mines on view, but the information boards are a bit dated and could do with a visual revamp.The Guides have personal recollections of the time, and we went around with Meng Ratha a newish guide, who seems a little young, and looked a bit bored, but his father was in the Khmer Rouge and his family was decimated by the troubles. Being frank he was not as engaging as "the Cat" who we listened to later.

One of the saddest places I've seen. We visited the War Museum around lunchtime and found it very quiet in the scorching sun. We were greeted at the gate by an author who has written a book based on one of the war veteran guides at the museum, who we chatted to for quite a while as he explained his and the guides story.The guide, who was free, who showed us round the museum was none other than the subject of the book. His experience of being a boy soldier fighting against the Khmer Rouge, his harrowing experiences of growing up an orphan, his horrific injuries fighting against an evil regime, all made for a heartbreaking and touching tour around the remnants of war.For those wanting in tact replicas of war machinery and weaponry, this is not the place for you. But for those who want an insight into the real nitty gritty history, with an enigmatic tour guide with real life experience of these horrific events, this place is perfect.

Sobering and Informative - Great Little Museum. The actual artifacts will be intriguing for war buffs and give a great visual explanation for what the trappings of these conflicts look like. The guides make the experience - we had the Cat for our first go-around (see other reviews where he is mentioned numerous times) and then we jumped in with a very informative Australian guide to give us an overall history of the conflicts in the region. It was great,Bring your tuk tuk and have them wait because there is no other option back to town.

Very suggestive. We went there with the kids to understand more about the was and the Khmer Rouges ... We heard story of atrocities from our guide that was used as child soldier and was shoot several times. We bought a book to understand more Cambodia history..My suggestion is to get the most out the guide: they can really tell you the truth about the crudely of that era and you will learn how Russia was selling 2 WW weaponry to Cambodia.. Sad

interesting displays of wartime equipment. for something different to do while in siem reap go out here - our museum guide spoke to much about himself - he has been shot and died from every weapon there !!!

Truly Eye Opening. This collection of war artifacts helped bring to life the turmoil that has plagued Cambodia for the past three decades. While it's a bit unsettling to be able to touch and see so much weaponry, it's well worth the experience. The tour guides have many personal connections to the war and remnants of the war and share anecdotes that gave me a bit of a chill. After a day at Angkor Wat that is full of tourists, a short visit to the 'museum' gave me a glimpse of what life was and is really like for the Cambodian people. Tips? Definitely take a tour. It's only ~30 minutes but brings the history of the country to life.

Great museum with veteran guides. This museum is close to Siem reap and worth the visit. We had a veteran guide who survived the Khmer Rouge and had excellent English give us a tour and his own harrowing stories of that awful time in Cambodia. Definitely advisable for history buffs or military enthusiasts also.

Quiet outdoor museum. This is an relatively small outdoor museum that consists of old war relics. Probably good for military enthusiasts but I felt there was a lack of explanation at the exhibits so kind of difficult to understand the significance of what I was viewing- placards explaining role and significance of items would have been helpful.

If you're interested in weaponry . . . .. This is a quirky little outdoor museum that displays weaponry and war machines used in Cambodia over several decades. There are some photos of war victims. The guide was a former child soldier, who was badly injured while forced to fight for the Khmer Rouge, and he told us various anecdotes from his life. We were disappointed that neither he nor the museum provided any concise historical information about Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge regime.

Something different than temples. In a country where war has played such a major role in recent history, there are of course many war relics. In the War Museum, you can take a look at the war machinery. But even more impressive than the weapons of war are the stories of veterans who give tours and tell their own story.

A place you should see. We went here not knowing what to expect . But to find this wonderfully presented museum set up by locals who are sharing their stories of surviving the past. We had a guide whose knowledge of the events were incredible mostly because he lived and saw them as a child. He explained all the aspects of the conflict, the weapons, aircraft, mines and artillery. How propaganda was used against the people. How the country is still suffering with the unfound mines and the damage they are still causing to animals and humans. All the workers there are volunteers but all have been affected by the events that have happened.

Interesting and surprising. This place creates such mixed emotions. We chose to walk around without a guide and feel that for us it was best. The big machinery is scattered throughout a mango grove and the outer edges have lots of little huts with remnants of the war in them. You can hold weapons of all sizes and see the destruction these things caused through stories and photos on the walls.
war history. As we had been to the Killing fields and war prison in Phnom Penh this was a must to complete the history to the end as here was were Phol Pot last sta took place, excellent
Worth a visit to this little Museum. Enjoy my visit to this Museum. Learn a lot about the history of Cambodia Civil War etc.....Free Guided tour in English.

A small but complete musem. I went twice, and I am glad I did. The first day I just popped in quickly to have a look and was taken by the hardware on display, a lot of tanks and troop carriers, all rusty and with no wheels. I looked around, handled a few of the many guns and didn't think much of it. On the second day I went, because a son was on another excursion the day before I was lucky enough to get there in time to hear author Karl Levy give a very good summary of the root causes of the war and its key actors. Brilliant. Once he was finished we were handed over to a Cambodian veteran. It was only after he showed us one of his trip advisor reviews that I worked out he had introduced himself as Cat, or the Cat. To my Australian ears, and with his accent, I heard something altogether more vernacular! Well, what a story he has to tell, and he told it well, involving everyone in a 4D tour of the museum and his many injuries, he is called the Cat because of his 9+ lives. And why do all the vehicles have no wheels? Because they had all struck one of the millions of mines still in Cambodia. Once he said that it was obvious that the armour on these massive Russian vehicles had been torn apart like tissue paper, some as recently as in the late 90s. Again, not a big, fancy museum, but it will give you some insight into the terror and horror that everyone must have lived through.

Landmine Museum is worth a look if you get a good guide.. We were lucky enough to have Sinarth as a guide who has survived 7 land mines and is known as The Cat as he should have been dead multiple times. His body is obviously a mess. He has had his vision restored in one eye, but he get around incredibly well for a man with only one full leg. He has maintained his sense of humor through it all and we were lucky enough to meet the Australian guy (Karl Levy) at the museum that has written his biography. The Information Billboards and the grounds need some love, but all up it was well worth the visit and the small entrance fee. With a different guide we may have rated the museum as low as a two star.

Emotional experience. We arrived at the museum just in time for a guided tour by ex-Khmer soldier 'The Cat'. He explained to us that he got his name because he had been blown up by land mines 4 times, shot 3 times, received 75% burns once, and been stung over 100 times by bees once (hence 9 lives!). the Cat then went on to show us his very numerous scars as proof, along with a missing lower leg, bone from his foot floating in a now blind eye, and various fragments of metal shrapnel under his skin. The Cat had gone fishing for breakfast as a 9 year old boy and returned to find his parents and whole village gone, taken by the Khmer Rouge. He would never see them again. This man's startling recollections of the horrors of war made this a very emotional visit, and one I would recommend to anybody.

Sobering. While not in our itinerary, this museum provided a great insight into the experiences of the Khmer war survivors, some of who, are guides at the museum. There's a collection of tanks and guns and landlines, graphic photos and stories to hear. It's not a big museum and it's all outdoors, but worth a visit.

Do not miss an opportunity to visit this museum!. Shamefully unaware of the recent history of Cambodia and the depth of suffering the country and its people endured during the Khmer Rouge movement, I was very keen to visit the War Museum to learn more and deepen my understanding of this time. The museum is centred around a collection of tanks, artillery and a rather impressive helicopter, set outdoors it's really quite atmospheric. However, the museum is brought to life by the guide. Free of charge and English speaking, each guide offers an informative yet accessible account of the war and has personal experiences to share. This really engages the mind and brings home the reality of what the museum illustrates. Whilst a sombre topic, my visit to the museum left me full of admiration for the people, who after so much hardship and suffering are striving to create a better future.It is only a short Tuk Tuk journey away from town and just $5 for a ticket. Please make this a must see on your visit to Siem Reap!

Interesting and Honest. We went to the War Museum after our visit to the Ankor temples and I must say it was a great place to visit. We were met by an author who had written a book about one of the guides working at the museum; named Cat ( named as a cat has 9 lives and so did this guy!). Our guide around the museum was a young man whose father had died in the Cambodian Civil War; he was informative, friendly and spoke excellent English. The tour around the outside museum ( situated in a mango grove ) was just long enough and free of charge. We obviously left a tip as the money the museum makes goes to help survivors of the war and those injured by land mines. I would recommend a visit, plus it only cost $5 to enter. All in all a great part of our stay in Siem Riep!!
Eye opening experience. Definitely worth a visit. Some harrowing stories. Just to hear what the people have experienced through the war was eye opening. Puts things in perspective.
Taken aback. Was never sure what the war was over, but after visiting the Museum I will be looking into the history

Worthwhile Museum. This is definitely worth the visit if one wants to learn important facts about Cambodia's recent history. There are many weapons and other military equipment on display. What made this visit special is the tour guide; he was a boy soldier for Khmer Rouge that was "recruited" when he was 12-years old. He had fascinating stories to tell as well as the injuries to back them up. It is convenient getting to the museum; it's about a 20-minute tuk-tuk ride from central Siem Reap.

Average at best. Located on a cleared land mine site, this museum is entirely outdoors. It consisted of the very rusted remains of very battle damaged war relics. Many small arms, shells, ammunition, land mines, grenades, mortars etc.. Some russian APC's, a couple of russian tanks and canon. All rusted and all very damaged.

Need to understand the place to appreciate. Most people see just rusting tanks, guns and stuff. But as I understand it, this was once a actual mine field and now it is a museum about that issue and the weapons used in the are for war.
Unforgettable Experience. It was one of the unforgettable experience which all travelers should explore here. It tells about how Cambodian people made war at that time.

Worth for visiting. A place that you must pay a visit if you want to know more about Cambodia history. The tour guid told us many sad story from the past. I suggest visitor to bring some extra cash to donate to them because they really need help.

Worth a trip. Everyone who`d like to learn a little about the sad history of Cambodia should spend the 5 US Dollar and go there. You`ll get a free guide, who tells a lot about the facts in English. You`ll not leave this place with a good feeling because it`s tough matter but it`s part of history. Tuk tuk from the Pub street to the museum costs about 3 US Dollar.

Worth Visiting!. The War Museum is near to the Siem Reap airport - highly recommend all to visit when you are on your way to the airport. Entrance fee is only 5USD, and there's an English-speaking guide who will share with you the history of the war. The museum is not big, 2 hours should be more than enough. The guide shared many of his personal experiences and I'm glad I visited the museum.

Informative and educational. The museum is near the airport, so expect to pay up to $20 USD return trip in tuk-tuk from town. The guides are free and have had direct experience with the civil war either being former soldiers or relatives, interesting stories on some of the individual vehicles stored there and how they came to be there, highly recommend if you are a military buff. It's all outdoors so probably go in the morning before it gets too hot. Expect it to take a couple of hours.

Interesting. great place to spend a couple of hours, we were escorted through the museum by a guide who was a teenage boy during the Pol Pot era, he talked about growing up under the Khmer Rouge and what impact it had on Cambodia.

Informative!. Great insight to the history of Cambodia. Friendly, professional free tour guides! Recommended for families to go as it is somewhat educational. Though it might be a better idea to go early or late afternoon as it is an outdoor musuem could get quite hot towards noon time.

A thought provoking visit. I have just returned from a visit to the War Museum and I found it without a doubt a worthwhile visit. Make sure you get one of the free guides to show you around, they have all been personally effected by the war and the Khmer Rouge regime and therefore have their own stories to tell. Our guide was the young Meng who's family were refugees from the war and his father was killed fighting against the Khmer Rouge. The guides are free but make a living from donations - I would say they are worth every dollar you give them especially as the entrance fee was only $5.It's important to also remember this is not a museum in the traditional sense. It is out doors (there's lots of shade but bring water) and it is a ex landmine field that has now been cleared. The armoury and guns etc were used in a war so no they are not bright, shiny and new. You go to the War Museum to learn so listen to the guide read the information and take your time going around.It was one of the most thought provoking museums I have ever visited.

A must visit in Siem Reap. The war museum is a large area of land (formerly full of land mines) with many ex military vehicles on display, with various buildings holding weaponry and ammunition. There are many trees so despite visiting in 38 degree heat walking around the ground in shade was very pleasant, and the hardware on display fascinating, if a little frightening.There's a free optional guide included in the $5 admission price which was well worth taking up as we were taken around the grounds and given a history of the conflicts in Cambodia, with some personal anecdotes thrown in. Our guide was polite, friendly and very informative, and afterwards we were free to explore the museum on our own for as long as we liked.There are some harrowing tales and imagery in the huts that display the weapons, but nothing too graphic. These are easily avoidable if not your kind of thing, and honestly this is as gentle a primer for the horrors of the Khmer rouge that you could expect. I think that if you're coming to Siem Reap you need to come here, to see the terrible recent past this country is emerging from, and better appreciate the country as it is now. The past isn't sugar coated but nor is it morbidly dug up, this was a very respectful and peaceful afternoon.

Very Interesting!. Not your typical museum - all outdoors, nice and shade, very quiet, and packed with information and artifacts! Highly recommended for anyone who wants to learn a bit about the very recent history that unfolded in the area. It seems crucial to preserve these artifacts and this history and it is unfortunate that the museum struggles to find the resources it needs. Having a free guide with the $5 entrance fee was great, and entirely worth it. We had Meng, and while he didn't have the same experiences some of the guides mentioned in other reviews had, he was still awesome. He told great stories, and was able to answer everyone questions in great detail. This was a fairly quick, educational way to spend an afternoon, and a welcomed break from walking around the temples.
Worthwhile visit. Good guides (involved and maimed) - with good english and good stories to tell - worth the visit and tips that they earn

very interesting although not for everyone. you see the terrible things that happened to the cambodian people during the Pol Pot regime, some of them are horrible and you get out of the museum with an impression that man can be terrible towards is fellowmen when he is totally unrestricted.

War Museum Cambodia . I highly recommend a visit to the War Museum located 15km from Siem Reap central. Entrance fee is US$5 and tour guides are former Khmer soldiers with Amputations. A great site to visit and learn more about the Khmer Rouge and Vietnam war. An abundance of military hardware.

Well worth a visit . Took a tuk tuk to the war museum , it's not a big place but well worth a visit , if you know nothing about the goings on in Cambodia a few years back , well worth a visit . a very sad time indeed for the local population , to which the rest of the world turned a blind eye too ...The cost was $5 each to enter , which includes a free guide if you wish , try and get the guy they call (CAT ) if you do , he's somebody who was directly involved in the conflict and has many sad stories ...most of it is open air display of tanks , weapons etc that were used to try and wipe out a whole generation of the locals , each display has a story about how long was used for and when was finally destroyed in battle etc .... There are many photo boards with pics land mine victims etc , and the sad story's that go with them , local farmers clearing fields to plant crops etc , trying to feed their family's , only to Step on a mine , and turn their whole world upside down , land mine clearing is still going on in parts of Cambodia .Makes me as an Australian release just how lucky I have been to grow up where I have

First hand accounts of war. Although not keen on war museums, from the TripAdvisor reviews we decided to go along to the War Museum Cambodia. It was a moving experience - the tanks and guns are the physical remains of a terrible time for this beautiful country. It was recent enough that those who participated are there as gudes - the objects bring it home to the visitor how such crude pieces of weaponry can reek havoc. Reminiscent of visiting the remains left behind in France, fifteen years after the end of the second world war. Noone would question that the Impertial War Museum and the Normandy landings museum are important and it is good to support those who are there to record firsthand what happened in Cambodia.

interesting place for having an idea about Cambodia's civil war. In a field full of old and destroyed tanks, fireguns, a helicopter and a chinese plane you can have an idea of Cambodia's terrible civilwar which took place grom 195 up to 1980 with too many atrocities.The most interestin part is what concerns the numerous mines that are spread all over the borders and continue to ambutate a lot of people.We had the oppurtinity to meet the australian author of an exciting book and have his book with a personal note
Interesting . It's interesting as long as you're interested in history and weapons and stuff. Very good guides and nice outdoor setting

Well worth a visit. Liking war museums,I found this museum extremely interesting.some of the guides were war vets even from opposing sides. The display of tanks,artillery and weapons are all from the battlefields around Siem reap. They had at least. 30 different types of machines guns on display of which all could be touched. The guides are free and the cost to visit is only 5 dollars..Well worth it.
Very cool . A must. Very interesting lots of displays tanks, helicopter, guns, rifles, trucks, granades, etcJust watch your step wandering around.

Quite average. Outdoors setting not really a museum more like a collection of old used artiellery and weapons. The guide was informative but asked for a donation for some reason. gave him some riel he seemed happy with it but seems strange that he needed it.The guide was nicknamed cat the man with 9 lives Wouldnt go again or recommend about 30 minutes expected more

A very nice place for history buffs. I had just watched "Killing Fields" and discussed the war with my guide before going here. The horror that these people experienced is almost unimaginable. Our guide lost 43 of 46 family members during the war. This museum really helps you feel the conflict.

Tells the human aspect of the Cambodian War. I enjoyed a visit of this musuem. Our brief 30 minute tour was lead by a young man who had lost much of his family to the war. He had some really interesting stories about how people lived (and died) during the war, and about the impact of landmines. You literally walk through a field of various tanks, trucks, and artillery. There isn't much high-tech displays here, everything is just printed on some posters. Also the museum is more focused on the human aspect, rather than the political origins of the war. But for $10, this is worth a quick visit when going to for from the airport

Thought-Provoking.... A good and not too long tour (important after a day in the sun!). My guide was young but had personal exprience of "the troubles" via his family. Well worth it, and especially poignant given that it is set in a cleared minefield.

Great for boys. Our young boys couldn't believe their luck when they were allowed to touch the items on display here.It is well set out and informative. Very cheap to enter and worth a look. Our boys went twice!
Cat. Interesting day filled with examples of war items. Cat is very lucky to be alive. Very hot outside, the entire tour is outdoors.

Very interesting museum. It takes you about 20min by tuk tuk to get there and it's definitely a very interesting place to go. Take a guided tour with one of the guides who will tell you from their experience how it was. Tours are free but it's a nice thing to make an offer- directly to them. It's interesting to notice how they have different opinion about Pol Pot...

Sobering view of the past. My visit lasted 1 1/2 hours and it gave a good insight to the horrors of war in Cambodia . My guide (who accepted a donation ) spent 30 minutes showing us around the displays with a good command of English , we then were able to wonder at our leisure , the guide had a personal tragedy from Pol Pots time in power. The remains of tanks and artillery are on display along with an variety of gun's which you are able to handle if that's your thing , cabinet displays of photographs and the history are in English to give you more information. Worth spending some time it is out of town but your hotel reception should be able to organise a Tuk Tuk for approx. US$3 each way mind waited whilst I looked around.

A gentle introduction to S21 and the killing fields if you go in this order. I used this attraction as a break from the temples. As I was going from Siam Reap to Phnom Penh, coming to the museum gave me a brief insight into the further "exhibitions" I would find in Phnom Penh. It mainly has old weaponry on display like rifles, RPGs and rocket launchers which you are allowed to pick up and hold.There are several mechanical infantry units displayed in the fields in addition to a fighter plane and helicopter. There is also a section dedicated to land knew and the curse they have brought Cambodia which is prevalent even now.

Small & concise. I had suggested to our guide that we would like to visit the landmine museum. He suggested that that his was his preferred option as offers more general information about the time of the Khmer Rouge and ongoing issues. We accepted his advice (it is also much closer to Siem Reap centre) and visited as part of a full day tour.There is no entrance fee, though the guide is very grateful for any tips you wish to give. Our guide 'the cat' all will be revealed if you visit, was quite a character and added an extra element to what was a very sobering tour. Heartbreaking to hear that at least 2 people per month are still killed/injured as mines are discovered in simple farmland etc It is a small museum, set outdoors, so rather nicer than the air conditioned building I had imagined as a war museum. Guns, tanks, missiles and of course landmines are displayed, though much more than this, many photo boards showing the atrocities of the Democratic Kampuchea 1975-1979. There is a small shop, mainly selling books. As part of Cambodias history I suggest this should be visited in addition to the temples of the area.

Option B for Visiting More Temples!. On my second day in Siem Reap and after visiting several ruined temples, I needed change of sceneries - visiting musems. Entrance fee is $5 per person. I was the only guest during my visit and there was no guide to help me. Weapons used during the war were on display such as canons, artilleries, helicopter, tanks, bullets, soldiers' uniforms, etc. Huts were set up along the major, big weapons. Inside the huts are bullets, mines, uniforms, pictures of soldiers,etc. Allow at least 15-30 minutes to view the above items, most of which are very rusty!

Well worth a visit and a must to support the victims of Cambodia's wars. We got a tuk tuk for US$6 from our hotel in the centre of town and it was about 15 - 20 minutes drive which enabled sight seeing of street market life en-route. The tik tuk driver waited while we looked around and had the guided tour.Our young guide was very knowledgable and incorporated stories from his grandmother, experiences of growing up in post Khmer Rouge Cambodia and recalled how his friends had been blown up by landmines and UXO when they were growing up.The museum is open air and I imagine it would be difficult to visit during the rainy season. The tour takes 40 minute and you are then given time to look round. There is a small bookshop and drinks can be purchased but it is wise to ensure you take your own water as well to ensure that you remain hydrated during the tour.The guide took us around each area in turn and explained the history very well. At US$5 per person it was well worth it and a very moving experience.

A few good pieces in an orchard.. Most of the equipment is Russian, left by the Vietnamese. A few tanks and a MIG, but lots of filler (stripped to the bone APC's and how many howitzers do you really want to see?). The small arms are nice which you can handle. $5 seemed a little over priced. Short bike ride from town. Nice orchard setting. Ok for a couple hours but nothing I have not seen elsewhere. Recommended for history buffs but your gf/wife will be bored so leave her at a cafe. Ride a bicycle here, no need for a tuk-tuk.

Educational. This is an interesting insight into the Pol Pot regime. Our guide told the story of the regime and how it effected the life's of the Camdodian people. You got to see mines, guns and other weapons used. The tanks, planes and atillery are all housed on the landmine and killing fields. Very hands on. An interesting place to visit

Sinarth takes you through the horrible recent history of this war ravaged country. Our guide, Sinarth, was a child soldier in the Cambodian army and has the war wounds to prove it. His tales set the somber mode of the museum but his spirit to overcome leaves you feeling the better for having visited. A great book by Karl Levy detailing Sinarth's life is available at the museum and adds a deeper perspective of what this beautiful country and this special man have been through.

Very interesting visit!. This war museum was a very interesting visit, the free tour guide Sinath aka The Cat was very detailed as he was involved in the war. Sinath gave a humorous tour and explained every thing in detail and showed his war wounds. He knew every weapon in the museum and explained it all. After the tour we could hold all the guns and RPGs for photos. I also purchased the book of Sinaths life and also met the author who wrote it, I am excited to read the book.

Where an old papaya orchard hosts the wreckage of war.. IN these modern days of terrorism you need strong nerves to enter a building and suddenly be faced with a smiling man pointing a Kalashnikov at you!But the chances are that if you haven’t had a heart attack on the spot that he’ll offer you the AK-47 so you can have a chance to pose with it or any one of several dozen other small arms.There is no standing on ceremony here. Everything is very relaxed, very open, very detailed and very graphic including being taken round the museum by a guide who had one leg blown off by a mine.Moun Sinath – otherwise known as “The Cat” – knows all about every tank, every armoured personnel carrier, every artillery piece and every mine, shell and photograph which is on display and so he should. He was one of those who fought against the Khymer Rouge in Cambodia’s bloody civil war.His intelligent and knowledgeable tour is delivered with some humour and a factual edge which is not for the faint hearted. You need to steel yourself on being given details about how a mine wrecked an armoured personnel carrier....only to be invited forward to look inside where some of the remains of the unfortunate occupants are still in situ!Entry cost just $5 including The Cat’s free tour and visitors were able to see everything from mortars to a Mig -19 fighter.I found two things absolutely fascinating. The first was an amazing collection of photographs including many rare shots of Khymer Rouge fighters and the second was the sheer incongruity of wandering up and down between rows of papaya trees surrounding by wrecked Russian T54 tanks, rocket launchers and other rusting armament.You had to pinch yourself just to make sure it was all real and as I walked out I made sure I gave a donation to the museum. It had been a graphic experience and well worth a few dollars.

An absolute eye opener. We visited the museum on a TA recommendation and were surprised by the openness of the young guide. He had a mixture of 2nd hand information and family experience which demonstrated the unknown (for an Aus) about the conflict which continued in the local area till 1999. A quick tour definitely worth seeing for $5.

A heart-wrenching time warp.... An outdoor exhibit of well-used and broken tanks, a big chopper, a Mig 19 fighter jet, artillery, missile launchers and small arms from the war years -- equipment from both the Soviet era and the U.S.
Guides are all victims of war, suffering from wounds including land mine amputations.

A humbling experience. I visited the museum 12th February 2016. The tuk tuk was $5 & will wait as long as you want them to,the journey takes about 20 minutes from central Siem Reap. I spent about 2 hours there & it was well worth the $5 entry fee. The free guide Mr Sidath gives a brilliant commentary to the tour with great humour despite the horrific wounds he received during the war. His biography has just been published & both he and Australian author Karl Levy are currently signing copies for people if they buy the book after the tour.I did & so far it's a very good read. Mr Sidarth asked for a donation at the end of the tour and everybody gave him something & I was happy to do this & you'll see why if you take his tour.
Outdoor complex. This is a display of weapons and artillery from the Khemer war. It is an eye opener. It offers free guides and the priced is reasonable. $5.
Worth visiting. Interesting visit! The tour guide (ex-soldier) gave us an insight to the tragic history. It is worth visiting if in siem reap

Cambodia war torn past. This museum is brilliant. All the guide are former injured soldiers of the conflict that are incredibly informative , speak good English and give personal accounts of what happen. The guides explain each weapon and vehicle which such detail and allow you to hold them. Inform you about the horrors of booby trap with explosive or improvised what we westerns would think as garden equipment. Also some of the vehicles which include old soviet tanks still have the bones of the dead soldiers inside them.

Eye Opening. I really recommend a visit here. A free guide(ex-soldier) walked around with me amazingly explaining the war & all the exhibits on show. The guided tour took 30-40 minutes & I walked around for another half hour. Definitely worth visiting

Small location but interesting diversion from the temples in Siem Reap. This is a small location which I believe is run by the army. On display are a lot of remnants of weapons used by the Khmer Rouge during their occupation, along with many WW2 (mostly Russian) weapons of war (tanks; trucks and anti-aircraft guns). There's also a very confronting replica of landmines inside the compound. For a short time, I thought they were genuine and active. My saddest memory of being here was being followed into the compound by a busload of Vietnamese tourists. One ran up to the weapons rack, took down an AK47 and mimicked shooting people - a throwback to the North/South conflict of the 60's /70's ? Whether a throwback to his "glory days" when he was in the army (North or South) or just someone pretending to be a soldier, I found that moment to be unsettling.Inside, there are also photos of soldiers of the Cambodian army, some of whom you may see on the streets in Siem Reap; without arms, victims of landmines in the district.

WAR, UH, WHAT'S IT GOOD FOR...ABSOLUTELY NOTHING. History needs to be seen and understood. It's graphic reminder that war is cruel, ruthless and a government fed machine of waste. Lessons learned and hope never repeated.

Thought Provoking. We were guided around by an ex-child soldier and it really puts the whole of Cambodia's recent conflicts into a real life context. Whilst the exhibits are limited the stories are both harrowing and uplifting. Not for the faint hearted.

Make the time and get a guide. This will take a couple of hours out of your day so if you are pressed for time it might be awkward to go but if you can please do. It is quite small but none of this matters when you have a guide show you around telling you about his experiences. Our guide was called "The Cat" ( 9 lives and then some) told us all about the land mines and tanks and showed us all his scars from AK47's, shrapnel and bee's (Bee's??? you will have to ask him) culminating with the missing right leg. Such an interesting man with a story to tell that has been written in a book which to my shame I did not buy as I was too overwhelmed to think by the end of our visit.Nothing is sugar coated it was a war and he tells it as it was

Wonderful visit. Went to visit the war museum after reading about it in trip advisor and in lonely planet. I was pleasantly surprised by the experience I had, a wonderful time. A small museum, with many great pictures, ammunition, tanks, mines. The free guides are great for information and able to ask any question. We joined a second free guide for a different perspective and was better than the first. Sinarth was a child solder in the war now working at the museum. Karl Levy wrote a book on Sinarth's story and was there to discuss the book and sign it. Karl and Sinarth made the experience above and beyond. Definitely would recommend going. Enlightening into the true experiences of the war.
Small but infirmative. Worth a visit.....guide infirmative and funny. Mostly tanks, rifles etc. easy access guide has very good English
Worth a visit. Interesting place, all about the machinery and ammunition used during the war. Very informative. A great guide who was in the war.

Make sure you have the museum guide show you around. This museum would have been rated average were it not for the real life stories and experiences of our museum guide. They made the visit fascinating and gave us an insight into some of the tragic recent history of the Khmer Rouge's influence in this lovely country

Sad history. This is a cool little museum. It's 5 dollars entry and it includes a free tour guide. Ours was great. He was so knowledgeable telling us about the countries recent history and giving us his own life stories and experiences to do with it too. His passion made it interesting.

Visit this Museum. I'm disappointed to see that some of these reviews read like the appraisal of a hotel or standard tourist attraction so here are my thoughts, having visited this week- for whatever they're worth.It seems to have been neglected by many that you're walking round an actual former minefield (where people undoubtedly died) with a war veteran who has been through more than you could possibly imagine. You are shown tanks (rusty, as one reviewer puts it) in which people died and within which their bones still remain. The exhibits aren't there for entertainment; they attempt to contextualise a relatively recent period of Cambodian history very hard for most visitors in 2016 to comprehend.This place should be treated with the intrigue of a museum and also the respect of a war cemetery. It was a privilege to have been able to visit.
Interesting collection of machinery. Lots of tanks, guns and even a helicopter. Out in the open with an authentic feel too it. Guide is free though a tip is expected.
Not much to see. There is not much to see there the weapon is old and some are missing most part. If you still want to learn about the history you should go there.

The weapons are old, but the story is still vital!. This is a small museum, with old weaponry and somewhat amateur displays. But the story behind them is important and impactful and well worth the visit. Learning about Cambodia's past, and the time of Khmer Rouge and Pol Pot, is as important as learning about the Holocaust and Hitler. Smaller scale of atrocity (in terms of body count), but it wiped out a whole generation of educated and professional Cambodians. The museum is a bit out of town but well worth the tuktuk trip.

Not Great - But definitely worth a visit. I found the museum artifacts and the stories of our guide to be quite interesting. It certainly provides perspective on the recent history of Cambodia. The guides tell personal accounts of the war which is compelling, but I would also liked to have learned more about some of the history of the wars. But, all-in-all, it is certainly worth the $5 entrance fee.

great little place Of the beaten track. This place doesn't advertise as much as the landmine museum and because of that i wanted to go and check it out. About 10 mins out of down town and past the army base, Nice quite area. I was told after entry that i could roam around on my own or join a tour group. So i dipped in and out of the group into old blown up tanks and handling some old war weapons. The tour guide was fantastic in explaining Cambodia's devastating past. He was passionate and very respectful. after the tour he explained to us Cambodias current political climate and problems. If you get bored of the temples its a nice way to knock out a couple of hours and just chill.

Necessary insight into Cambodia's horrific past. For only $5, you can get an insight into the past of Cambodia particularly during the reign of Khmer Rouge and Pol Pot. It was quite distressing to hear the story of the tour guide and his experiences. The museum itself is just a field off a small building with various artillery, weapons, mines and war vehicles (including war helicopters and USSR tanks) and you can explore it at all at your own pace after the brief tour guide (or skipping the included tour guide although I personally recommend going initially with one).

Worth a visit. I didn't know much about Cambodia when I arrived. I went with a friend who had been before and wanted to show me the country. I would recommend this to any first time visitor, although quite sad, it gives you a basic understanding of their past and how the people feel about it today. Good value and the price of your ticket goes to those injured during the war.

Everyone visiting here should see. For a museum that does not over advertise itself it is a must stop for anyone visiting Siem Reap. Staffed by volunteers who are all survivors of the Khymer Rouge war. Tour guides are free. Their story is as much of the museum as the artifacts there. Reminds one of how cruel man can be to man and makes you know that this cannot happen again. Also a story not only of information but one of forgiveness.
History. It is tour to the history of the war between Cambodia khamer and the French colonists very interesting.
Guided tour from 'The Cat' (local veteran) unmissable. An unexpected holiday highlight enjoyed by ages 5 to 43 alike. Find out about The Killing Fields first hand. Sobering and remarkable.

Not the best. I'll be honest. I did not like this museum. The info and photos need replacing because they are sun damaged. The guns were the best bit. My husband who is x military quite liked this museum. He said that some of the tanks there he'd learnt about but never actually seen one before. It's just a rusty tank to me. Worth going if you're interested in that sort of thing. It's also worth going so that the museum can continue to function and the more people that go then the better it can become.

Worth a stop if you have time but if you don't...don't worry about it.. Most of the items here are outside and rusting away. The tanks, trucks, and heavy guns are rusting away to nothing but still interesting to see. The display of landmines, guns, rocket launchers on display is interesting and you can pick them up and hold them (don't worry...they aren't in working order.) With a little more upkeep and maybe even a building this would get a higher rating but as it...worth it if you have some extra time.

Have to visit . Its worth going to visit the less popular war museum & its only a 10 minute tuk ride out of town. You get a free guide or you can walk around on your own, it is worth getting the guide

Don't miss this museum. This was recommended to us in order to get a better grasp of what Cambodia went through during the Khmer Rouge regime and it was very informative as well as heart breaking. We were shown around by Thom and his story is one we all need to hear

Well worth a visit. The negative reviewers are perhaps forgetting the context in which the museum was constructed. War only left Cambodia 15 or so years ago and the museum is relatively new. If you take the museum for what it's worth, it is a cheap ($5USD) and valuable insight into the weapons, context and story of Cambodian conflict. The guides were helpful and management seem to be doing the best they can with what they've got. Well worth a visit. (Consider stopping in on the way to or from the nearby silk farm).

Insightful Museum. It is not like the typical museum as I imagine. It is an open field, filled with various machine/gun/trunk etc. I take my own time to explore the museum by myself without the guide. It worth the visit.

Important experience . The war museum itself isn't incredible but before I went I really didn't know much at all about the war or Cambodian history in general. I think going is very important if you want to get an insight into the Cambodian mentality that has been shaped by many years of death and war. Definitely worth a visit and for just 5 dollars doesn't set you back much.

Deserves a place in every itinerary. No visit to Cambodia is complete with a short visit to the War Museum. The guides (included in the $5 entrance fee) bring the recent troubled decades to life with their personal stories. It isn't grand but it helped us to understand the massive impact of civil war and appreciate how far Cambodia has come in the last 17 years.
War Museum Cambodia - Siem Reap. War Museum Cambodia - Siem Reap:Was an experience to view the museum, heaps of Russian and Chinese tanks - Entry $5.00 USD

Staggering experience but a must visit place. Our guide (The Cat) was a veteran, fought in the khmer rouge period. He has a very good sense of humor (despite the tragic story) and a really good enlgish knowledge. If you want to understand a bit more what Cambodian people went trough in the 70's and 80's visit this place.

Can't miss!!. Visited the War Museum as recommended by so many people on TA.I reconfirm everything everyone is saying. Yes this place was confronting but it is also an insight into the Cambodian culture. We had the tour guide known as "Tom" . He was amazing. He shared his story with us and it was very sad to hear, but he shows no anger and disappointment instead told us about how he now has a wife and 4 kids. He looked so happy and proud telling us this. Everyone should visit the war museum entrance is only $5 each and all the money goes to maintaining the museum as well as supporting the veterans (tour guides)

Wonderful guides. It is not so much the displays that make this museum but he guides. All have experiences of the Khmer war, some from opposing sides. Some have been victims of land mines. All will tell you their stories which are very sad but fascinating. All have wonderful English. Please tip these men accordingly. They do this as a volunteer service but rely on tips to survive and feed their families.

quite a confronting tour. glad we went but it stirred the emotions for all our group - terrific local guide who talked at length about the history and impact on the Cambodian people - highly recommended
Amazing . The museum gave an amazing insight into Cambodia's recent history. Entry was $5 and free tour guides were available - the guide is what made the experience 5 star

What a amazing place. Yes cheap
Yes no frills
Yes got very emotional
Yes def worth it
Yes great for kids
Yes brought the book$10
Reading it now,
Don't miss out on this place

A must, surely will make you stay longer!. Since we are budget travelers, we opted to visit this museum instead of the National Museum. We were not disappointed, we were rather educated back to the past, the present and the future of Cambodia. Plus given an entertaining guides in the museum. Take the chance to put it in your list!

Visited the war museum. The entry ticket is cheap.
A nice place to see the history and photo shooting.
The place was few visitor so that you can enjoy it.

Interesting equipment. Cost $5 pp to enter. You can pay extra for a guide or wander yourself. It is worth getting a guide for genuine commentary and there is limited signage. There are plenty of old vehicles, tanks, cannon to look at, also plenty of ordinance and old guns to have a gander at, they also have a huge helicopter and old plane. Great for 30minutes give or take.

Was okay. Travelers : My family of 6. My husband and I with 4 kids. 17, 14, 12 and 9. We visited on Dec 21st. Third day of a three day trip. Our driver recommended it since we had already been to the 3 main sites. And the water town.The museum entrance is free of cost, they ask you to leave a donation for the tour guide.The tour was an ok pass of time. The kids had some fun with the guns and the tanks.All in all if you're all templed out and you just want to entertain the kids, it's okay. I personally didn't feel much entertained or educated.

No frills war museum. The Ear a Museum is about 7km from Siem Reap and easily accessible by tuk tuk or taxi. Very basic layout with old tanks, guns and various armoured vehicles in the open and some small arms under cover. Also posters showing various stages of Cambodias past conflicts. Very interesting for military enthusiasts, but not much by way of explanation. The entry fee is only US$5 and there are free guides, although we opted to just walk around by ourselves. I learnt a lot about the various Cambodian conflicts and history prior to Pol Pot and that made me do more research after going home. In this regard I think the museum was worth the visit as it opened up my knowledge of those complicated and troubled times.

EDUCATIONAL &EMOTIONAL. The war museum gives you a good idea what happened pre and Pot Pol regime. The guide did a good job in explaining the history of Cambodia. Coming here will make you appreciate how precious life is.

Insightful museum. It's a little outside of town, but worth the time if you would like to know more about the history of Cambodia. The $5 for entrance and guide was truly worth it, considering the number of artefacts they have preserved, and that the guides are people who have lived to tell their tale. We also got to touch and feel all the artefacts.The guide told of his personal stories and experiences. It was interesting and insightful to say the least. It would only take an hour tops, so you can easily fit this into your itinerary.

Easy to follow. Easy to follow the path and learn about the mechanical story of the war .Also follows the human story of the devastation of the civil war in Cambodia. If you like war artifacts , you may really enjoy a visit. a little off the beat and track.

Raw insight into life under the Khmer Rouge. After visiting the temples, countryside, National Museum in Siem Reap and speaking to local guides, we still felt we didn't have much understanding of what happened in Cambodia under the Khmer Rouge, so chose to visit this war museum to fill these gaps in our knowledge. The displays themselves of rusty tanks, guns and landmines were not that appealling to me but were helpful props for the talk from the guide who shared his personal story as the son of a veteran. His account of the violent, brutal annihilation of a generation under the dictatorship of Pol Pot was extremely moving.This museum is not for the faint hearted but explains an significant part of the countries history.Although there is shade in the trees and the huts, walking around the open air museum can be hot and humid, so would recommend visiting early in the morning or late afternoon.
Well worth the visit. Admission cost was $5 per person and that included an informative guide. I thought it was an excellent complement to Genocide Museum
Interesting Musuem. Interesting machinery and weapons but highlight is the guide. This veteran puts a personal story to the artifacts and it shows how modern this tragedy is.

Must-see in Siem Reap! Moving experience, definitely worth visiting. A visit to the War Museum Cambodia is eye-opening and a must-see in Siem Reap. The tour guides are all people who experienced life under the Pol Pot regime, including some that were child soldiers and lost their parents to war. They tell their first hand accounts of what life was like in that period, giving visitors a chance to understand contemporary history - that isn't shown in other museums in Cambodia. What really made the visit was the stories from the guides, who all volunteer their time to share their stories. Ours was very open and candid, and told us devastating stories of his friends and family members. It was incredibly moving and heart-breaking. I would recommend that anyone visiting Siem Reap pay the War Museum a visit, it is definitely worth a visit.

Amazing 1st hand account of the war. We had a great 1st hand insight from one of the tour guides into the Khmer Rouge period. As interesting as it is, there is also an element of sadness and pain.Our tour guide Sinath was extremely knowledgeable and spoke a lot about his experiences of the civil war in Cambodia. There is an Australian called Karl Levy who is currently there promoting a book he just released about Sinath's experiences in the war. I would truly recommend anyone visiting Siem Reap to visit this museum.

Very moving experince. We took one of the guides at the war museum he had been a 12 year old victim of Pol Pots regime his family tried to flee over the Tia border but were caught he was the only survivor and lost his arm. Tragic his English was very good and we were happy we took the time to do this experience

Fantastic opportunity to experience contemporary history!. Our guide had vast and first-hand experience of the war and devastation caused during the Pol Pot regime - we each learned new and fascinating details and left being reminded that we have much to be thankful for. The pain and suffering caused during that time remains, for many, an all too vivid memory with people still uncertain what happened to their friends and family yet proud to share their stories with visitors to the museum. Very moving!

Heart breaking, but insightful . This is n amazing tour. It only cost $5 per person and you get a very small tour. This is conducted by a tour guide who was involved in the war. We had the cat who gave us an honest account.I would recommend this for all the family. Children get to touch and engage with the exhibits. Please save some money to tip the guides at the end.

So-So. Been here but don't know what to do. Just follow the tour guide and here all their explanation on Cambodia. Not too many things to do other than snapping pictures and just sightseeing. It's quite far from the town

Great guide . The war museum was about 15-20 minutes out of town (we took a tuk tuk costing about $6 including taking us for lunch first) and was very nicely set up. It had a simple rustic feel to the place which I really liked. Coming from a place where everything would be in glass cabinets and behind ropes it was really nice to be able to get up close to some war remnants. We had an awesome tour guide (the provide free tours). His name was Tom and he spoke really good English and had a really great sense of humour. He knew a lot about the history of Cambodia and made the tour very engaging. He was able to explain all parts of the museum and gave the experience a very personal touch. Although other review may complain that it's not very big or not much to see I think it should be kept in mind this is run by a group of individuals wishing to share their knowledge it's does not have millions of dollars pumped into it by the government like some war museums in the world. We found an 1-2 hours was a good length of time to spend there. I am very glad we took the time to go here, it is very worthwhile choosing to have a tour guide. He just made the whole experience so much more informative. Thank you very much Tom and all the staff at the Siem Reap War Museum.

So glad we went.. Almost didn't go as we were going to go to the one in Phnom Penh. But this is the place to go. The guide who took us around was so informative. Please do yourself the favour and take a guide.

a memoars of crime againts humanity. Infamous and underrated museum as i can tell from how many tourist that came to this museum. Come here and asked for a guide, that way you will knew the dark history of cambodia better. Some of the guide itself is a survivor from the war. Chilling experience, sad, and definitely worth to visit when you come to Siem Reap.

Liked our guide very much. Our guide spoke about his own experiences, his families and more facts. Showed us a lot of pictures and mines and wepons. Took 30 minutes to walk around and it only cost us 5 dollar each. He spook very good english. We bicycled there from Pub street which took us only 15 minutes.

Not worth your time. I have visited here a few times with out of town friends. I had an uncomfortable experience with a security guard there one time which has made me never want to return. The displays are average, if war weapons really interest you, then go, otherwise check out the Landmine Museum, where your money will go towards a good cause.
war museum. not really for us but we did go it is great if you want to know all about the Khmer war and see alot of the tanks and guns

Worth a visit. The War Museum is not far from town and can easily be done on 60 to 90 minutes so if this type of thing holds any interest it's worth a visit. As other reviewers have said, the key to the experience is the guides as they bring it to life and also answer questions. Ours was the son of a veteran and very passionate. He patiently answered all my questions and took time to share his thoughts, knowledge and experiences. We were really glad we went and it served to remind us just how recently Cambodians were facing war and hardship and how resilient they are as they emerge from such turbulent decades

Worth a look. We rode bikes the 4km out to the museum worth the effort staff were really good guides are free entry is $5. The staff are ex army and have lived through the war the museum is there for which means its not just a lot of photos on a wall.
THE STORIES OF TEARS AND WARS.. friendly personal guided - touching our heart with true side Cambodian war stories shed blood and tears.

War Museum of Cambodia at Siem Reap offers a rare, personal look at Cambodia's nightmare. Travellers to Siem Reap and Angkor Wat can learn something more recent than ancient history at this outdoor museum. Privately owned and set in a "rustic" setting on the outskirts of Siem Reap, the War Museum offers visitors a no-charge (but donations are definitely appreciated) personal tour of war and genocide relics, conducted by a Cambodian with personal experience of the US bombing of Cambodia and the subsequent nightmarish 1975-79 Khmer Rouge regime. The tour is intimate, quiet, intelligent and deeply moving. The old guns, plane, helicopter, mortars, landmines and hundreds of photos and weapons give a chilling taste of what constant war was like for this fragile, agrarian country. I strongly recommend a visit - but TIP THE TOURGUIDE, rather than putting everything in the donation box. Also, like everywhere else, wear a hat and take water.

Sobering, but left me hopeful for Cambodia's future. This was an extremely interesting chapter of our recent visit to Siem Reap. The exhibits themselves are fairly straightforward. What brings the whole experience to life is the guided tour by an English speaking guide who lived through Cambodia's recent terrible history. We probably spent only 90 minutes at the museum. However, all four of us (including two teenage children) came away very moved by the experience. Highly recommended.

Recent war history of Cambodia. Very interesting visit about the advent of the Khmer rouge 40 years ago, the genocide by the Khmer and the later civil war in Cambodia between Khmer Rouges and the governement until 1999. Our guide shared with us personal memories of this period. It's really shattering and helps understand today's Cambodia.

sobering and enlightening. very well laid out. Really must try and get one of the war veterans as a guide to walk you around and make the history captured in the museum come alive. Please do spend some time here to appreciate the horrors Cambodia went through ever so recently - yet the entire country projects such a happy face to tourists. Much to learn from...

Interesting. The war museum is quite small but for just 5 dollars you get to see a lot of guns and equipment from the war, plus a free guide to tell you all about it. you can see it all in less than an hour but well worth a visit if you have the time.

Nothing special, guides tells what popsnin their mind. Our guide told about history of vietnamese war and secret war very differently than the truth is. And if that didin't leave sour taste he started begging money after telling about te flaws of another guides working there.Again wondering where goes the entrance fee money, because you have to pay to the "free" guide separately

Sobering. This isn't one of those places you go to because it's fun. But it's important. Our guide fought against the Khmer Rouge for a decade and paid the price. He lost a leg to a landmine and has shrapnel still embedded in his body in multiple places. Hearing a personal story from someone who has gone through so much is what makes this place special. In addition to that, it is a very raw experience. Everything there was actually used in the genocide/war, and you can pick up the guns and touch the tanks and anti-aircraft guns. It makes this tragic piece of Cambodian history very real. You need to go here to get a fuller picture of what makes Cambodia what it is today. It won't be "fun," but it's meaningful, important, and informative.

Important history to acknowledge along with the temples. The war Museum was a great addition to our time and Siem Reap. Though I had very little knowledge about the more recent history in Cambodia, I felt that it was an incredibly important place to visit to learn more. It does not take long at all, and it is outdoors which makes it very pleasant experience. Definitely put it on your last if you're visiting the area. It even meant a lot to her guide (a Cambodian) that we were interested in learning more about the history, and he was willing to share his story as we walked through the museum. As you can see in the other reviews, there are free guides there who were involved in someway you are also able to share their stories.
Highly recommended!. If tired of visiting temples you can visit this place and learn about war in Cambodia. They offer free guide that will explain the history.

Must-visit place. My friend and I asked our tour guide Rany to change our itinerary to visit this place. The museum provides a sobering reminder of what the Cambodian people had to endure from the Indochina wars through the civil war, and the lingering effects of these. To visit the ancient temples of Siem Reap is all well and good, but visiting the museum gives us a glimpse into the tragic experiences of people who live today.

Very interesting and cheap. Interesting tour with friendly tour guides. Guides are very knowledgeable and happy to share personal history and information. Excellent artifacts on display, cheap entrance fee. Expected to donate/tip tour guide but no amount stated.
Great. Good tour by guides who are personally influenced by the warfare. Lots of tanks, AA-guns, mines and stories. Me and my backpacking partner had a great time!

Not to be missed. The guides make this place what it is.You are being guided by people who have been directly impacted by the war and the land mine issues.They will tell you their piece of history as they show you around the different exhibits.Make sure you tip the guide at the end (you pay no extra for the guide)

it is a sad place but still fun to tour. the small is small, for me the ticket price is quite high for this small place. you can have a knowledge about the combodia story and if you not into history you will have fun play and taking picture with the gun there. a real gun without bullet if you have that army spirit in you.

If you like weapons and stories of war, this is a must!. For 5 USD you get a free guide (war vet) to guide you around the museum. You can touch and climb on almost anything, AND they sell beer. Fantastic!

A very worthwhile, humbling experience. We only visited Siem Reap while in Cambodia, so felt we should visit this museum to understand the history of the war better. While the museum may be basic by western standards, it is not well funded (if at all) by the state, and compared to the temples hardly visited at all. This is an hour or so very well spent to reflect on the horrific and recent history of this beautiful country. Very worthy of your tourist dollar.

A great way to learn a bit of history of Cambodia and to meet some very interesting local people!. The War Museum in Siem Reap is a very interesting museum. Beyond the items that you get to see, the best part is meeting the guides who have real life "war stories" to tell you (and show you in some cases!) I strongly urge you to spend 30-45 minutes at this site which is very close to the airport and to all most hotels and learn a bit of the history of the area which is critical to understanding some of its current issues that it and its people face.

Just to know a bit more about historie. Verry nice, small but interesting, the tanks and all are really old and just as they find them, looking like used ;) , replaced.Its just e few years ago, but also should never be forgitten, a lesson for all.

Impressive. Not a well known place to visit as Ankor is the main attraction but if you have a spare 2 hours its well worth the visit. Make sure you get a guide who have experienced the war themselves. Speak good english and very informative. Their service is free but they ask for a tip/donation afterwards. Which they deserve.

A sad, but important history. Went for about two hours and it was well worth the $5 entry free. Get the guide! They are free (yes a small tip at the end of your tour is expected) and they make the visit unforgettable! Plus, if you have the cash to visit Cambodia then I highly doubt $5 is putting a huge dent in your wallet. The hands on display is awesome and the area is clean and nice and people aren't hassling you to buy things or for Tuktuk rides out front. Yes, some of the attractions are a bit faded and worn out, but hopefully this will improve with more donations over time. While most people visiting this part of Cambodia are here to see Angkor Wat (which is amazing) I believe that taking a few hours out of your trip is a great way to learn about Cambodia's lesser known, dark history and it is also important so that we as mankind don't repeat the mistakes of our past.

$5 entry a bit steep but guide well worth the tour. We enjoyed the tour guide Mr. Sathang aka The Cat who told many interesting stories bringing the history to life. But I'd rather half the ticket price and make a guide a mandatory $2 per person fee, rather than a "free" guide who looks for tips at the end of the tour. These war vets deserve a guaranteed income.

Great Stories. I enjoyed the tanks, artillery and other war memorabilia but by far the beat part of this experience was the guide; Moun Sinath... aka "The Cat". He was extremely giving of his time (offered for free to all) and the stories he told were brutally honest and captivating with the scars to prove them. Please give a small donation at the end to keep this place going.

Sad history. With USD5 per person for entry, you entered different kind of world especially when the guides as a witness of the war himself tell the stories and show you all the scars on his body. Plenty sad photos from the civil war also the artillery that they used. In the end of the tour, the guide asked tip for him..

A must see!. This is a real eye-opener it shows you the real reality of war. I have read various reviews after visiting this museum, people saying things are old, dirty, rusty, damaged. This is the best display I have seen that represents the real side of war, the damaged, burnt out vehicles. Just stop and think, where have they come from.......what happened to the crew when it was hit........did they get out.......or did they not. Now look at the vehicle again. Then there is the wall of weapons, you can handle any of the guns, shells, mortars etc and again think to yourself, what happened to the guns owner, what did the owner do with this gun, there is a very high proability with the area you are in that these guns have blood on them. I have not really been one for history of wars etc but after visiting here it's made me think. Personally I would like to see more museums like this where you can touch, feel and hold such items.

Understand what Cambodia has been through the last 50 years.. A short Tuk Tuk ride from the hotel. The guides at the museum are from the civil war in Cambodia. They are free but accept tips. They do a great job explaining what happened from 1970's to 1990's. They have guns, old landmines, tanks and other weapons from that time period. This is a great place to go and learn about Cambodia!

Heart rending and unforgettable. The guide made me cry twice. Such heart rending stories told sympathetically and simply. As other reviews said, talking to the guide is the absolute highlight. That said there is a lot to see around the grounds - I enjoyed wandering around looking at the old bits of equipment from all over and the descriptions. Apparently the place was demined after it was opened which made me nervous to walk on the grass, but so far so good.
