I think everyone should go to the War Museum to help try to understand what Cambodians went through... then you can have more empathy as you go of to your fancy resorts and cheap massages!
Confronting. Hard to visit but it is so recent and a reminder of what humans are capable of when a despot gets in charge and no one stops him

Disappointing - past its "sell-by" date.. The museum was a $5 tuk-tuk drive from my hotel with vehicles situated among trees and visual displays in wooden sheds. A free guide is available. Most of the rusting Russian and Chinese hulks were from the Pol Pot era however there were some Japanese rifles from the Second World War. Guns on display can be handled. Plenty of landmines can be viewed. Some of the photographic displays were distinctly faded. My visit did provide some welcome shade from the heat of Siem Reap city.

Sad poignant reminder of the indifference of the western world.. This is telling the story, through numerous pieces of rusting military hardware, of how the western world betrayed, and abandoned, the Cambodian population.It was left to the communist forces of Vietnam to liberate Cambodia, and put an end to the obscene dicatorship of the mass murderer Pol Po, together with his regime in 1978.A sad visit, made all the more so, by the number of limbless guides injured in the fighting- all with trajic stories to tell.There are many relics of the "liberation war" - all the more poignant for being both an extensive minefield and a battlefield just a few miles away in the tranquil temples of Angkor. It does not take many weapons, shells, mines and artillery pieces or displays of injured civilians to show the price paid to rid this peaceful Buddist country of one of the C20th tyrants. On reflection I am glad I went, although at the time I found it unnerving, and had left in a very sombre mood.

Vital when in Cambodia . A truly sobering day out. We didn't understand why it is bad etiquette to mention the past before visiting here. They have war weapons that were used on all sides of the conflict and tour guides directly affected tell you theirs and others stories. If you visit seim reap, this is a definite must see.

A must. The war museum is a must stop. You need only 1 1/2 hrs. It is a $6.00 round trip ride from our hotel. A free guide is provided and the guides are all people who have lived through the experience. Essential to being in Cambodia and understanding the country and its history.

Insight in cambodian recent history... The war museum itself is an exhibition of weapons,vehicles and so on. What we highly recommend though is to hear facts and personal stories from a guide who will make you think about the suffering the cambodian people went through and we really ask ourself why people dont learn from horrors like this. There are still landmines allover the country and people get hurt. But in comparison, for example, to most european countries, healthcare is not available for everyone and disability makes it much harder to find a job. When visiting the temples of angkor, you will see the musicians that are often victims of landmines. At the war museum you will have the opportunity to learn more about the recent history and support the people with your time and interest and who wants can donate some money to help them.

Guides bring to life the true stories. The static displays are only one aspect of this museum. The real life stories bought to life by the guides are what makes this place a must to visit. Confronting and sad but you realise this is a country full of hope and compassion and great potential. A must for teenagers of western countries to explore and understand how lucky we are. p

Fabulously real. A really interesting and well worthwhile. Talking to the guides who were all veterans was a fascinating experience. 45 minutes is enough time to allow for a good look around and a chat.

What you see is what you get.. This museum has a huge range of weapons that were used until fairly recent times in Cambodia's turbulent history. Tanks and anti-aircraft weapons sit out rusting in the fields but I really liked the experience. It's not fancy but it's real. Tours are led (if you like) by ex-soldiers. I found that really valuable and learned a lot. My poor guide had lost a leg like many, due to landmines. He was so interesting and gentle. I paid him at the end of my tour for his kindness and willingness to share. I did see one group of young blokes in the museum who got all excited about handing the weapons like side show entertainment. I watched their guide walk away. Respect people, respect and you will learn a lot.

It is worth the visit!. I chose to tour the museum by myself. It is worth a visit after Landmine Museum and other temples in order to understand the country a bit better. It is a pity that most Asian tourists opt for shopping, good food and bypass museums. If you are interested in knowing more about the history and prefer a small, quiet "tourist attraction", consider this!

Sad reminder of the cost of war.. Really enjoyed this tour as we were given real accounts of the history. Unfortunately it was also a little horrific when you hear of the huge loss to families during this period in Cambodias history. They do say that the guide is free but in reality it is expected for you to give a donation as they are not paid.

An Absolute Must Experience!!!. I strongly urge anyone who travels to Siem Reap to visit the War Museum in Kaksekam Village. It is incredibly informative and gives a confronting up close insight into decades of conflict in Cambodia. Yet most tourist bypass it on the way to the temples. The guides have all experienced the civil war as veterans, landmine survivors or as civilians and they are what make this museum. They are not looking for pity they just want the stories to continue to be told to educated and hopefully ensure that these atrocities are never allowed to happen again. Our guide told us not only of his own personal story of being the son of an unwilling soldier, the daily fear of stepping on landmines but also of the unimaginable suffering the Cambodian people have endured, and even still do 16 years on. I have read the books, seen the movies but to hear the personal stories from those who survived the war is absolutely heartbreaking. This was one very emotional day which will be ingrained in my memory forever!I took my 9 and 10 year olds, whilst they couldn't comprehend a lot of the stories they certainly understood what it was all about and it was very educational for them.Please don't forgot to leave a generous donation!!!

Come for the personal stories. The outdoor museum itself is nothing fancy - just lots of war remnants and some photos. What makes the visit truly amazing is the personal story of the tour guide. We were fortunate to have Tom as our guide. He was injured by a landmine at the age of 16 and tells a deeply personal story of how war affected Camboda (and how it continues to affects the country via landlines and the tool on its peoples).The guides are all volunteers, so be prepared for to give a tip that also goes towards war victims.Or visit to the War Museum was a moving experience for my whole family. A definite chance to connect with with its history. It is located towards the airport. A tuk tuk will take you there, wait and take you back to town for $10 but you can further bargain down that price.

Must see when in Siem Reap. We came here on the off-chance as we had a spare afternoon and i wanted to learn a bit more about the country's history. Not sure what to expect but was actually one of my highlights of my whole trip to Cambodia! It is only small, mainly outdoors and the guided tour only lasts one hour, but you can wonder around by yourself afterwards. Everything is in English. For a small entrance fee you are greated by a war veteran who gives you an extremely good, yet unbiased insight into all aspects of the war - not just the bits you may have heard about in films or on the news. I learnt so much and came away feeling very appreciative and more knowledgeable. There are many photos taken during and after the war, as well as disused tanks/war supplies, old mines etc.Our guide, Sokham was inspirational. He lost his arm to a landmine whilst fighting the Kyhmer Rouge when he was only 14. He also talked about the current sociopolitical context of the country which is very interesting. He was willing to answer any questions and was grateful at our interest.What surprised was it's lack of visitors. They were so grateful for our visit and it annoyed me that more tourists don't visit. It isn't publicised very well which is a shame and, in my opinion, you cannot visit a country like this without making time to understand its history and plight of its people to get to where they are today. This museum does just that.Please remember, all guides are volunteers and rely on tips. I think they do a fantastic job and hopefully more people will take the time to come and visit. Warning: It is very emotional! I cannot rate this museum enough.

A simple and small museum. It is a small and could hardly be classified as a museum. Just a few tanks, a helicopter and some machine guns were exhibited. The most interesting thing is that you can actually touch many different hand guns, landmines, grenades, bombs etc. And unlike attractions crowded with thousands of people, there is very few visitors.

Don't overlook!. When we asked our hotel about the War museum they looked slightly confused and had to question its location... this seems to be a common theme reading others reviews, not enough publicity. Despite being a small museum without government funding, its 100% worth a visit for $5, the guides who have all survived war and landmine injuries are free of charge and are more than happy to walk you around the museum and open your eyes to a hard history (tipping is highly recommended as the guides volunteer and receive no wages). Overall a very educational visit !

Informative and moving. I read all the reviews for this and all were positive. If you want a genuine experience and another take on Siem Reap besides the temples this is the place to go.... Guide was knowledgeable and quite moving on his tale of the War....don't forget to tip!

Too Underrated . This small museum deserved better publicity. Went there with no expectation and what a surprise. We (adults with few teenagers) enjoyed the free guided tour around the museum with first hand explanations from war veteran. Much better than the Mine Museum.

Educational eye opener. Unbelievable, we thought we were well educated and knowledgable until we visited here, the staff were wonderful , the information truthful and factual, the exhibits so interesting, yes brought tears to our eyes, but you cannot cannot miss this experience and to get the facts ! And leave a donation please to keep this very important museum up and running, if you do not visit you are sadly truly missing out.

War Museum. Fantastic experience.The museum receives no government funding and to see real photos, listen to the stories of people who have lived the atrocities and welcome any questions you have, was an experience unrivaled by other museums. Arrive with no expectations and be taken through life only 15 years earlier.

Unmatched experience, educational. Costs only USD 5/-, and a free guide is provided. Closes as 5:30 PM, but guides start leaving early when there are less visitors, so if you are keen on getting a guide, pls do not arrive too close to 5:30.You need 60-90 minutes if you want a lot of pictures. A must visit for families with young boys (young girls may not appreciate the war machines so much)

Small, but very informative.. You don't need more than an hour to visit. It's very small but the best part is the free guide that is provided with a $5 entrance fee. Our guide was part of the war and had a very personal story to share. He was also very helpful in answering questions and spoke English very well. In the US, we don't have museums where you can hold the weapons and see everything up close. It was interesting to hear how much these cost and then feel how heavy they were!

Education that is priceless. For $5.00 USD, you can see a past that should never be repeated.My friend and I chose to have a guide teach us, and glad we did. Our guide, Ratha, was informative, patient and very friendly. He told us his own experiences of the war and showed us real guns, tanks and deactivated bombs that were used.Please be considerate when taking pictures. Many have died/suffered because of what is in this museum.Great way to spend an afternoon to learn about the past. A nice option that is not a temple.Highly recommended.

Thought provoking experience. Anyone who doesn't know much about Cambodia's recent history should visit the War Museum in Siem Riep. There is a large collection of deactivated military hardware, all of which was used during Cambodia's troubled past.For a $5 entry fee, you can walk around the grounds by yourself or for no extra charge you can have a guided tour with an English speaking guide. I strongly recommend this, as you can get a greater understanding of the conflict. Tips are not expected, but appreciated and in my opinion, deserved. We had a guide for around 30 mins, who was also able to answer any questions we had. Be considerate when touching or taking pictures with the vehicles/weapons, the guide will probably remind you that many died as a result of them. Tuk-Tuk should only be $5-6 return from Siem Riep, although we paid $8 and took a detour to pick up water and refreshments.

Great experience . I went to the war museum and had a great experience, for $5 it's a really good deal. I enjoyed learning more about Cambodia's history and the guide was very friendly and knowledgeable. Lots to see and lots to learn.

Worth it!. For $5 this is definitely worth a see! I would definitely recommend getting a free Tour guide. Our tour guide was able to tell us so much information, he answered all of our questions and even told us stories about his own family and friends during the war, a good way to spend an afternoon in siem reap.

Great informative afternoon. Really interesting afternoon spent at the war museum, our guide was great, good english and very knowledgeable, answered all of our questions very well and shared some very touching first hand experiences. Would recommend it to all visitors to Cambodia to get a good quick insight into the recent history of cambodia

Basic but informative and touching. This was the most basic museum of our entire trip round SE Asia but in my opinion probably the best.We were shown round the museum by a tour guide who lost an arm to a land mine when he was a kid. He talked us through the history of the French War, American war and Pol Pot. What made this museum different was the guide could talk to us about personal tragedy's he and people close to him have actually experienced really giving you a feel for how these events shaped people's lives and are still affecting people today. If you go to Siem Reap you must see this place.

Small but very good. Use a guide who has experienced the war...his memories reveal what a terrible impact thus had on his family, neighbourhood and the country as a whole - a small site but with good exhibits - the guide will make the visit more educational.

Must see museum.. A great educational museum made even better by the guides. They are free but work on donations. My guide had excellent English and told us very insightful and harrowing stories about his family and his own personal experiences. A culturally and historically important place, I would really recommend this if you are in Siem Reap.

Simple but worth it. An open air museum (don't forget to bring your anti mosquito spray) full of interesting things to see to learn more about Khmer rouge and the troubled recent history of Cambodia. 5 dollars admission fee and free guide available on site. An interesting alternative to Angkor complex.

A look into our guide's past. Often when we travel we like to see all of the great things that a city or country has to offer. It is important not to forget that they have storied pasts as well. Although this outdoor museum is not very large, our guide did a great job of describing what he and his family lived through from the 1970s until the 1990s.
Very good experience. My family loved this. It is very surreal walking around place like this. Our tour guy was lovely and very informative.

must see- super impactful and educational. We were recommended this Museum by our driver. We were coming into Siem Riep after a few days in Phnom Penh, so had already visited The Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum, and were somewhat hit with the gory details. I was not really excited to attend yet another heavy, depressing, but necessary and educating, museum of horrors. Tour Guide onsite was 'free' in that we could tip him at the end if we liked. Long story short, he was very knowledgeable, and like the majority of Cambodians, impacted by the horrors of the Khmer Rouge tyranny. The museum showed the machines of war, utilized from 1975, all the way up the 1999. It was shocking to see a tank in the museum, that was still in use in 1999. Seeing the actual war machines (decommissioned of course) really hit everything home. Very educational and must see, if you want to learn more about the war in Cambodia.

Simple but compelling. We hadn't intended on coming here but our tuk tuk driver suggested it and I'm glad we decided to go. Our guide was included in the admission fee and was the best part of the museum (do not do it alone). He was the missing piece to our Cambodian experience. Although we had read much about the Khmer Rouge in Phnom Penh, it was our guide that provides us with insight on how it was to be someone who had witnessed it and who had their family affected by it. His explanations were not seeking pity, but to inform. He was very knowledgeable. Recommended!

Great take on the recent past. This is a private museum but the personal touch is a fantastic addendum if you visited the killing fields or Tuol Sleng in Phnom Penh. The museum contains a collection of military equipment but what was valuable were the stories from the free guide. The museum also frames the ongoing struggle of Cambodians with land mines and anguish from decades of war. Learned a lot and it would be a shame if we lost this relic because of lack of visitors which seems to be the case. Check it out if you have time.

A must see for those who want more.... This was an excellent experience. Our tour guide gave his own personal account of how the war had impacted his life. We were surprised how few the number of tourists were actually there given that we had been at the temples the day prior. This is a must for those who want to understand a country and want more than temples and cheap market wares.

This place is a must see . The personal approach this museum takes makes for a wonderful experience. Our guide was Tom, a war veteran who lost his arm to a claymore land mine when he was just 14. The personal stories he shared made this terrible period of Cambodian history come alive for us. The message that came through loud and clear is practice tolerance and make love not war. Do not miss this amazing place.

Learn a bit of History. It is an outdoor museum, with old war vehicles, cannons, guns as exhibit. It also has interactive areas like the one with the flamethrower / mine. They are organized and presented like it has been only a day after they were last used in the war.We went in the late afternoon, and the guides left are non-English speakers. Still, we had learned alot.

Wont be dissapointed. Grab the free guide and learn about the history although this may not be the same sort of museum you will be use to back home it is amazing if you are into history and war time history. All the guides where involved in the war and tell you there story . You will be asked for a gratuity at the end but i didnt find this to much as these guys spend the time to help you learn about there past

Informative!. Had a few hours to spare before we had to be at the airport so our driver took us here! I usually HATE tours but I really enjoyed this one. We got a really informative free guide who took his time with us, excellent english too. Unfortunately it was revealed that the museum is lacking tourists and may not survive much longer, what a shame!I really hope people support this informative experience!

Very sobering. This is very well presented and gives a person good insight into what has taken place in the Vietnam war years. It is very clear and factual and doesn't glorify the wart but gives you a good depth of understanding of what has taken place
Great and entertaining display. Very interesting place, free guide to walk you around and explain the many exhibits. I learnt so much from him

Thought provoking visit. We went with our two boys aged 7 and 15. We had a really knowledgeable guide who really educated us about war in Cambodia- sobering and thought provoking. Definately worth a visit
Sobering.... Looking for something to do that we would both enjoy we ended up here. The staff were welcoming and friendly. This is a must see it really opens your eyes to the history of Cambodia.
Eye opening. The war museum was an eye ponder, situations and relics shown and explained by a war veteran brought to light that in a war there are no winners.A must visit...though a somber one.

Another reminder of what Cambodia has suffered. Probably less well known than the killing fields and S.21, this place is well worth a visit. Receipts support related causes, as do purchases from the shop, so really helps to support a good cause. The more one sees of Cambodian history, the more remarkable it is that the country survived at all - these are important reminders and should definitely be on every itinerary.

Please visit and donate!. The staff at the museum are friendly and offer free tours around the area - our tour guide was telling us how sometimes there are only 20 people in a day that visit, which means the museum can't survive for much longer which is a shame and pity as the artifacts really shed light on a dire situation and give a person perspective, especially after hearing what the tour guide had to say!
Very informative and humbling. worth a visit and the free guides are very passionate in sharing the history. Quite an eye opener to terrible times for the lovely Cambodian people.

Definitely recommended . Our tuk-tuk driver suggested a visit to the museum and it was very interesting. Do take the free tour with a guide. Most of the guides a war veterans, telling you their own personal stories. You learn a lot about the fate of landmine victims and can make a donotion since the Cambodian government does not provide any support. Out guide Mang spoke good English and answered all out questions. I highly recommend a visit to the museum.

Sobering Stuff. we visited here not really sure what expect. When we arrived we were the only people there! Our guide was excellent, very very good English. His story of losing all his family at 12 and then being forced to fight for the Khmer Rouge at 14 was very sad and brought a tear to my eye. (His father in law is also an amputee who plays in the band on pub street. They play every night to make some money as they can't work in normal jobs) Worth every penny, you must visit.

Eye-opening and well worth the visit. A friend recommended I take a visit to the War Museum if I had any interest in Cambodian war history. I’m not a person who is particularly fascinated by history in general, but Cambodia really struck a chord with me. The atrocities that they suffered are incomprehensible and so heinous that you can’t help but want to learn more about what led to it. The museum is a little off the beaten path and I was taken by a tuk tuk- we stopped at a tourism office in town to purchase my $5 USD ticket beforehand, for some reason. When I arrived, I was surprised to find practically no one there. I entered the outdoor museum (alone, mind you) and was greeted by a guide. The guides are free and very informative (albeit slightly difficult to understand.) Mine escorted me around the property, which is filled with planes, helicopters, tanks, guns, land mines, grenades, and every other weapon you can possibly think of. His stories absolutely broke my heart – pointing out particular kinds of land mines that killed his friends, talking about his parents’ passing, and going into detail about the fear of bombs, being dropped by my own country. He spoke about several of the other tour guides, and it seems everyone that works there has been directly affected by the Khmer Rouge. There’s nothing particularly wonderful about this museum in terms of aesthetics, but if you want to educate yourself and get personalized treatment, the museum could really use your support. Give them a small tip at the end of the tour and they’ll be really grateful.

A great place to visit no matter your intentions. At first glance, it seems like a couple of rusty tanks and vehicles. But don't be fooled by it. This museum has a lot more to offer! The guides, which are free, are amazing and are all victims of the khmer roughe in one way or the other. Don't miss the opportunity to talk to them and learn a lot more about modern Cambodia than you might have learnt in school. This is the real deal. No sugarcoating. Angkor wat might be cool, but without a visit to the war museum and the guides (I emphasise the guides, since they are the most important part of the museum) you will never understand Cambodia as a whole. And if information, a more humble view on life, and learning things about the country you visit, isn't interesting to you, well no problem! The also have aa Chinese Mig fighter jet as well as a sovjet helicopter, and tons of guns you can hold and pose with. A great place to visit no matter what your intentions are
For those who love the weapons thing n war. Great place for historical lover. This place is a museum of war things..weapons, war tank n everything about war ... Entrance fee us5

Humbling Experience. I had a general idea that Cambodia has had a really hard time not being invilved in war. To get a detailed version of what this country has gone through, go and visit this site. The guides are free with entry fee and all are former war veterans, Some fought for Khmer Rouge and some against them. All were wounded in more ways than one. Their storys are compelling and they are working hard to make Cambodia a better country, If you can get Tom to be your guide. He is a genuine man and a great storyteller. He really made this experience worth our time.

A Worthwhile Stop. Background on pricing etc - there is an entrance fee of $5 and you will need a tuk tuk to get out to the museum as it's about 20 minutes from the Pub St area, for us i think this was $7 return.Now the Mueseum, firstly get a guide (included in price) - they are worth their weight in gold for the information and background they give you.Our guide was a Khmer child soldier at 10. Although the Khmer history is mind-boggling to comprehend, he made it real. From the guns with bent barrels from the heat to the stories of how people were killed using sharpened bamboo to save on bullets. The museum houses a lot of tanks and big machinery as well as guns, landmines and photos from the war, but without the stories it's just a collection.If you're not coming to Siem Reap for the cheap grog, and want to know more about the culture than the temples, this is the stop to really be able understand the country and it's people and everything they've been through.
mengenal sejarah di cambodia. untuk entrance masuk usd5. kira2 45min dr town utk ke war museum. for me,its not worth the money because it only took 30mins to watch all the war stuff thr.

Amazing place . This is well worth the visit to get an idea of what went on during the war time in Cambodia. Make sure you get a tour guide when you are here and they will show you around and explain everything.

Fascinating . After reading reviews, it does state that the entrance is free to visitors but there is an entrance fee of $5 and is worth it. They offer free tour guide which are very knowledgable and is worth the visit of in seim reap!!!!

History Before Your Eyes. I was dubious about going here but I am so glad I went. Our guide was young and his mission is to tell people about the history of the Khmer Rouge and all the atrocities that happened. He lived through this period of time and his stories were fascinating.It is an open air museum with a few huts that hold the landmines and guns that were used, as well as photos. They collected tanks etc. and brought them into Siem Reap and explained a lot of history. For instance people were taken and chained inside the tanks and left to die. The early landmines were easy to find as metal detectors were used but as the war went on the mines were made out of plastic and impossible to find.We were told that the amputees you see in town are proud people and they sell books or play in bands to make money. It was definitely worth the visit.

Very informative. An informative way to learn about the war that happened there. Weapons used, and its effects on the beautiful Khmer people.We can highly recommend Silong , one of the employees there. He has an incredible memory, told us lots of information, and made it an experience which spoke to our hearts as well as our minds. Thanks Silong.(We wish you well).

A Must See to Appreciate Cambodia History. Go here, and request (and tip well) one of the local non-paid guides. They have lost a lot and are brave in sharing their personal stories and those of their countries sad history.

Insightful. Whilst indeed simple in appearance, the site was well laid out and organised. Recommend the free tour, guided by extremely friendly and passionate local men. They are extremely knowledgeable about the atrocities that happened and can even share from personal experience. The displays, such as the weapon rack and landmines, were well set up and being allowed to interact with many of them was appreciated. Please be generous in visiting and help support the museum and its message.
An interesting experience. This is a bit of a secondary Museum in Siem Reap, but nonetheless has it's beauty. A great collection of artifacts and weaponry from the recent Vietnam era and recent past.

Well worth the visit with a local guide. Definitely need to visit with one of the local guides who will bring the place to life & have a lot of stories to tell. A guide is included in the entry fee which is $5. All outdoors so need to visit on a dry day!
Not great. There is no indoor exhibitions. Just a few old tanks and guns. Very basic. Not much explanations. Very disappointing.

A must visit when in Siem Reap. The tour guide was excellent he knew all the history of the Kymer Rouge Regime. The museum displays a wide variety of military equipment used in the wars in Cambodia over the last three decades. A very good insight to the life the Cambodian people have endured.The museum is 5km from town centre, Tut-Tut's are very cheap and will wait while you visit the museum.

Support is needed. This place is a little out of the way, but easily combined with a visit to Banteay Srei. The stories told are powerful and the work done is essential. Financial help is very needed.

Cambodia's voilent past.. Well worth the 5 dollars entry fee. A vast array of soviet era tanks and other heavy weapons as well as an assortment of small arms and mines and mortars. The guides are free however I recommend a good tip as the young lad we had was extremely knowledgeable regards Cambodia's violent past. He was passionate about making sure his generation was aware of their past and never forgot what their parents and grandparents had experienced.
Worth the visit. YOu should see this for several reasons. When one quarter of the country was masqueraded by the Khmer rouge you need to know about it

Do not miss this. It will only take you an hour and you will learn a great deal in that time about the recent violent history of Cambodia. The guides explain clearly the cause, the conflict, the terrible suffering and ghosts that they live with. They will leave you with a better understanding of the very recent horrors and you will better understand why there are so many amputees left to beg on the streets and perhaps more understanding and charitable attitude I hope.

Harrowing. A sobering experience, the rust and remnants of a disturbing past which is as fascinating as it is saddening. Must visit in Siem Reap, but be prepared for the stories your guide will tell you.

The guides are free but please tip handsomely.. Our guide was a veteran of the Cambodian War who lost his arm at the age of just 14 as a boy soldier. The exhibits were authentic and bring home the absolute horror of war. I knew little about Khymer Rouge & Pol Pot at the start - man's inhumanity to man is incomprehensible. Never should this be allowed to happen again.

Must see with the free tour guide. Must go with (free) tour guide. You can give a tip at the end but it adds to the experience. It's horrific yet fascinating. The tour guide give so much information in a short time. We'll worth the visit. It doesn't take long.

. Make sure you get a guide! Sobering experience. We decided to visit the War Museum after reading the positive reviews on Trip Advisor. My husband and I went with our 4 children aged between 7-15 I wasn;t sure what they would think, but they got a very important histyory lesson from our wonderful guide. The guides are free and I highly recommend that you get one. Our guide told us his own harrowing story about growing up in Cambodiaduring the reign of the Khmer Rouge and the difficulties that he has faced growing up without his paretns when they both died when he was just 5 years old. Our guide spoke perfect English and he often gets asked why he doesn;t move to another country. He chooses to stay in Cambodia and volunteer at the War Museum as he believes in the importance of sharing his story and the troubled history that his country has been through. We gave him a very good tip as we were extremely grateful for his honest and emotional story and for all of the information that he shared with us. He answered all of our questions openly and honestly. This is definitely worth a visit!$5 for adults and kids are free. Get a free guide and tip them well if you were happy with them. They are not pushy at all which always makes me give a better tip.

Heart Breaking. The real story here is not the equipment the guns the tanks etc, but the stories of the guides and their personal experiences from the war and subsequent times.Modern Cambodia has a horrific history and now more than ever there are lessons be learnt that these atrocities never happen again.

Cambodia history that cannot be forgotten. A small but important collection of military artifacts and history of the wars and conflicts that are part of Cambodia. This is time well spent while visiting, and for best experience, have a guide who will provide a personal perspective to the horrors of recent past.

Worth a visit. It's quite a way out of town maybe $2 tuk tuk ride but it is definitely worth a visit. It's a small open air museum which offers free guides. Do get one to take you round it makes the experience. Not only do they explain in detail all the land mines and equipment as well as the tanks and politics etc but you also get their own personal accounts and stories of the civil war. Very very sobering. It's not big and won't take up much time. I spent about an hour and half there. Ask your tuk tuk driver to stay and wait as its in the middle of nowhere so it's not easy to catch one back! Very informative. Glad I took the time to go.

Great platform to learn about the dark era of Cambodia. At first, I thought at $5, it was another rip-off attraction. However, after spending more than an hour in the museum, I believe this museum is a must visit attraction while you are in Siem Reap. I was impressed by the number of tank, artillery and gun displayed in the museum. There was also a fighter jet and a combat helicopter to greet you at the entrance.You can roam freely without guide but I would strongly advise to ask for a guide (its free anyway) or wait for one because as survivors of the war, they would give insight explanation of what had happened during the war. The lack of information displayed at each items is also one of the reason why you need a guide.The location of the museum is quite far from the main road but it is just about 10 minutes tuk tuk ride from the town. In my opinion, this is the best platform to learn about the war during the Khmer Rouge era.

A somewhat sobering experience. Quite a large collection of military weapons, artillery, tanks, and even a massive Soviet helicopter and a Korean war era MIG fighter. With the exception of the aircraft most of the artifacts were recovered in the field and showed battle damage, some quite severe. Also quite a collection of a variety of mines and ordinance. One of the things that made the experience more than just a collection of hardware was the opportunity to go to the museum with one of the actual veterans of that combat during the Khmer Rouge era. Our guide lost his family during the early years of the Khmer Rouge, all killed but himself when he was nine years old. Eventually he fought against The Khmer Rouge and was seriously wounded a number of times. He showed us battle wounds including several AK 47 rounds, a piece of shrapnel under his skin, scars from mine damage and lifted his pants leg to reveal a prosthetic limb from a mine injury. All of this beginning as a 13 year old soldier. His accounts of the mass killings under the Pol Pot regime were almost surreal. No question that this visit was worthwhile, if not more than a bit uncomfortable, in understanding how ideological struggles translate to human misery. $5 admission pp and an optional guide tip supports these individuals. Easily accessible by tuk tuk.

A very worthwhile visit. Our guide was forced into being a child soldier for the Khmer Rouge and had lost one arm. He explained what had happened to him, his family and friends during that time and it brought me to tears. The photos of some of the victims are a terrible reminder of what happened in Cambodia during the terrible years of the war. The most shocking thing for us was that Cambodia is still paying back the various governments, eg Russia, the USA, China etc for the cost of armaments, tanks and so on. A very sad place but well set out and peaceful now.

Worth a visit to hear first-hand from a true survivor of the Khmer Rouge years. This open-air museum is well worth a visit for the tour given by the guides, all veterans of the Khmer Rouge years, real survivors. Reality stares you straight in the face - this is a sobering experience. The museum itself is basic in the extreme so come for the stories and the opportunity to ask questions and learn about Cambodia's brutal past.

Educational and much more...... War was always images or articles from the past or news from aboard to me. Listening to experience from a one armed soft spoken war veteran, and seeing and feeling all the guns/ landmines.....really made one humble and appreciate peace. I highly recommend this educational but shocking experience, and please don't hesistate to donate.

More than just the visual. Get a tour guide and learn about the history. Khmer people suffrage and Vietnam War collateral damage. Khmer Rouge genocide and stories from child soldiers now grown. Tip your guide directly, they don't get anything from the museum.

Humbling experience . This is one of those non-entertaining activities that everyone visiting Siem Reap needs to do. Totally funded by donations and a minimal entry fee of $5 US it is an interesting and informative way to see about and understand what Cambodian people have had to endure over the last 50 or so years. Our guide was orphaned as a result of war & shared with passion & humility.

A great way to.learn more about life during the Khmer rouge days . Entry $5 Guides are free, they are first hand survivors and old veterans. An old Mine field just out of the central cbd is the only war museum in cambodia. Our guide was "the cat" a man who has died and come back to life more then 10 times! He was a young boy drafted into the Khmer rouge at 10 and taught to do terrible things to serve pol.pot. He is a true survivor and leads you through the history and weapons used during the war days. A must go, for anyone who wants to see first hand the damage caused by war. Donations aren't expected but go along way to support the victims of land mines.

Ok. If you know what your looking at and have an active interest in military the place is not to bad. A mix of excellent condition small arms and some very good recoilless rifles. Some of the armoured vehicles (most really) in average condition however if you know what your looking at!!! not to bad over all. Good job with the limited funds you have guys. $5 entry very fair price.

Not your average museum. No this is another war museum. It was unique and worth the hassle to get there. We went because we had a bit of time to burn. The museum layout was basically a garden of war remnants. We had a veteran as a tour guide, where he focused on telling us his experience during the war and showed us his battle scars as he brought us around. Then after he was done, we were allowed to explore the whole place unsupervised. You can play with the disarmed weapon, tanks, helicopter, and landmines, etc. Best part is admission was only $5usd. Worth!!

Sobering. We have done the war museum in ho chi minh and it was all propaganda. This war museum remains balanced. Most exhibitions are outdoor but there is good shade. The guides are free and offer an insight into cambodias troubled past.

Definitely worth visiting . I would recommend this to anyone that is interested in Cambodian history, in which everyone should be if they are touring the country. $5 entry and a kind donation to an English speaking tour guide who will show you around the stations. It is outdoors so bring a hat etc. Very upsetting but a must-see.

Interesting and fascinating guided tour, must do. The guided tour was very informative and engaging and I learned so much about Cambodia's difficult past. Our guide spoke openly about the history of his country in excellent English and his own personal experiences connecting him to his descriptions made it that much more shocking. The details were very violent and saddening so the museum may be too troubling for young children. The museum itself was organised brilliantly and there were many opportunities to get hands-on with small mines, guns and arms, all in a lush outdoor expansive environment. Overall I found the museum intriguing and incredibly eye-opening. A must-visit for all tourists to Siem Reap in order to understand Cambodia's terrible history.

A worthwhile visit to understand recent history. The museum itself is mostly rusting tanks, guns and a few photo boards. But the guides who work for a tip make it all very worthwhile to get some understanding about the decades of civil war the poor Cambodian people endured, the terrible genocide by the Khmer Rouge and the ongoing legacy of land mines riddling the countryside.Certainly highly recommended.

Reality of the Cambodia war. These place gives you the idea of how the Cambodian war ended with all possible equipments and tanks used.The guides are somehow related to the war and they explain the history in very nice and simple way.Must place to witness the history of Cambodia in siem reap.

A very humbling experinece which I so glad I did. I had read about the War remnants museum in a travel guide and felt I should pay it a visit, considering the bloody and sickening history of this poor country which has already suffered more than any of us could possibly imagine. As an adult, I knew very little about the Khmer Rouge regime or anything really about the **** **** Pol Pot!! It's really hard not to swear in this review, such is the anger for that evil dictator and what he did to this Country. The museum is a very harsh and stark reminder of just what the people of Cambodia suffered in just a very short space of time in those dark years of the early 70's. It's extremely well presented and quite poignant in it's location. How you can walk around lush foliage, trees and manicured gardens, but scattered amongst them are tanks, cannons, shells, ammunition and so many horrific images is a real eye opener. It's reflective, emotional, educational and should make anyone who visits feel extremely lucky, privileged and honoured to even be sharing a part of this dark period in Cambodia's history. I know Siem Reap is all about Angkor, but you must find time to visit this museum...........please.

Brilliant educational tour. The tuk tuk went down narrow and quiet streets to an unassuming entrance. We walked into a surprisingly huge open expanse with incredible display of war relics including Russian helicopters, tanks and armoury. Free guide walked around with us explaining the displays and also provided in depth lecture on Cambodia's war history, including all about landmines. He was engaging and knowledgeable, and gave us an insight into what schools teach young Cambodians about its history. Brilliant educational tour and highly recommended.

War museam Siemens reap. The tour is taken by a local who has had experience of wot did happen They explain the whole proses of the war and haw they have uptaind all the display proses and haw they are still working to remove the rest of the mines that are around the country

Reflection on war. I have visited many war museums around the world this one was a little different. Decaying hulls of armoured vehicles and guns, a Hind Helicopter and a Mig fighter jet along with old weapons that people can handle. Sadly and it's not the museums fault the weather was wet and thus causing the walking tracks to become muddy. The free guide is great with personal knowledge of the era. The atrocities caused by the Khmer Rouge on their own people is daunting enough but to see it would of been more devastating. Take the time to visit. Like everything they have their story to tell. A sad but true reflection on how mankind can be so cruel. The artifacts no longer work but would be great to see a restoration program start trying to bring some former glory to these beasts of war. This attraction is really for all age groups, and I listened to a old US soldier talking about his time in SEA during his service puts this museum where it should be something that needs to be told to all future visitors and generations of asset that should not be forgotten.

go and have a look. we went to the museum as a day-off-the-temples rest day. we had a fantastic guide who took us around each of the info areas explaining the whole history of Cambodia in a fascinating way. It makes you realise what a terrible and traumatic time the Cambodians have had to live through.Our teenage boys absolutely loved it as they could touch and hold all the weapons and artillery, even climb into the tanks and rocket launchers!Definitely worth a visit

Worth visiting !. We went to the museum after half a day at the temples. Was really interesting with a great guide. $5 to get in which i think is reasonable. Very sad to learn more about the civil war and the weapons and machines that they have on show are incredible!

Important piece of history - must see. Even if you came to see temples and Pub Street this museum is too important to miss. Only $5 entry it includes a free guide who has been injured as a result of war. Our guide spoke great English and provided great explanations of the myriad exhibits. Awesome photos and all the weaponry you could wish to see. The museum is a sad and poignant reminder of what Cambodia has suffered and is still suffering with 2 million land mines in the ground killing and injuring people every day, even in 2015. Apart from the fact this museum is an awesome record of troubled times, with only 20 visitors a day at the moment it will die if not supported - and that will also be a tragedy

A place of sad reflection. I first visited this site 3 years ago. It is difficult to describe the feelings it brings out. A mixture of sadness, anger and disbelief at man's inhumanity to man. Yes it is worth seeing if only to bring into sharp focus what happened here and at other sites across Cambodia. Is it interesting? Yes but in the most odd way. My visit created a desire in me to read more about the history of this wonderful nation and to try to understand the mind of Pol Pot and his followers. Have I succeeded? Well in same ways. Do come here but be prepared to be saddened by the experience

Amazing insight into the history of Cambodia. This place is well worth the visit. The $5 admission fee is nothing for the history lesson you get. Our guide Tom was very in depth and detailed on the history of Cambodia and gave us a great insight into it all, such a nice man always smiling despite everything he has been through.. People complaining about the set up need to get a grip, the place is full of history and the guides bring it to life. The guides are volunteers and mainly veterans who may not be able to get work elsewhere due to their injuries in the war and from Landmines. It really shows us how lucky some of us really are.

Good history lesson of the civil war in Cambodia. You really get to see alot of weapons and land mines (of course they are not operational) during the visit. A little bit out of town but get a cheap Tuk Tuk to take you there for less than <$10 USD.

Excellent source of Cambodian history . I understand why previous reviewers may have given the museum a low review, as the museum doesn't have a professional touch to it (as say the National Museum does). While it lacks fancy exhibits, it does have many artifacts from the war, including mines, small arms, tanks, and even a helicopter. What truly makes the museum is the guide. A guide comes with your 5$ admission fee. My guide recently graduated university, and his father had fought in the war. Other guides are veterans. He had so much knowledge about Cambodia's recent history (past 40 years) and stayed with me at the end to answer all of my questions related to Cambodia and their present circumstances. As I had no prior knowledge on Cambodia, it was very eye opening and informative. Remember, the tour guides are volunteers and the museum runs on donations and your small admission fee. Of course it will not look like the National Museum, but it is still very worthwhile and you'll gain lots of information. A must see in Siem Reap for responsible tourism. SN: I did offer a small donation at the end, but was not pressured to do so.

Definitely worth visiting . We got the free guide and it was definitely worth it. He told us all about the region the old problems and the current political problems. We asked him tons of questions and he answered all of them. You can also climb on everything and take pictures. It was both fun and informative. We were never asked to donate either.

Pretty Worth Visiting. Though when i arrived here i was pretty disappointed of high expectations, this place has lots of things to learn. Many of the things there like tanks and war machines are broken and rusty, but it has a collection of guns which will make a good photo. This place is worth visiting if you like army things.. but it needs lots of repair

Must visit . This is an hour or so visit so after u have seen the lake from the road (but not gone on the boat - DO NOT OR THEY CHARGE U $50 to hire the entire boat when it is $3 in the communal one which they don't tell you)It's full of historical information and the tour guide is a veteran with first hand experience. The guide is FOC but you can make a donation if you wish without pressure - bones/remains are still in a tank. Harrowing stories but interesting

Old museum but informative. Probably not as modern as National Angkor Museum but I would say it's quite interesting to visit this museum. But just make sure that you get the museum guide to help you browsing around the museum. So that u can further understand what's War Museum is all about. The guides are very friendly. Entrance ticket is $5, fairly cheap for me. But for some head ups, the museum is not in a building, so it's going to be hot & humid. Probably bring a shade or cap.

Very interesting for all ages. I have been to the War Museum twice before and plan on taking more friends in the next few months. It is very informative and gives you a great insight into the Pol Pot regime from both sides. The machinery, photos and excellent guides personal stories makes it all feel so real. Makes you appreciate the safety of our country. Very reasonable entrance fee and well kept grounds. Thoughly recommend visiting this place of history.

Must do in Siem Reap!!!. This was by far the best thing we did in Siem Reap. The entrance is a very reasonable price ($5) and inside the guides work for free. It's even more interesting as all the guides are war veterans and gladly share their experiences with you. It's important that the legacy of the victims of the war lives on and this is how they share it. You are expected to give a donation however, but it's definitely worth the experience and it's for a good cause! The tour was just amazing and our guide was a very good man (Tom).

Brilliant insight!! . Went today with 2 friends, received some great information regarding the history of Cambodia and would thoroughly recommend the trip!At $5 it's very reasonably priced for what you get; an hour long guide with a war veteran who fought in the Cambodian Civil war! The guide is present through a number of different station and spoke at length about the old armed vehicles which are at the museum!Only criticism would be that there is a lot of pressure placed on you at the end of the tour for a donation by the tour guide. We were asked personally if we wanted to donate and if so too give the money to the tour guide at the time! Appreciate the need for donation in attractions like this however think it should be a personal choice and not pushed upon you! Other than that, very good!

A chilling reminder of recent history.. We travelled here on a tuk tuk from our hotel and it was around 5km from the heart of Siem Reap. We didn't take a free guide, but the plaques kept you reasonably informed as to what you were observing, where it was made, where it was last used and for how long.It is outdoors so it's very hot. We would have stayed longer if it wasn't so hot. It would be good to allow 1 hour to peruse the museum.

Nice museum. Nice museum. Visit Ard 30 mins enough unless you want the local guide to go with you. Impressive Russian tanks build in 1930s, used in the 1970s and on display now, though looked like scrapped metals. However 20000KHR pp was worth it.

Worth every dollar. This should be a must if you are visiting Siem Reap. We were escorted by our excellent guide Mean Sokhon who was forced into the war at the age of 14. He subsequently lost his arm at 16 when his friend stepped on a landline. His English was very good as he explained what happened in the war. The displays were informative.

Well worth a visit. It seems wrong to say this was great due to the nature of its exhibits, but it was so interesting and we were amazed how recent everything was. It is $5 to get in and this includes a guide who has first hand experience of the wars. It really is worth going and they also need support as they are in danger of having to close.
Personal Opinion. Hmmm... personally we felt that this is a waste of time and money. We went there and all we see are rusty metals. Its us... cos this is not our cup of tea.

Visit with the guide. The entrance fee to the museum includes a free local guide. He spoke great English and was very informative and helpful in answering any queries about the history in Cambodia. We highly recommend a visit to this museum to get an even deeper insight on the wars Cambodia has endured.

Great place, sad memoriez. The museum is actually an open air place where a different set of tanks, planes artillery and weapons are on display. There are different sets of bullets, rockets, mortars and mines on display.The museum is dedicated to the memories of the war that happened in the seventies which claimed millions of casualtiesTicket price is okay 5$ and you may need to take a Tuk Tuk to get there

A real lesson and insight to the khmar rougue war don't miss it. We learnt at lot from our guide. Tom told us his story. Tom is one very brave amazing human to tell this day after day. I will always be grateful that he spent the time telling us his story. He kindly guided us through the various weapons and land-mines. You will be expected to give a donation its worth it as you will learn something. I read some bad reviews please don't take this as being the truth.

GET A GUIDE! . Entry fee is only $5 and we fantastic personal account from our guide, who offer their service for FREE, so there is little excuse not to let them show you around. Being frank the museum itself is in need of some love and care and I believe it will continue to grow in quality as more and more visitors come. The guides really do make this place though. They do give you an opportunity at the end to donate but this wasn't pushy or driven.

Worth a visit if you're in Siem Reap. Definitely worth a visit if you're in Siem Reap but don't be expecting a polished exhibition. Cheap entrance fee and all guides appear to have decent English and knowledge of the war. Depending on your interest, the tour should take around 2 hours
great. enjoy and digest this very complicated historyread the story of the vets. very insightful what was and is going ongood placevery educativeand keep some change for donations

Peaceful setting with so much history. This museum is set in a beautiful setting outside. It is very peaceful. There is not much information to read around the museum and hence we chose to have a free guided tour. The man who took us on the tour was very young and so full of knowledge and information. We didn't know much about the history of the Cambodian War so he started at the beginning and explained it all to us and it was fascinating. We would definately recommend taking up the free tour. We learnt so much and really walked away from the museum having a better appreciation of what the poor Cambodian people went through only 30 years ago.

Everyone should see this place.. This experience is informative and at times very confronting. The free guides are a must. This horror is so recent that most of the people volunteering there were born during the war.

Worth a look.. The Museum only consisted of old tanks, aircraft, anti tank weapons, plenty of guns.They give you a free guide who takes you around and explains every thing to you for free, although they do hint that a tip would be helpful to keep the place open, i gave them US$5, which he seemed happy with, and he was very informative about the Khmer and Pol Pot era, most of it is out in the open, so if the weather is bad then it may be a bit uncomfortable, some things are under cover, worth one visit.

Must go, listen and see!. This museum tells you about the awful war that lasten tillen 1999. Can you imagine that all the cruelties took placement not even so long ago. Please listen to the guide who fought during this war himself, his story really touched me.

Amazing Story and Place. We had one more day and hadn't really planned anything so we decided to go see the war museum. It was a cheap thing to do but listening to our guide tell the story of the war and how he lost his arm etc made the tour so awesome and touching. There were times I had to hold back the tears. It's unbelievable what the soldiers went through. Lest us not forget.

Must see. We went here to cram in something else instead of waiting around our hotel for an airport transfer. It's well worth going to and better still if you go just after opening time you'll get a guide probably to yourself. You'll learn lots about what really happened. It's not just for war buffs, we came away feeling quite moved by the hardship and tragedy that people here have gone through in the recent wars.

Most eye opening tour ever. We decided to spent an hour here after visiting the military museum in Hanoi. The reviews did paint a somber, reflective picture of this museum. It is far more of an education than a visit. The tour guide (as every other review highlights) is what makes this such an important place to visit if you go to Siem Reap. It's about $8 from town return and the Tuk Tuk driver will wait for you. It's $5 to get in for adults (kids free) and we tipped the guide $10. It is the most moving, eye opening, real insight into the atrocities of this war torn country. Not any easy experience but if you don't know much about the genocide then go and learn. If you know lots already then you are guaranteed to learn more. 10/10!!

Place to understand Cambodians and their history. I just came back from war museum and would like to recommend everybody to visit this place. Our guide explained us everything about the recent history of Cambodia that was missed from newspapers and helped us understand more Cambodian people. Despite the reviews I previously read, that the tours are guided by war veterans, he was a young man, with fantastic English and willing to answer any question we asked. Thank you!

Must see. There isn't a lot about the recent wars in Cambodia in the whole country as they try to forget the atrocities, so this is a must for anyone with an interest in recent history.Brilliant open air museum, filled with the remains of tanks, rocket launchers, guns, mines etc. this was fun for the kids as you can play with the guns, climb on the tanks. However, the highlight is to explore with a guide (for free) who will explain the complex history and build up to the wars and the rise of Khmer Rouge. Our guide had lost 3/4 of his family through the wars and following famine

Heart wrenching trip through their history. We chanced heading there in the pouring rain, and even then were not disappointed. Our guide was Silom, a good humoured young Cambodian man, who took us through the history of the various stages of Cambodia's wars and the travesty visited upon these gentle people. Very knowledgeable as his parents were first hand survivors of the war and was willing to answer any questions we had (though we didn't have very many, being stunned into silence mostly). I know some reviews have said it is a collection of rust bucket tanks, but if you take the time to listen to the free guides and their stories, you will gain a completely new respect for this place and what it represents, and for the people here who strive hard towards a better life. Worth every penny and then some, really a must see in Siem Reap.

A must see in Siem Reap.. We were shown around by Mr Tom who is an incredible man with a good sense of humor and a beautiful philosophy on life . We walked around the outdoor museum with Mr Tom at a leisurely pace , who explained about the Cambodian History relative to the museum and the history of many of the old weapons on display also about his own personal experiences . The visit was a highlight off my trip to Cambodia and gave me a greater appreciation of the struggle Cambodians have faced .the entry fee is very small.

Should be the Top Attraction in Siem Reap . We visited the war museum on the last day of our stay in Siem Reap. It was, undoubtedly, our favourite visit of our stay in the city. For us, it was far better than our visit to the temples. The museum has a collection of land mines, military munitions, tanks and air craft which were interesting. That said, what made our visit particularly impactful was the free guide ("Tom"), whose services came as a part of our $5 admission (tips after the tour are shared amongst guides).Tom was an eye-witness of the Cambodian civil war. He lost his family at 12 years old, whilst attempting to flee to a Thai refugee camp, and he subsequently lost his arm to a land mine during his time as a 14-year-old solider. Meeting Tom was the highlight of our stay because he offered a thoughtful and though-provoking presentation about the war. He answered our historical questions, and also our questions about the lasting impact of the war on Cambodia. It was a real honour for him to take the time to guide us. The museum employs a number of former soldiers, like Tom, who were the victims of land mines. I would rate this as the #1 attraction in Siem Reap and would encourage all visitors to go.

Highlight of Siem Reap. This was perhaps the highlight of my entire Southeast Asia backpacking trip. It changed my life! A trip to Siem Reap just seeing the temples is remarkably incomplete. You must make it over here to more fully understand the complexity of its history. It will provide you with near infinite more appreciation! :) I honestly don't understand the poor reviews of this place. First of all, the value is unreal. It is incredibly inexpensive. Forego a coffee or a drink and you can pay for it. The return on the money is INSANE.You get a free guide to walk through the experience with you. You must take the guide! They are the key to understanding all the museum has to offer! :) Our guide, Silo (I'm not sure if that's how you spell it, I'm sorry!) was just remarkable. Though not a veteran, he learned immense amounts about the war from his father. We were able to talk with some of the veterans at the end anyway so it was truly the best of both worlds! It was INCREDIBLE to hear Silo's perspective as a youth in Cambodia ready to turn the country around. It's interesting that all these artifacts are not perfectly preserved as many people are used to when visiting a museum. Perhaps Cambodia is more eager to move on, even forget, the past than we realize. Must must must! Like I said, I don't understand the negative reviews in the slightest. This was the highlight of my trip! Skip a day of temples and make this a priority but be sure to get a guide :)

Definitely worth a visit. A sobering and very worthwhile place for people interested in learning more about the 1970-1999 civil war. Our guide was Moun Sinath, who spoke excellent English and whose stories moved me to tears. The museum was built on a former mine field and has a variety of tanks, arms and a plane. The weapons of war are stark contract to the lush tropical garden they are located in.

Impressive not to miss visit to War Museum Siem Reap. We visited the War Museum in July. First we met the general manager Richard who like us was Dutch and had lived in Amsterdam too. We had a nice conversation about the museum. He was very passionate about his job and the museum. He wants the best for the people that work there. It was great to talk to Richard. The museum is very well maintained. You can follow a route or freely look around. There are a lot of tanks, planes, mines and weapons that were used during the war, to see and you are allowed to touch the weapons if you like. Also there are a lot of photos of the war, the war victims and of the places where they have found the tanks.A young man guided us during our visit. With his stories everything you saw, came alive. He was very young, the youngest guide, we later heard, but he also had already suffered a lot. His stories about the war in Cambodia were very impressive and it made me feel sad. But I am very grateful for this experience to talk to someone that has experienced the war. I think more promotion of this museum would be wise to attract more people. Because I think this museum is a must see for people visiting Siem Reap. Also I would recommend the system to the museum to give people the opportunity to become friends of the museum and support the museum.

So moving. I felt a mix of humbled, shocked and horrified by what was shown to us by our free guide, Cat.
I'm slightly more ashamed at my fellow Westerners' one star reviews on this page. Have you no humanity?

A taste of war. What an eye opener. Very cheap to get in and we got a free English speaking guide to go around with us. The stories that were revealed in that time were unknown to me before and I thought I was quite well read. Some of the tales moved my wife to tears. This has to be a tour that you have to make if you come to Cambodia. Do not miss it. Take a guide and get the stories. We paid it was that worth it.

Better museum than you might expect. I was pleasantly surprised by this visit. It is a "tank orchard", in that tanks, half tracks, howitzers, etc are arranged in an arbor. Some have signs on or near them detailing its manufacture data, who used it in Cambodia's civil war and when, and the circumstances of its discovery or capture. There are also several sheds with photos and interpretive material, as well as shelves of weapons, landlines, uniform pieces and other materiel.

So incredibly moving. We took a tuk tuk ride here and although it's quite far out of town it's well worth a visit.They have a tour guide (it's included in the entrance fee) that takes you around the items there and explains everything in great detail, it's so incredibly moving and we both had a few tears, the man that showed us had been a victim of war and was just the most incredible man, so brave and warm and kind, we took an instant liking to him and felt very humbled by what he had been through.Although sad, we came away with thoughts and feelings that would stay with us forever.Thank you for all that work at the museum and all that you've done in your bravery, you're incredible.

It is a compliation of old rusty army relics! But it is the story told by the guides that smashes you. We had a young guide who lost both his parents in the civil war and he had an impressive story to tell, more about what happened in general than what happened with his family. Still the story is impressive enough and the surroundings of old sovjet tanks but also US, Vietnamese, chinese etc mines show you the sufferings of a civil war which was at the same time a proxy war of the powers of the cold war

Authentic exprience of the nation's struggle against Khmer Rouge. Excellent experience for those who want to dive into Cambodia's horrible past when the nation got under attack by North Vietnam/Russia (and consequently by the US) and the Khmer Rouge/China later. A war between systems for regional influence followed by a barbaric Communist death cult that killed a quarter of the Khmer population. The Museum does a great job in visualizing this dark younger history. Lots of tanks (some still contain remains of the killed crew), heavy guns and light guns - the latter may be handled. Also a Chinese MIG-19 copy in the colors of the Khmer Rouge is parked there. We had a very knowledgeable young guide with fluent English. Don't forget to donate to the landmine victim project on your way out.

Worth a visit . This was a very impactful and emotional experience. The highlight was our guide, whose own personal story was so awe inspiring. It really opened my eyes to the atrocities that the people of Cambodia have experienced. It is worth a visit if you have some free time in Siem Reap.

Another example where you can witness the great tragedy that was inflicted upon Cambodia, dreadful history. Tragic is-just not good enough or powerful a word to describe the inhumanity and abuse put upon the poor folk of this country. Not only were they bombed both day and night and many had to flee their ravaged country villages to live like cave people in the jungles with no food or proper equipment, but their own people abused and tortured and brutally killed so many of their own.... For what ??? They tried to annihilate their own history in some hairbrained attempt to equalise every one....and many of the Khmer Rouge leaders and perpetrators are still very much at large and in powerful positions within the country.This museum like several others here shows you first hand examples and relics from the war. Tragic.

Informative and heartbreaking . Very informative. I came away with a much better understanding of a very confusing and terrible era of history.This museum is a must if visiting Siem Reap.Much thanks to our wonderful and inspiring guide Sinath (I hope I have the name right....also known as "the cat") This gentleman was a wonderful guide ..so informative and a happy disposition. His story is inspirational.

A must see, so raw so real . I have visited a lot of war museums , interactive displays diagrams etc . This is raw , a load of tanks , artillery , rocket launchers , a MiG a helicopter pulled out of the jungle less than 20 yrs ago and put in a field .A load of Russian equipment some ( a lot ) dating back to WWII . Smashed up T51s & T52s . A scary collection of machine guns to pick up.

Fantastic . Fantastic place and a must see in Siem Reap. As a young couple eager to get off the beaten track, we wanted to avoid the National Museum and decided to visit the War Museum. Only 5$ entrance fee but was well worth it, with a free tour guide by a local who was badly affected by the Cambodian troubles. Well worth a visit!

Guide- Very Interesting Life Story. The actual museum exhibits were not the highlight of the visit but listening to the life story of the guide. Remarkable life.You are able to handle the weapons which I found to be in poor taste.

Amazing guide. This was really interesting to see and our guide was incredibly knowledgeable and interesting, giving an appropriate amount of information. I was glad that we did this before the Phare Circus as it helped to understand the show.

A must do history lesson. Visited the war museum today after finding an hour free. It was so very worthwhile and a shame more tourists don't make the trip to the outskirts of town to see this place. There are a good assortment of tanks etc, and many guns which my 11 yr old son found very interesting having only seen pictures before.The highlight however was our guide who took us around the museum and explained all the weapons, and gave us a very detailed and sometimes sad insight into the history of war in Cambodia. He gave us a very personal insight into his life and how he and his friends and family have been affected by the fighting off the past decades beyond the obvious physical injuries. Please everyone go see this museum

Military Graveyard. A collection of destroyed tanks and other artifacts from the last three decades of war of the previous centurary in Cambodia's History. We had a guide (with prosthetics due to land mines) who fought during the Khmer Rouge period and his story's gave a chilling reminder of the dangers of war and the madness of the Pol Pot era of Cambodia. This is the only war museum of this type in Cambodia and is worth a visit while in Siem Reap. A similar experience to the Killing Fields and one leaves feeling the pain and suffering endured by the soldiers and peoples of Cambodia during this sad period of Cambodia's History. This carnage was mostly caused by Cambodians on Cambodians and often involved Family on Family. Some of the tanks still have visual reminders of the people who died in the burned hulks.

The Most Sacred Place in Siem Reap. Siem Reap abounds in temples old and new; yet the War Museum holds a sanctity beyond any of them. Its rusting artifacts of war and fading photographs of victims tell the horror of the thirty years of warfare in Cambodia. There are no skulls no dramatic footage of suffering and pain. Simply the mute testimony of the lives of everyday soldiers who died and of the everyday people who were their victims. The tanks and armored vehicles are not maintained as monuments to valor and glory but as simple reminders of suffering and pain without achievement or reason.Most of the victims of mines and genocide were killed by their fellow Cambodians, but at every stage of the war out side powers -- France, Japan, United States, Russia, China, and Vietnam -- each played a bloody role in different years.Unfortunately printed guides often encourage people to come here to hold the weapons of the past and make outrageous photographs. And every day, that is what happens.We were hardly there more than ten minutes when a van load of young Australians assaulted the museum, each racing to grab a weapon for the silliest photo they could make. They seemed unaware that the vehicles around them still contained the burned shoes and torn uniforms of lives lost in the war.

Battlefield military equipment. An interesting display of battlefield military equipment, tanks and weapons collected from the war. Not much information available but the guides here can give a better insight with stories of their own. Situated 6 km from the the town centre on Route 6 Airport Road, this museum is worth a visit if you need a change from visiting temples.

Trip Highlight. Not a museum so much as a collection of war artifacts. The reason to go is to talk to a tour guide. Our guide was part of these wars and gave a wonderful history of Cambodia, wars and otherwise. Our guide was able to speak in detail as well as tell us the overall historical aspects needed to understand the history in front of us. It started to rain while we were there and our guide let us sit in his office and pepper him with questions. This was a true highlight to our trip.

Confronting and extraordinary . Unfortunately we were there when many screaming students visiting which dampened experience a little, however it was still incredibly moving and thought provoking.Our guide was fantastic ( Sileong) and took us through relics and photos from the atrocities. He shared personal accounts and views which was difficult but refreshing. Well worth your $5 !

Great historical information to feed your kids. Tranquil and surprisingly, fun; The War Museum was a big landmark with many old (and of course, inactive) types of guns, rifles, old bullets, war tanks and information about the Khmer Rouge with pictures from back then. Was definitely inspiring to know about the unfortunate circumstances the Cambodians had to go through.

Inspiring tour guides made this a trip highlight. This is a very humble museum that seeks to tell the story of Cambodia's war-torn history. A number of weapons and war machines are available for view, with an emphasis on the modern day problem of land mines. The attraction, though, is the incredible tour guides. All of them played a role in that history and share their inspiring stories. Mine, a man who called himself Tom, shared the tragic history of Cambodia with grace and passion. I learned so much and for the first time truly felt the challenges the people of Cambodia have faced. There is a small fee (US$5, I think), and it seems very quaint upon arrival. It is absolutely worth your time, however.

interesting. was great.lots of old military vehicles that are in very bad conditions..plenty of guns, land mines..easy walk around..get a guide to tell you stuff. well worth a look very close by about halfway between airport and centre of siem reip
