Tour. A must do , especially with the great guide and former soldier. He shared all his knowledge , scars and life's experiences . It does sadden me to see how humans can be maimed, killed and tortured by there own kind.

Amazing tour guide. We were shown around by Moun Sinath, who seemed like an amazing guy. He was a veteran with all kinds of bullet wounds and stories to tell about the conflict in Cambodia. Very interesting.

Antique Guns & Ammunition . I am happy that I got a chance to hold antique M16 and AK47. There are many war tanker and different types of bombs and ammunition at this War Museum. For entry you need to pay $5 per person. I guess it's worth it. Please don't forget to bring your camera because there are many interesting antique war machine there.

Very Interesting.. This was one of the most interesting things I did while in Cambodia. At the same time, it's quite sad too. But lots of decommissioned tanks etc from the war. Make sure to get a tour guide for it. They are free (but worth giving a tip) and have a lot of great stories about the war that give you a good insight to how horrible it was.

Humbling experience. We asked our tuk-tuk driver to take us to the landmine museum but ended up here anyway (they seem to have a way of making you do what they want you to!) - however we weren't disappointed.The museum is full of old weapons, tanks, 2 aircraft and various models of landmines. There are plaques next to everything explaining what they are. After 5/10 minutes of aimless wondering we were approached and offered a guide - we took this opportunity and the guide, an amputee due to the landmines, talked us around several of the most important exhibits and told us his personal tale, and described what life is like in Cambodia, which was extremely moving.Highly recommended.

Wonderful derelicts. The real heaven for armour modellers - all machines and other pieces are rusted to the core, blown by mines or otherwise shown that they were abandoned in the jungles for decades. Not your average military museum at all!

Make sure you get the guide. This place has so much history, as does the guide who will be happy to show you around for a couple of bucks, before you complain about paying them, remember that's all the income they live off.They will give you an amazing insight into not only the countries history but also their own, and it's well worth it. Very cool place to visit.

Alright!. It was the first place we visited after landing as it was on the way to the hotel. When we got there, there was no tour guide available so we had to take a self tour. Which was a bad start. We checked out the war machines and everything but could not relate to it. Try avoid going after 3-4ish!

Not worth it at all . You pay 5 dollars to walk in a smelly and old place . As for the so they claim is free guide ,he did not move from his place and told me to wait for 20 min and then he left me alone . I am disappointed

A personal insight. On it's own this museum would be ok but wouldn't stand out. What makes this different is that you can choose to be shown around by a guide, someone who is a war veteran themselves or a land mine victim. This museum gives them an opportunity for employment that often they otherwise wouldn't have. They have a unique and in many cases harrowing story to tell which is well worth listening to.

Wasn't worth the $5 entry fee and the ride out to the place. Read good reviews and thought we would give it a try. Was highly disappointed as all they had were rusted armor vehicles and some poor collection of small arms.I guess as some one who has been through military training - they was nothing new, interesting or exciting! It maybe interesting for those served in the Vietnam war or may not have chance to come up close to weapons.

Extensive information on a taboo topic. We were so happy to have stumbled upon this place while exploring different areas of Siem Reap. This was such a nice compliment to different aspects of our travels after already visited the Killing fields and hearing about people injured from UXOs. Our tour guide was former Khmer Rouge whose family was killed by the Khmer Rouge and who was missing a limb from a landmine. He gave us very frank information about How Cambodia has been impacted by the Khmer Rouge, which was nice to be able to discuss such a seemingly taboo subject. There was extensive information about the timeline of the the Khmer Rouge and the military acts. There are massive abandoned weapons from various countries left from jet am and since on display. Bonus for animal lovers: there is a cute, loving kitty on the grounds with a curly tail that likes to make friends with visitors. There is a donation box on the grounds, and is easily accessible for people with mobility challenges.

Memories of a distant, evil time, but worth seeing. Give it an average rating, but I actually like this strange little museum outside Siem Reap. It is mostly a collection of rusty, dusty weapons of war strung out through a shady arbor. Many are small arms and familiar to anyone who was in the war -- AKs, M16s, grenades (all rendered harmless). Many are big -- artillery pieces used by all parties. And a couple once could fly -- a Soviet-made helicopter and a MiG that has seen better days. Still, it was an interesting trip back to the bad old days and I'll do it again.

An experience which could have been better. The collection of war relics, the hand guns and rifles which you are allowed to handle, and the war memorabilia and the photos make for an educational and possibly a sobering experience ... but the lack of any guides or someone to walk you thru the history of the place (even though it was advertised on the ticket) did not help. The 10 dollar entry fee somehow did not feel justified.

A humbling experience. The War Museum is a 20 minute Tuk Tuk drive from Pub Street and has decommissioned tanks, artillery, Chinese fighter jets, rifles and many other examples of mankind's' seemingly endless talent to produce horrific machinery. There is lots of information, including photographs and exhibits to immerse yourself in. The museum is worthy of a visit simply to garner a better understanding of Cambodia's troubled past. There are also veterans you can talk to. One of the more ironic aspects of the experience is the location and setting of the museum, which is a peaceful, silent garden lined with papaya trees. A humbling and worthwhile experience.

Very humbling. Although the site is not large, it certainly had an impact on us. We chose to use one of the local guides and his personal experiences made the whole tour surreal. He was a walking shrapnel magnet and his stories and knowledge made the visit very real. A donation can be given at the end for the upkeep of the site but no pressure is applied to do so. Very worthwhile IMHO.

Definitely worth the visit!!. This was such a moving, authentic view of the tragic history Cambodia has gone through. Our tour guide, Tom, was a war veteran and really brought the experience to life for us. He spoke English very well, was incredibly knowledgable, and was open to sharing his own personal unfortunate story- from being separated from his family at a young age, being forced to fight, losing his arm, and the difficulty finding work afterward. Despite everything, it was so inspiring to hear his positive outlook on life and hope for a peaceful future. It was a heartbreaking, but important educational and cultural experience to understand what the Cambodia people have gone through - definitely check it out!

Worth a visit. After the genocie museum and the killing fiels in Phnom Phen, this makes the whole history-story complete. Talk to the veterans and let them explain their story.... very interesting. The whole area has some guns and tanks etc.

History lesson, worth it.. This museum shows all the kind of artifact of war, guns, tanks, rounds, shells complete with uranium tips still attached ! Unless the fella was pulling me leg but we didn't get to close just in case. Our guide is free, I say free but they do ask for a gratuitie after there tour of which u feel obligue to give them a note. The guides are exservice men or survivors more to the case as they show u there scars. This guide had been shot 9 or 10 times in his life but he had the scars and the shrapnel still under his skin of which we saw ! One of the tanks he showed us had bone and soles of old shoes, of one his comrades still in there, bit grisley really.  Was good to see all the arsenal of war, an education, would recommend.

A must go if you're in Siem Reap. A small but yet very interesting museum. They offer all the visitors a free guided tour around the compound. This guided tour makes all the difference when you visit the museum. The guides are war veterans that participated in the horrifying war that took place in Cambodia. All of them have somehow been hurt and lost limbs. Our guide Tom was injured by a land mine and lost his left arm. To hear his story and being told about the war that took place not even 30 years ago was truly touching. The guided tour is 35+– minutes. Tom took us around the compound showing us different kinds of army vehicles, guns, mines, a built up mine field etc. After the tour you are free to walk around and look at everything yourself. You can even pick up some old guns from the war of you are into that. Even though the visit was great it's not that informative. Beside from what the guide tells you there's not many information signs were you can read yourself. Right now they are building a new, bigger museum including a movie room, more information etc so it will change and become even better soon. In my eyes, definitely worth a visit!

Extremely educational, brought tears to my eyes.. When I arrived to the war museum on a tuk-tuk I didn't know what to expect. Admission was 5$ and comes with a free tour guide, but this was no ordinary tour guide. His name was Tom and he had experienced all the horrors of the Cambodian war/genocide. He lost his arm and his entire family at a very young age. His stories were the most authentic/unfortunate imaginable. I highly recommend going here if you want a first-person account of the tragedies that happened in Cambodia. It was truely heartbreaking but gave me a much greater appreciation for my own life that I am blessed with.

It was heartbreaking and informative. Give this place a go. it paints a rather drab picture and makes you wonder how human beings can do some of the things it shows done to others. that said, it is very informative. Our guide was a man who had lost his hand to a land mine and explained to us in details as to what had happened during the civil war.the monies accumulated go into making the lives of people who lost their limbs in mines a little better.

Moving and powerful. Visiting the Siem Reap war museum was a very sobering and emotional experience. Our tour guide named Tom was excellent! He was full of interesting information and had a very compelling story about his experience with the war. I will never forget his stories and the information he gave us, I can wholeheartedly say it was an unforgettable experience. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys history.

A small but good place full of History. It's a small museum with some old stuff of the war, destroyed tanks, mines, missels and granades to see. It's good to see something about the recent history of Cambodia. You have a free guide that was in the war. It's cheep and a good place to go. Surrounded by trees and shade, not too hot as other places. It's ok!

Hands on experience.. This is a really cool place to go and the guides are free. You can even tamper with the weapons, climb the tanks and equipment, obviously at your own risk. The vehicles and weapons here are in shambles though, but I guess that's the reason you can actually get to hold them and check them out. On the premisses they got a Chinese fighter, a USSR chopper, USSR tanks, and other armored vehicles, different sorts of artillery, assorted small-arms, AK's, m-16's , machine guns, RPG's, assorted other carbines, mines, mortars etc. It's a nice place to spend an hour or so!

Wow, I learned so much. This museum is all outdoors with pavilions that house information. My tour guide was so knowledgable and explained a lot about history that I didn't know. You have so this museum if you visit the city.

Get the free guide!. Fascinating insight into Cambodias past, if you've been to the Killing Fields or any of the other related locations, this place is an important location to help piece together a wider picture of Cambodia's conflict. The guide we had was 'The Cat,' who has an incredible story to share, and all guides have been deeply affected by violence and war (please bear this in mind and be respectful by resisting the urge to pose for pictures with any of the artefacts which include deactivated firearms).

Great visit. Great experience even if you are not into war stuff at all. Entrance fee is $5 and you get a free tour guide (if you want you can just walk around on your own but guide is worth it) who was a war veteran and talked about war history, guns they used, war crimes and interesting facts that only a person who been throught it all could know. Highly recommended!!!!

Understand to history for better future. The guide in this museum gives a very good explanation not only about the machines and war. He was once in the battle field fighting with enemies. The stories behind is saddening. They only ended the war 16 years ago... It is not too long ago and there are still a lot of victims that need help. The least we can do is to donate some money.

A MUST TO SEE.. If you go to Siem Reap, make sure you visit this museum! This place is filled with memorabilia from the strife of this war torn country. The Guides their are all ex soldiers or have been involved in some way or another. The place is full of relics from the wars of the last 30 years.

A must-see even if you're not into War stuffs. War Museum Cambodia wasn't really part of my itinerary when I went to Siem Reap last March because I hate sad stories and Cambodia's history was full of those. Throughout my stay, I directed all my activities to arts and food. But on my last afternoon there, I missed the shuttle bus to the Silk farm so I had to find other options not to waste time in Cambodia therefore, I decided to go to the museum. Despite being hesitant at first, I was glad I did go there. It was a window where you could see snippets of what happened to Cambodia's past.The Catch - Their tour guides are survivors with personal experienced of the war. (though I didn't get the chance to talk to one of them because no one was available when I went there. however, their manager, Richard was kind enough to do the tour instead. I didn't just learn about the stuffs on war but also on so many other things inside Cambodia and the world as he himself is a well-traveled guy.) If you're into war stuffs, I'm pretty sure you'll be amazed on the things displayed there especially the customized and homemade weapons. I, myself was impressed how man's mind work and create horrible things.Wishlist: A video presentation before the tour would be helpful. Just a short clip with a summary of Cambodia's history and what to expect on the tour. (I had this when I was in Ho Chi Minh City and it was helpful)Getting there:From the Night Market, I took a Tuktuk and paid US$5 for the round trip.

War is Hell. If you go here and you should make sure you get one of the guides to talk you through the story of Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge. Cat was our guide and he is a true war veteran with stories of being shot, blown up and even stung to death by wasps and then brought back to life.The story is more important than the actual weapons which is vast.

One of the items on "to do" list. Siam Reap in general has a lot of history. War museum is one of them. Besides given the opportunity to actually touch the weapons and come so close to tanks, fighter gets etc, the history overall is sad. I do recommend you get a tour guide. Note: everything in this museum is very old and not being taken care off.

Worthwhile, interesting & personal. We visited the War Museum today and although a little dubious beforehand, not really a huge fan of museums, i am really glad i took the time to go.Having visited Cambodia before I have visited and read up on the history of the country. Yet today, to be able to stand and talk with someone who lived through it all was a completely different experience, just amazing. That this man has seen the things he has, fought in a horrendous war, been injured and lost limbs and here he is managing to give tours and speak in perfectly good english telling us everything in such detail. There literally are no words.Please pay this museum a visit, with a $5 entrance fee it really is worthwhile. At the end there is a tip box and we wanted to add money to let them know how much we appreciated our experience there. One member of staff came over and said if we wanted we could give our tip to our guide, as we were tipping anyway I was more than happy to hand it straight to him. The thanks he then gave us nearly had me in tears.

Interesting to visit. We had asked to go to the Landmines Museum, but ended up here instead. The free guide will ask for money at the end of the tour, but we were happy to pay a small amount, as the stories he told us were interesting and from his own experiences.Not sure about the uranium bombs that were on display though - especially as our guide had described his wife's death due to uranium bomb poisoning. Maybe he was just having us on about the bombs being uranium, just to see our faces?

One of the best things we did in Cambodia. I've given this such a high rating mainly due to the free guide you get with your $5USD ticket. Our guide had been inducted as a Khmer Rouge solider after they shot his father when he was 14. He gave a real honest account and spoke as if it was the first time he was giving the tour. My husband really enjoyed the fact that you could climb on rusty tanks and touch old weapons, as most museums don't let you go near touching anything.

An interesting discovery in Siem Reap. Depending on which guide you get, an enormous amount can be learnt about the turbulent history of Cambodia. Sok Sophorn was our second guide that we kind of tagged along with as we found him to be more informative than our allocated guide. The museum has an eclectic mix of some pre WW2 to modern day armaments from the USA, China and Russia. Incredibly in interesting

The horrors of war.... Not sure if it's worth the trip, but I liked it. The guide (the cat) told us the story of his life as a victim of the Khmer Rouge and a child soldier. Additionally, the guide provided some information on the small arms and ordinance on display, as well as telling some war stories related to the rusted armor in the museum collection. This is a good way to get perspective on the Cambodian civil war. I didn't visit the landmine museum, which is supposed to be better, but this war museum is more convenient.

A worthwhile visit . This is a good way to hear stories and the history first hand from the people that lived it. The tour is free, and the guide will tell you his personal story which is woven into the history lesson. He is open about his life and experiences and wants you to learn as much as you can and ask as many questions as possible. I really recommend this to anyone wanting to learn from local people about the history of this country.

Brought me to tears.. Went to the museum not knowing more than the basics about the suffering of the Cambodian people. Was assigned a guide, (Mr. Sophorn) which gave us a brief history of the war and atrocities during the 70 - 99 period. Even though Mr. Sophorn give these tours every day, it was clear that he still was haunted by his experiences during this time. I left the museum crying thinking about the horror these people went through.Be sure to leave a big tip, these guys really deserve it.

So worth a vist. This was a good choice but we all felt so down at the end because of the atrocities that the local guide educated us about. The guide is well worth listening to and your heart really goes out to the suffering not only he and his family suffered but what the people also suffered. We found the cambodian,s such lovely people that we all felt for them while for what the went through after learning from the `cat` . This man has more war wounds then you can imagine, sharpnel and loss of a limb but he talks with honesty no malice or hatred, so inspiring. It is,nt a pleasant vist but it is a must ! . You may understand Cambodia better after going here.

I DON'T MIND ADMITTING I CRIED. On one level the museum is a collection of rusty artillary and small arms but on a human level it provides lessons we must never forget. What makes the difference is a wonderful guide who at fourteen years old saw his father shot in front of him and was forced to join the Khymer Rouge. He lost the lower half of his leg to a landmine and was the sole survivor from an infrantry squad of twenty one. He told his story and that of Cambodia with dignity and emotion but never expressed anger or recrimination even when describing the on-going resentment he experiences from some people. He lost his youth, his family and his leg but has learnt excellent English and spends his time describing the terrible period in his country's history. I was moved to tears by his strength and dignity. Dont let the subject matter put you off. We came away proud to have met him and a little wiser.

Quick trip. Old broken down bombed out gutted war machines. A historical tour of the land mines and some info on the civil war. It might differ depending on guide.There are fruit trees \ orchard here. Somewhat somber experience. We did not have time on our short trip to check out the killing fields and land mine museum. This place is on way to airport so enough opportunity to check it out.

Went for the guide . Honestly I was a bit disappointed, the reason being was going to this museum you are supposed to given a free guide that is a war vet which is why I went as I already visited the war museum in Phnom Penh. Anyways arriving there I was looking forward to it (cost me 5$ tuk tuk there and back, and then 5$ for entrance) then the tour began... But with a guy from Holland.. I think he's helping out which is great and he does give you a decent tour but the only reason I went was for the the tour guided by a war veteran, so that was a let down... Make sure you know when the times are that you'll get a war vet guide

The cost of war. We came to Siem Reap from Vietnam and my memories of the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City were fresh. The war museum here is basically just a scrap yard of rusting weaponry; however, I feel it was at least as powerful as the HCMC museum entirely due to the war veterans who lead the free tours. Our guide (nicknamed the crazy guide) told us of having his father killed in front of him, being forced to fight for the Khmer Rouge, and losing his leg to a land mine. He did so with no political bias (unlike at Vietnam's museum), and seemingly no malice toward the super powers Cambodia has so often been caught between. It was clear his motivation was to tell as many people as possible about the true costs of war and to promote peace.If you come, do not turn down the offer of a free tour guide. We almost did and he was really the only reason to visit.

Great for a couple hours. New very little about the Khmer Rouge days, but found the museum and the photographs of great interest. Our guide was very knowledgeable which of course gives you a true insight on how things were between 1975 and 1979 in Cambodia when all the killings took place. Having made the visit I am wanting to read more on how these senseless killings were allowed to continue for so long.

It's all down to the guide.. I've read the mixed reviews on this place and I would say, yes there are lots of weapons and such (it is a museum after all) however it's well worth a visit. The guide is what made it for us "The Cat" as he is called, due to surviving man war wounds. We didn't know a great deal about this civil war and so found it both interesting and disturbing especially since it wasn't that long ago that it all happened. If you have the time and are interested in finding out about Cambodian history take the time and take a tuk tuk towards the airport (only 10mins or so) and $5 and spend 1/2hr or hour depending on your interest.

Weapons, weapons and more weapons.... If you're interested in different weapons this is the place. Spent a few hours here checking out the collection. You can take photos holding rifles, sitting in artillery and other fun stuff. Learn about land mines from the guides. It's something a little different and interesting.

Basic museum but very moving. Use the tour guide service offered by a former member of the army for a very personal and moving account of the impact of warfare and, in particular, land mines. Take money for tips and donations.

Simple yet meaningful. Rusty open air display of military vehicles and weapons even a small fake minefield. To some it may be expensive and not worth their $5 entrance fee but it is a great introduction for visitors to know a lot of the war that is happening in Cambodia. Pictures of war would bring you back to the time where it was just death and killing in their country at that time. For those who wish to have a tour guide, they do have it and is free of charge.
war museum simple. simple but you will know the summary of Kampuchea civil war. Interesting for a first timer like us. fully recommended for those who hate wars..,

Rusty war junk in a yard. Open air display of rusty vintage military hardware, some faded photos, some even more rusty small arms and grenades, a small fake minefield, and that's it, half an hour and 5 $ lost forever!

Introduction to Killing Fields. Soviet era land mines, tanks. artillery, torn lives and body parts... In all this sadness you learn all about yesterday and today of South Asian Pacific and its politics. It is not just Cambodia, there is more to digest about Thailand, Vietnam, Russia, China etc. I would highly recommend to enquire for a tour guide at the entrance. Tour guide is free. And you can tip him following the tour. Our guide was fantastic - a war veteran with one leg.

Amazingly Sad History. Really interesting and amazingly sad history, that really isn't that so long ago!!!The guide who was a war veteran and extremely proud man was very emotional whilst telling the history of his country.Very small outdoor museum with old tanks and guns, an old helicopter and plane that were used during the war and off course the infamous land mines, that was really brought to the worlds attention by the late Princess Diana.Worth a visit if you like your history
War remains. The war remains of wrecked military as you can feel how was the people in Cambodia suffered during the war. Plus you will get free guide from the former soldiers.

Interesting experience. I didn't know what to expect with the museum but thought i would try it. The museum is open air and has a number of old tanks and a helicopter and a mig jet to look at. You get a free guide on arrival and this is what makes the experience. Whilst showing us mines and weapons our guide told us his story of the conflicts and seeing his own father shot and being forced to fight from the age of 14 until he lost his leg. His story was amazing and one I will not forget.

An Eye Opener. This is a pretty basic outdoor museum with a collection of war remains from the local area - it's real!It made 'stuff' that we had only read about or seen on the news starkly real - especially as our guide had been in the war against Pol Pots army, and had the bullet wounds and missing leg to talk about it!Old tanks, artillery, a vast array of guns to look at and hold, and landmines to see and described ( and still a huge issue in Cambodia today!). A gratuity to the guide is appreciated as a thank you at the end. But you are then also free to walk around at your leisure

A must see. A bit of Cambodia's most recent history. Take one day from the temple tours and go visit this place! The tour guides are former soldiers, it couldnt be more real and touching. Great people, sad past.

factual. The good thing about this small outdoor museum is that the guide says he is an original fighter who joined the fight at the age of 11. His stories along with the exhibits make the whole thing worthwhile even though you are left with the impression that some things are a little exaggerated to improve the end of tour tip.

Dont think about missing!. Defiantly an eye opener.Haunting and important.The things that we never knew about the Vietnam and Cambodian war are just staggering.It is not just important for visitors to see, but for the world and future generations to understand so that we fight this sort of thing in the future.

Rip-Off. Not lucky for me to visit So Ponn is the guide not good. Seriously question if the guide had been Khmer Rogue as he claimed. His dates didn't line up (he said he was captured by the KR at age 19 in 1975, but based on his current age claim he had to be 14 then), and he sat down at the end of the tour, made a big show of rubbing and showing me his artificial leg, which he said was lost by a landmine and family live with the poverty. He certainly had an artificial leg, but his entire tour and demeanor made me feel as thou he was only after my money, reminding me to leave a donation again and again $20 that is very bad thing I met, even thou I paid $5 to get in. None of it rung true, although they did have a collection of rusty tanks and weapons is not good.

Worth a visit. The guide who showed us around himself was a victim of the civil war.We did not realize that he lost one of his legs because of a mine and lost one of his eyes during combat until he tole us. having a survivor-guide gave a personal touch to the whole visit

Important place to visit. Most Americans over the age of about forty know a bit about the Vietnam War, but the events of the Cambodian involvement are largely unknown. Our guide was a former soldier and he explained in great detail how Cambodia was pulled into the Vietnam War due to strategic proximity. The displays are outside and rather pared down. The museum makes no attempt to promote war or brag about their role in the conflicts of the past forty years. The guide provided a clear and factual narrative and answered our few questions about the political climate. Much time was devoted to the problem of landmines and there is an extensive display of the types of landmines used from the Vietnam War to the war with the Khmer Rouge. Our visit was sobering and insightful, an important revelation about contemporary Cambodia after days in the Angkor Wat temples.If you visit, be sure to tip the guide well. They earn it and their work there at the museum is important.

Very moving. Your $5 entry fee allows you to have a free guide which you should def take up as the exhibits take on a completely different view when told through their stories. Our guide had become a boy soldier at the age of 14 until 24, and had lost a number of his family due to the war. Although most of us are aware of the 4 years from 1975, I was shocked to see how much of the weapons were still in use until 1999, and it also gives you an idea of the scale of the cost to the Cambodian people which still owes £100million to Russia and still has 1 million land mines to clear.The kids enjoyed playing on the weapons and holding the guns but were def more aware of the less glamourous side to war by the time we had finished, very glad we took the time to visit here. Please do and ensure that you donate to support them.

So important! Soun was a great guide! . I think everyone should go here. It is so important to ask for a free guide so you can learn about the history behind the machines. Our guide was Soun, a former child soldier and his story was so strong and sad. It had a huge impact on me and I have cried and thought a lot abot Soun and cambodian people who has suffered the war. Please go here! It will change your life. And donate if you can!

Interesting History. A must see if in SR., especially if your a tourist looking for military history in Cambodia. Probably interest most people only downside is the sad human cost of war graphically depicted in certain areas and some of the true stories told by some wonderful ex soldiers who tell their personal stories and it still pains them to do so. A close up look and hands on experience with all sorts of weaponry and all types of transport. Good afternoon outing to do this and the Silk Farm as close together a short way from town, approx 20-30 mins by tuk tuk from town centre.

Interesting to see, only 5$USD entry. Did this on the way back from the Silk Farm.Many old relics including MiG. Old disused weapons also present, my son loved it and had a Rambo moment. Did not use any of the local guides but heard some talking to other groups, very good english. If you have an hour to fill and interested in modern Khumer Rogue military history then not a bad stop.

"HANDS ON EXPERIENCE". We found this on our last day in Seam Reap. Its only a few dollars for a walk round. Loads of tanks, anti aircraft and loads of weapons you can pick up and handle and I mean loads. We took a few Rambo shots with the machines guns, one in each hand and had a sit in the tanks and seats on an anti aircraft gun. Cool

Tour guide service is great. With the purchase of the entrance ticket, you're entitled to request for a tour guide for the museum. Whom will walk you through the exhibits and gives you a background of wars that has happened in the modern history of The Kingdom of Cambodia.

A must visit.. This is our second visit to the war museum , as now they have veteran guides who can relay in good English the horrors of their destroyed youth.If you want to understand Cambodia this visit is of paramount importance.$ 5 entry fee, & for a small tip a veteran will tell you his life story in an interesting & informative way.

The tour guide was great.. This place is a little way out from the centre so make sure your Tuk Tuk waits for you otherwise it's a long walk home. The price seems fair when you go in and the tour guide is free. Our guide was amazing. Especially his personal story that he's willing to share with you and definitely brought a tear to my eye. These guys don't get paid to do this the government takes all the money,so your tips help them out. It's got some really good remnants of vehicles and weapons from the war to see and as I said the guide will make you feel more of a connection with them than if you just walked round.

Amazing stories. We cycled from the centre of town up to the museum which was an easy ~25 min ride. Entry is $5 and make sure you get a guide; without a guide the 'museum' is just some old equipment and the odd photograph. Our guide had very good english and shared his experience from the khmer rouge and as a soldier, even where he was blown up by a landmine and lost one of his legs. A truly emotional visit worth more than money can buy.They are also happy for you to take photos with guns, the helicopter and climb onto the tanks. A worthwhile experience.

Reminder of the war horrors here. This museum is a collection of military pieces which were blown up in the jungle and then hauled to this location for display many years later. You can handle mortars, land mines and small arms, including the infamous AK 47. An English speaking guide is available at no extra cost. Ours was a one legged veteran of the civil war who had been shot 10 times over the course of the war and subsequent Vietnamese occupation. It was very interesting to get hits story and background. Of course he wanted a tip at the end, and I gave him $5 which he seemed happy with. Make sure that whatever transport you have taken there waits for you, since it is a little off the beaten track.

Get a guide. I walked in thinking I can just read the information off the board against each display however I highly suggest you get a guide. There are a number of free guides at the gate who are war veterans. The displays are basically just a range of tanks, artillery and land mines etc. What makes it interesting is the guide explaining how each weapon was used and also giving their account of their own personal experience. I tagged on to a small group who had a guide and had a much better experience hence the suggestion.

Living historie. Me and my 2 friends visited the war museum today. It was really impressive. Al the tour guides are war veteranes. Because they fought in the war they are like living history. The stories you know come to life. The tour guides speak pretty good english and are really kind. The 5 dollar entrance encludes a tour guide. They wont ask you for a tip or anything. We did give our guide a tip because we were impressed by his story. If you have a free hour go to the museum and learn more about the tragic history of this beautiful country.

Interesting. This visit was not planned. One afternoon we found ourselves with nothing much to do. One of our sons suggested that we go and have a look. We are so thank full that we did. The Tour Guide had lost a leg on a landmine. Once again to hear stories from someone who has lived what they are talking about, has a very deep impact.It was a informative way to spend an afternoon

Interesting but you need a guide. We were looking for something informative in Siem Reap, for the teenagers in our group to start to understand the history of the country. This seemed to be the best thing we could find.It was an interesting hour or so, but I wouldn't do it without one of the free guides. Our guy was a former Khmer Rouge soldier who had lost a leg due to a landmine - a powerful story which enhanced our visit there and made all the weaponry seem more real and brutal.He talked about Cambodian history for a little while and also told us his story. Then left us alone to wander among the old tanks and machinery and to look at the landmine and gun displays.If you've done the temples and have exhausted all the markets, it would be worth checking out
Displays things used to maim and kill people.. $3 ride from town. Make sure you talk to a free guide who will tell you their experiences of being blown up.

Must see. Easily the best non-temple attraction we visited during our stay in Siem Reap. Well-worth the $5 and personally we wished we'd forgone the National Museum and just spent more time at the War museum. A war veteran is your guide through the displays which enables you to ask questions of their experiences and the devasting impact the Khmer Rouge had, and still has, on the Cambodian people. Our guide was excellent and provided genuine discourse that was impassioned with ever-present raw emotion. This is a must see for anyone who visits Siem Reap. I have no interest in weapons, tanks etc, but the stories are what made this visit a real eye-opener.

Interesting but could be so much better.. We were disappointed with this museum. There were no 'free' local guides available while we were there, so we walked around by ourselves. No information about the Cambodian War, just details of the machinery. We were expecting to be here several hours but walked around in 30mins. My boys did enjoy looking at all the guns and holding them. It could be such a great museum with a bit of up grading and a few more tour guides.

A powerful museum. Our family visited the War Museum on the recommendation of another friend and we were not disappointed. Our guide had fought in the war in Cambodia and had lost his leg in a land mine accident and so his account of life in Cambodia under the rule of the Khmer Rogue was moving. There are plenty of artifacts to see and even touch. My 6 and 11 year old were captivated by what they saw and heard as was I. Take the time to stop by this hidden gem; you won't be disappointed!

Touching. I didn't expect a casual tour ended up as a very heartbreaking, eye opening and touching tour.Important for you to go through this museum with a guide. They provide for free, war veterans, who can talk you through the history first hand. I felt like watching a live documentary listening to his story and all the objects there came to live and meaningful suddenly. You will come out grateful of not living through the atrocities of war.Do tip the guide, as veterans many of them lost leg and or sight so not having other options of work.
Use the guide. This place has relics left over from the war and the Khmer Rouge. Guides are available for free and you need to use them. Much better than doing self guided.

A moving experience .... We came in expecting to liesurely look at an 'arsenal' of tanks, guns, bazookas and a whole array of military equipment. But we were unprepared for the humbling story of our war veteran guide who had lived through the horrors of the 35-year conflict of this great and resilient country.His stories of true-to-life events struck a cord in all of us ... you should visit and talk with the war veterans there. Nothing compares.Am really glad we did visit.

Eye opening experience. I agree with other reviews by saying that it is a bit small and not too many artifacts, but I have never had the experience of being able to come so close to real war objects. My boyfriend is interested in military history and guns, and was able to pick up and hold several real guns. You could walk up to the old tanks, helicopters, and pretty much spend as much time as you wanted.The tour was given by an ex soldier, and while the f-word was dropped several times, I can't imagine how I would emerge from dealing with his experiences, especially when he was so young. The tour was very eye opening, and I am very happy that we spent time with him. His english, french, japanese, (he kept switching!) was very easy to understand, and he didn't stand over us, but let us spend time alone.Very worth the experience.

Very Interestig. I've been here a few times with groups and have found this is one of the places the makes like to come best. They can get up close to a helicopter, tanks ect and handle the weapons ect without getting hurt. The guides are wonderful and explain the history of the war in great detail. They are very passionate to tell their stories in the hope these atrocities never happen again. The guides have all suffered loss of limbs and injuries so know first hand what happened. Some of the stories will leave you feeling absolutely gutted! Great respect for them and their honesty. Highly recommend a visit here if your in Siem Reip.

The War Museum Cambodia/Siem Reap. If you are in Siem Reap, you need to go for a visit because it will wakeyou up and pray and hope that there will be no more useless wars in the world...yes, it tells you what you need to know abour horrors of war.

A reminder of civil war in Cambodia. We visited this museum whilst in Siem Reap. There are many exhibits laying in an area which is easy to get around. There are many exhibits of the guns and tanks which were captured during and after the war, but the "sheds" contained many photos and detail of the mines and guns used in the war and this information was very interesting. This site has a number of "old soldiers) who, for a small fee, will guide you round the site. Well worth a short visit.
Well worth the $5 admission. We walked the War Museum Cambodia, well worth thwe visit, bring a camera, take your time to talk to the locals - well worth the visit

Entertaining Guide. Not sure if he was really in the war or not (how can you ever be sure) but regardless his English was good and his stories were also great. He was missing a leg and had several scars from land mines, bullets, bazooka fire. That was his story....true or not???? Well worth the $5 admission and hopefully engages your mind to learn more about the war atrocities.

Having fun to take picture holding various weapons... Very nice place to visit. Lack of signboard/information board, some areas designed as mock land mine field. with actual display of ruin artifacts of tank, aeroplane, warfields and etc. The best part there are lots of guns display at some huts and visitor can free to take it for photo shooting purpose.

Interesting but..... With 5 USD per person entrance fee, we didn't expect much.There are lots of old and damaged armored vehicle, a helicopter, and a jet fighter. You can hold old machine guns and RPGs.We decided to have a guide and we got Mr. Vanna. He's friendly, talkative, informative....overly informative most of the time. He explained Cambodia's modern history especially his experience with Khmer Rouge and his service in the Cambodian Army. I enjoyed his service though it would be nicer if he's a bit less enthusiastic and let us absorb the information he tells us and sink into the atmosphere. Also I would appreciate if he decided to cooperate less F word in his story. I like the knowledge about how different kind of mines work but the rest are just so so. You wouldn't miss anything if you didn't visit this place.

Moving Experience. The War Museum is a collection of guns, mines, tanks, aircraft, photographs of war time. What makes this such a moving experience is the tour guide - reliving their personal experiences under Poll Pott. This is a very different experience from the temples, countryside but I believe an important experience to understand the travesties the Khmer people experienced.

Great tour! Even more amazing tour guide!. The tour guide, Suon, was the highlight of the museum. Being someone who was actually involved in the war, he could share a heartbreaking and detailed history of Cambodia's troubled past. He was so informative and sweet and his English was great too! For only $5 dollars it's definitely worth your time!
A hidden gem. Not very well publicised but what a surprise. A huge range of ordinance which can be touched and intersting guides.

This is a complete waste of time.. I went with full anticipation expecting something along the lines of the Saigon and Hanoi war museums and the marvelous one in Dien Bien Phu where the French were defeated. All of which are excellent and housed in a proper buildings with several floors and a huge diversity of information beautifully presented.This is nothing like that. It's a wide open field full of rusted old tanks and artillery guns. Running along next to it are shanty style sheds full of bombs and mines with just a few photgraphs. I walked through in five minutes and headed out to the airport an hour early as I was expecting to spend some time there. A complete and utter waste of time. :(

Worth it! . It was a short visit, you only really need an hour. There is a free tour guide and you should take that otherwise the tour will just be a waste of time. We were taken around by a war veteran who had good parents killed by the kyhmer rouge when he was a child. We learnt a lot about the history of Cambodia from probably the best source. You will end up tipping the guide.

Sobering but a must. We came here as we had an afternoon to spare before our trips and it was well worth it. It is about 15 mins in a tuk tuk from the centre of siem Reap and about £4 each in. There are free ex soldiers to guide you and I urge you to take up the offer. We had an ex Kymer soldier Sun and his story (as he guided you) as a brain washed child soldier was heart breaking, for both sides of this conflict. There are plenty of rusty old tanks, launchers, mines, etc which in themselves are nothing spectacular but combined with the guide makes it really hit home the atocities of the Pol Pot regime. You apparently have the opportunity to hold decommisioned gunbs etc at the end but after the stories we heard from Sun, did not seem appropriate.

Understand more Cambodia, not only temples!. We went to the war museum by bike USD1,00 and paid the ticket o the museum is only USD5,00, really cheap comparing to other attractions in Siem Reap and you have free tour included guided by a veteran of the war that will explain better his experience during the battle. We have lucky to get Sun (veteran from Khmer Rouge side), beside the atrocities caused by Khmer Rouge in Camboja, we could understand his story, the way he had to survive the war against the other side and also inside his own side. He has a very sad story, we were touched and we do recommend this visit to understand better this amazing country.

So many ways to maim and kill.. This is one of those places where you have visit to get the full story of Cambodia's recent past. A short tuk tuk ride and a tour round here with a guide from the museum, will bring to life the stories of the hell that was Pol Pot and his regime. The numerous methods man created to kill his fellow man is so bad it does make you question mankind. However, get in touch with this guide we had Bikhour@gmail.com and he will bring a smile to you after all the doom and gloom on display here. The rusting remnants of conflicts past along with the many weapons and mines are countered with the many photographs on display. the full narrative on display can be a bit heavy for a holiday, but I urge you to visit this museum and to see the lasting damage land mines are still doing to this day.

Worth a look. Good place to go and find out a little about the conflicts Cambodia has been involved in. Only a15 minute tuk tuk journey from town. Admission of $5 will include a very informative guide that was involved in the war. Together it took a little over an hour to go through the exhibits and then I was left to go around on my own.

Educational. The fighting around siem reap only ceased 20 years ago. The museum is full of rusty military vehicles, helicopters, guns etc which is the norm for these types of museums.What I didn't expect was my guide was a disabled ex soldier who operated some of this machinery and was part of the action.He spoke of how family members were "Enlisted" by raiding parties by both sides and fought against each other. He spoke about the transition from villager to soldier and then the ongoing struggle to fit back into the Cambodian lifestyle with a disability.He is one of many many.Cambodia is a truly wonderful experience for all the senses.

Touching, must visit!. We visited the war museum on our travels today in Siem Reap. When we arrived it was 5$ for the entrance fee. At first seeing the outside we didn't think the visit would be what it was compared to when we left. We was offered a free guide to take us round, which we would advise getting! Our tour guide was Wanna. He spoke very good English and told us some very emotional stories about he history and some of the things the veterans went through. It was touching and gave us as young travels a huge insight into things that we never knew happened. We would recommend visiting. The machinery/guns are rusty however this adds to the effect and shows they was used in the war. If you get a tour guide make sure you tip them, money goes to them & their families not the government.Thank you for a great day out!

Worthwhile visit - great value. The best thing about this museum is each group that arrives gets a free personal guide who has fought in the war. My guides name was Bik Houre as far as i can remember and his english was perfect. He started off by giving me the background to the wars cambodia recently fought in and then showed me the various weapons, mines, tanks etc used by both sides. The guide himself had his leg amputated from stepping on a mine. You can learn alot about Cambodia's history from the guide for a small entrance fee of $5 it was one of my highlights of siem reap

aged and rusty battle relics but great for military enthusiasts. interesting collection but many of the vehicles are rusting away they need to be preserved ... it does make it authentic though ... what makes it unique is that the tour guide actually lived through the wars with the scars to prove it... the gun and anti personnel mine collection are also top notch. Try and engage the guide to hear his stories and appreciate the exhibit more
The best War Museum ever. A must for everyone to speak to a local who was in the conflict and here the true history of Cambodia, the guns and war relics are top class

Nice collection but bit depressing. The place contains all relevant information about the cambodian wars but the thing which i personally didn't like was the overall impact. It gives you a depressing feeling. Its just a personal opinion and if you really like to see war related things, its the best place.

OK ... . A $2 tuk-tuk ride from Siem Reap gets you to this open-air museum.The entrance fee at the time of writing was $5 pp - which is a little high given the very poor quality of the exhibits. The quality of the free guide is the only thing that gives this attraction any merit. The attractions themselves are uncared for, rusty and have definitely seen better days (or even better years!). The guide we had was OK. He was an ex-Khmer Rouge soldier who had lived through the '75 revolution and then continued fighting from Thailand after the Vietnamese ousted Pol Pot in 1978. The standard of English was passable but not great which weakened what was obviously an otherwise harrowing and interesting story. The ex Khmer Rouge soldiers tend to paint themselves as victims in cambodia's history rather than taking responsibility for the atrocities perpetrated by them. As such, bear in mind what information you get while it may be factually correct is also biased - perpetrating the view of the Khmer soldiers as a brain washed group of "innocents", not entirely responsible for their actions. A view I certainly struggled with having previously visited S-21 & the killing fields of Phnom Penh.

wee worth a visit. Got to be honest we had a bit of spare time left in siem reap and we decided to visit this museum i am so glad we, did .a few dollars to get in and if you want one of the ex soldiers will walk you round and tell you there story .we picked a man by the name of SUON the crazy man as the others called him he brought a sad story to life how he joined the kymer roughe what happened to his family and the terrible things that went on in cambodia and how he lost his leg .a few guns rusty tanks a plane and a great story well worth a few dollars

Crash course in recent Cambodian history. The museum does not require too much time to visit, but you can learn a lot about recent Cambodia by seeing what's here. I was surprised by the range of time the hardware came from, and from where it was sourced. To go deeper I would strongly suggest a guide. There is not much explanation about the underlying historical events - I was told this is part of Cambodian culture to allow each side to "save face".

Interesting exhibits and first hand encounters. We visited the War Museum during our second day in Siem Riep for something to. We weren't expecting a whole lot, but we were pleasantly surprised. We were asked if we would like a free guided tour with an army veteran. He gave us first hand stories of his time in the army and what he saw during the Khmer Rogue Regime. Some of his stories were horrific and a big eye opener in terms of what i understood about the Khmer Rogue. I cant remember the guides name but his english was great and he was truly passionate about what he was talking about. At one stage he almost brought us and himself to tears recounting a story about how the mothers and children were treated during the regime.

Fantastic. I thought this would be boring, but our guide, a war veteran, made it interesting, as he was able to add the personal touch of telling us his sad story. Worth taking a tuk tuk out there (not far from town)

Very informative and moving visit.. Vanna was our guide. He provided us with a very personal account of his experiences during the war as well as information on the horrific tactics used by the Khmer Rouge. Exceptional guide with unimaginable stories. Very good English too.

A must visit place if you want to understand the human aspect of war in Cambodia. Cambodian War Museum is located outside of the city centre, so be prepared for a little longer tuk tuk ride than usual. If you just go there to wander among the exhibits, you are not going to learn much from this visit, as the most educational element is a guided tour, performed by Cambodian army veteran, which is free of charge and is truly a highlight of the visit. Ex-soldiers will tell you personal stories of fights against the Khmer Rogue and about the life of landmine victims, which most of them belong to. For us, it was a truly emotional experience and a very educational one. On top of this, this is one of those museums, where most of the exhibits don't have "do not touch signs", so you can hold and take a picture with arms like AK-47 Kalashnikov, M16, grenade launchers or RPGs.

Veteran war. It was a very quiet place, too quiet for such a nice place.You learn so much about all the deadly weapons (although mostly rusty) used during the war.For people like me who never actually see and hold M16 and AK47, it is really quite an excitement. And to make it more interesting, I was guided by free guide who turned out to be war veteran who lost his leg during the war.Since it's located near airport, I visited this nice place for an hour and jumped back onto my tuktuk who took me to airport.I would recommend you guys to try and to there.

Very interesting and not to be missed.. Unlike any museum I have ever been to! We wondered where our tuk tuk driver was taking us to as it is not in a touristy area (a dollar from Angkor Miracle hotel), along a dusty lane. An open air museum which we found to be very atmospheric. Such peaceful grounds housing such horrific memories of Cambdia's troubled past.Excellent guide with personal experience of the war. VERY interesting with good English.Highly recommend a visit here.The fee is nominal - would happily have paid more.

Rusty chars and guns. We arrived at the museum and were welcomed by old military personnel.We visited the place and saw rusty planes and chars. We saw old guns and munitions. We saw old mines. We saw the pictures of dead people. Pictures of war, desolation. We saw pictures of mutilated people because mines were everywhere. We were well aware of the terrible Red Khmer period and its atrocities. We read a few books about Pol Pot's regime and the terrible period following his regime.I just wish this museum would also bring an education approach "Never Again" and would just talk also about the few people who were judged and sentenced (maybe a few chair at the end of the visit with a 15mins movie about the end of the war and about The Hague trial and recent Phnom Penh verdict). We should have left this place conscious of the horror of that war but also with a hope that people are remembered what happen and educated so it cannot happen again. And unfortunately, this is not the case.In the end, this visit was just gross.

A must visit. A real thought-provoking museum where the guide will give you an insight into their own lives and their personal tragedies. Extremely moving. Will probably take about an hour to visit. Lots of historical information about Cambodia's past presented in a unique and interactive way.

Very interesting . Just got back from a tour of the war museum outside Siem Reap. Was definitely worthwhile. Our guide Vanna had a very good knowledge of everything on display. I recommend it if you're truly interested in the history of Cambodia.

A place not to miss. We travelled to many war museums around Vietnam and Cambodia but to actually be shown around the museum by Suon was amazing. If u go make sure u take the free opportunity to be shown around by a guide. Their stories are heartbreaking and deliver a fascinating insight into the history of Cambodia. Definitely worth our time and $5 entry fee!

Don't miss this place. Make sure you take a short tuk tuk ride just out of Siem Reap to visit this place. Tickets are $5 and war veterans are on hand to show you around and provide a history lesson at no extra cost (tips are appreciated)! All the old tanks and weapons are on display and there is even a helicopter and jet to look at too. I'm not a military history buff but I still enjoyed this tour, well worth a visit!

Very moving with amputee tour guide. This museum houses a collection of tanks, artillery shells, and land mines but the real value is your tour guide, a victim of the war. Ours had his leg amputated at age 18 in a land mine explosion. Very moving photographs. If you want to know more about what it felt like to be in the war, go.
Un tuffo in una delle più grandi tragedie del XX secolo. If you want to put salt on your trip you can't lose this place! ask for Mr Moun as your guide, you won't be disappointed!

Mr. Leng Vanna is an amazing war survivor!. My wife and I visited the war museum in Siem Reap October 23, 2014 and were lucky to have Mr. Leng Vanna as our guide. He shared information about the war that only a survivor could know. The stories were haunting, chilling, and provided insight about the horrendous civil war that affected everyone in this country of 40 million people. His English is excellent. His knowledge of the weapons and mines was very detailed and informative. Perhaps most surprising is his ability to laugh and make jokes after going through so much stress and trauma. We would highly recommend anyone visiting the war museum to ask for specifically for Mr. Leng Vanna.

Sad and scary. It had some old tanks and weapons on exhibit. A main issue is the sad and scary landmines and what they had done to the people there. My guide was a victim with one of his legs blown off.

Visit if you can - we really enjoyed. We spent around 2 hours here and really enjoyed it. Entry to the museum is USD$5.00 per person, there are free guides that escort you around and explain the exhibits to you (please remember to tip at the end of the tour as a token of your respect as it is much appreciated). Our guide was Suon one of the veterans and he was fantastic, it was truly heartbreaking to hear his own personal experiences and tragedies of what he has been through and his time in the Khmer Rouge , he himself is a survivor of losing a limb on a landmine, my two boys (Mr 15 and Mr 8), were fascinated with the stories and were asking him lots of questions about everything he showed us, and he was more than happy to share and explain things in more detail. The boys got to see a lot of old war artefacts, like landmines, grenades, bombs, missiles, guns (they even got to hold one), tanks, trucks and helicopters. Well worth a visit.

Amazjng. I am a history buff and particularly interested in military history. I found this museum unexpectedly interesting. Unlike many museums show pristine examples of armaments, tanks etc., this museum has battlefield relics many of which are horribly disfigured by the large explosions. It hammers home be across abuse of war.The young man who served as our guide had lost an arm. After the tour, I ask him how he lost his arm. He said his parents were farmers who after the war salvaged for explosives to make money. One day a bomb went off killing his parents, sister and amputating his arm. Truly amazing. So sad.

well worth the visit. The museum was very interesting and well worth the $5 entry charge. the guides are free and well worth using them as their information on the history of the killing fields was riveting.

A very worthwhile activity . I'm happy my fiancé and I had the chance to visit the war museum. With the guides who are war veteran and who survived through the extreme brutality of war, the experience felt very real. The museum and especially their war vet guides should be constant reminders that never again should atrocities such as what happened to Cambodia ever occur again.....

A guide makes it worthwhile. Upon arrival, you will be offered the free services of a guide (tipping is encouraged). Take the guide. Without the personal story of our guide, the outdoor museum would not have been worthwhile. With one, it was fascinating. The guides are, I believe, all former soldiers or otherwise affected by the Khmer Rouge. Without their insight and experiences, you will wander somewhat aimlessly through a field of old army tanks, see several displays of weapons and look at a few photo collages.

Great insight into Cambodia. A very reasonable $5 entrance fee gets you in an a free guide to talk you through the exhibits. The real value is in the discussions with the guides, who have lived experiences they share with you. Could not recommend highly enough as a way of getting insight into Cambodia's recent past.

Eye-Opening and Informative. My wife and I visited the Cambodia War Museum during a trip to Seim Reap in early October. The museum is off Airport Road - 900 meters down a nondescript side road - about halfway between the city and the airport. Admission is $5. The museum includes examples of mines, mortars, guns, artillery, tanks, planes, vehicles, and other weaponry from the Cambodian civil war. Our guide, Moun (included with price of admission), was informative and helpful, providing a description of the items on display and sharing stories from his years fighting agianst the Khmer Rouge. He shared a few brief stories about his wounds, including a leg lost to a land mine. I would suggest allowing approximately 1 hour for a visit - perhaps more if one has a strong interest in military equipment. Be advised that this museum is entirely outdoors so it's not a place to consider if one wants to be out of the weather.

Vanna made it worth!. Vanna explained everything very patiently about the conflict occurred in Cambodia. He also shared his own experience with us. Was great to hear from a person who in fact participated in such complicated time.The museum still preserve the weapons and war machines. Really shocking to see what the cambodians passed through! Khmer Rouge explained in photos and artifacts and more important the guides took part in to this conflict!After the tour I talked with Vanna for a good time and I learned a lot from him! I will always remember his life story! Thank you Vanna! Ah and one thing I cannot erase from my mind: ADIDAS!

A good insight into a troubled past.. While the exhibits are basic and a little rusty the experience was truly heartbreaking for me as my guide took me through the trying times under the Khymer Rouge and his own personal tragedies. One wonders how mankind can be so cruel to each other. After visiting this museum I fully understood why the majority of the people of the Cambodian Nation are so young. If you take the opportunity head out in a tuk tuk, $6 return from Central Siem Reap (the driver will wait for you and take you home). The free guides are marvelous ambassadors for the emerging Cambodian nation. Please be generous with your tip as a token of your respect for what they have been through in their troubled past.

Unique weapons, landmines and more. We didnt plan to visit the war museum but our local driver who recommand us to go there. The meseum is small. We paid $5 for admission. There are some weapons shown which all used during the war. If you want to learn more about the history of Cambodia and Khmer Rouge, it is worth to go.

Must visit!. The War museum was an eye opening and an overwhelming experience. The tour guide Mr. Wanna was an ex- army soldier who had first hand combat experience during the Khmer Rouge years. The museum itself has worn down weaponry from the war years and the tour guide did an excellent job of briefing us. Should be on your list if visiting Siem Reap. 5$ entry fee.

A must see!. For a $3 tuk tuk fare (each way) it is a bargain to pay for such an interesting place. We paid $5 each for admission and we're greeted by Vanna who offered to show us around and give us his history with the Khmer Rouge. He was very informative and had great English. He was happy to answer questions and give his life stories and experiences. This should be a must see if you come to Siem Reap. I cannot thank him enough!There are many of the weapons used including guns, landmines, and grenades of all types. There are also many pictures from the genocide, the landmine victims, and those trying to find the mines. There are also the many machines used in the war.

Wanna was a great guide!. While the museum doesn't seem like much when you first walk in, the experience is truly unique. All of the tour guides lived through the genocide and had army experience. Our guide, wanna, was willing to share his story with us. He survived incredible feats and made me have a deeper understanding of the Cambodian people.

Well worth a visit. Me and my girlfriend decided to go it as it's the only war museum in cambodia and after visiting s21 and the killing fields we felt it was necessary to have a full understanding of the suffering and hardship the Cambodian people went through. We arrived and we're greeted by Mr vanna, an incredibly friendly and knowledgeable war veteran. We decided to have him give us a tour so we could fully appreciate all the things we were looking at. It was well worth it, getting first hand insight into the things that happened and the real stories of the things he went through and of friends he lost. Very moving and couldn't help but feel sorry for Mr vanna but also amazed and impressed at what he had been through and that he could still smile. Would recommend to anyone and would certainly recommend a tour by one of the veterans.

Well worth the visit. We spent an amazing afternoon at this museum. Our guide (can't remember his name) was very informative and showed us the exhibitions whilst adding personal insights to his experiences during the Pol Pot regime and civil war. What these beautiful people have endured is beyond belief. So glad we live in Australia and are sooooo lucky to live peacefully. Really gives you an understanding of the country and what they have had to endure. Definitely worth a visit, and the $5 entry fee

Emotional experience, worth a visit!. For a measles $5 entry fee the story and truth we were told seemed unfair. The pain and suffering of these veterans is emotional and unjust! Soun was a great volunteer guide who spoke good English and did not do a propaganda story time.The place is clearly not well funded and the artefacts are a little worn and tired, but overall is was authentic and informative. Great gun collections and some shocking photo displays of the injured civilians from landlines. The photos of human remains was confronting from the Kmher Killing Fields. May their souls Rest in Peace!

A must do. We had an amazing experience at the war museum. Very real and our guide Wanna was so open and honest in sharing his real life experiences in the war. The memorabilia is impressive and the photos were very daunting. This is so worth a visit if in Siem Reap

Feel the Pain. Although it is impossible to feel the pain of the Cambodian people during the Khmer Rouge times, one can only try to empathize. This museum showcases the war artifacts from the civil war, you can obtain a free guide in the museum - however it is encouraged to tip or donate for the conservation of this museum.
Eye opener. This museum gives so much information about a complex and terrifying time in Cambodia's history. Our guide was outstanding. He had fought in the war and shared his knowledge generously.

Brought me to tears. I could feel the ghosts of Cambodia in this place. I took my 19 year old son to the museum to give him an understanding of the history of Cambodia. The guide was insightful and had excellent English. Every gun, tank and landmine had a history. As a proud Australian who cries every Anzac Day I could just barely hold my tears when visiting this place. It is real and confronting but a must see if only to educate and try and stop this from happening again. The resilience of the Cambodian people in the face of such evil is inspiring.

Average. Make this your last itinerary.. The entrance is affordable compared to other museums in Siem Reap. But guides are not consistenly available. We went there and no one bothered to tour us and tell the story.
Disturbingly Real. Great value activity leaving you with a disturbing insight to the relatively recent history of Cambodia. Our guide Sophoon was excellent.

Very interesting. I probably learned and understood more about Cambodian history from our trip here, than anywhere or anything previously.We had Mr Sinath as our guide, and his story of survival was incredible and he spoke very well, and particularly engaged our young boys. The tour starts with a personal introduction by the guide in the 'small arms' shelter, after which visitors get to hold and pose with any of the weapons on display. I personally found this rather disturbing to see the boys in my family having so much 'fun' and joking around with these weapons in front of a man who had just explained to use the horrors he had endured....but sadly, he didn't seem to mind as much as I did.After this, we went on to the land mine display and explanation, and then a tour of the 'armour graveyard'. Most of the armour on display is very badly damaged and not restored in any way. My husband said it was sad that they had not been preserved in any way, but he still managed to take over 150 snaps for 'reference'.I think we spent a good 1.5hrs here, my husband probably would have spent more, but we had other plans for the day and had to move on. My young boys enjoyed being able to climb up onto the tanks etc and pose for photos.At the end, of course, our 'free' guide explained that they volunteered their services and any 'tips' would be appreciated........

Tragic , and thought provoking. This is a must see, the people of Cambodia have suffered an almost unimaginable tragedy. A nation of almost 9 million people has been reduced to a little more than a million after almost 40 years of war, genocide, murder, bombing, corruption and land mines and UXO. The guides here, child soldier survivors communicate so vividly their story and survival. Heart wrenching .

Highly recommend!. My boyfriend and I got told about this museum by a tuk tuk driver so didn't really know what to expect. We went to the museum (which is all outdoors) and were taken round by a tour guide who spoke good English. He spoke us through the war with very good detail. He also told us how he was a 14 year old soldier in the war and an unfortunate victim of a landmine. Truly heartbreaking and definitely worth a visit!!!
Very good. A visit that makes you reflect and realise how lucky I've been not having to experience war. Also makes you understand where Cambodia is coming from.

Should have skipped. This is one of the most expensive attractions I've ever seen in Cambodia, relative to the value it returns. All the exhibits are mostly redundant and the guides weren't at all helpful. It has a wide, open space filled with war antiques and that's mostly it. You can get better value from the Cambodian Landmine Museum and the Vietnam War Museum. Be careful of tuk tuk drivers who overprice rides. We found Khmer tuk tuk drivers to be very welcoming, honest and accommodating, so stick with them. We stumbled upon one tuk tuk driver who looked Indian who tried to take advantage of our supposed naivete, good thing there was a Khmer driver near.

War Museum - worth a look. There were no guides when I arrived.It was very interesting seeing the tanks, canons, helicopter and jet. There were also examples of landmines and ammunition.I think it would have been better if a guide would have been available as mentioned by other travellers

A chance to hear their history. We had very limited time in Seam Reap and someone suggested a visit to this museum. It is aging war machines all outside. What made this a great museum was the guided tour. Our guide was Suon. He had lived through the war and fought with the Khmer Rouge. He told his story of loosing his family as a child and his struggle through everything. That and the photos, weapons and machinery made the visit extremely meaningful. It is an experience we will never forget.

So impressive. I have to say that before I arrived to Cambodia I didn´t know anything about the civil war. I was so shock listening all the stories about it, and visiting this place was so impressive to me. Our guide was very good explaining in English everything about the war, he was affected by a landmine loosing one of his legs. When the visit finished all of us were speechless.

Interesting War Museum. There is no glitz or glamour to this interesting museum which displays old war machines from the Kymer Rouge era and offers the chance to talk with a veteran of the Pol Pot era. As a "Nam Era veteran, I vividly recall that time period. It is well worth any ones time to see and hear of the atrocities perpetrated against the Cambodians from those who were directly affected.

for to know the war history who want.. Well, this museum is not bad for who want to know the civil war history in Cambodia,I think there is good , you can take look the weapon , tank , gun , cannon, ..etc,over there have simple infomation on lot weapon, and some photo show the history,including civil war ..etc.but I really feel they needed take care the remains of war,because they're increasing damage day than day.

A unique opportunity. This museum does not offer glitzy multi media displays or make overs by Madame Tussauds, what it does offer is the opportunity to hear from the mouths of soldiers who lived through the horrors of the Kymer Rouge regime what they and their families and ordinary Cambodians experienced, while wandering round a display of rusted military armaments. Our guide had been a soldier with the Kymer Rouge, and his story echoed similar stories of child soldiers in Sierra Leone. You don't have to know a lot about the history of the country just be willing to ask a few questions to gain a unique insight into the country. It would be wonderful the government or a charity could invest a bit of money into this museum as I believe it could become an important tourist destination.

Well worth the visit. Ended out here by chance, were so glad we did. Our guide Suon was amazing. Telling us his life story was extremely sad, however made you appreciate the horrific times Cambodia has seen. Would not have been the same without him. Not much to the Museum itself, apart from some old artilary and photos. Its the guide that makes this place worthwhile.

Worth a few hours. This is an outdoor exhibit of old planes, tanks, guns land mines etc. They sit you down at the start and explain the Cambodian history which helps too. Our guide had 1 leg blown off by bland mine.About 5km out of town..get the tuk tuk to wait as its a very quiet area.

Go here!. This place is full of old rusty war material (tanks, mines, ak47 and more). When you go here you MUST talk to the guide and listen to his life story. Our guide (named Soun) was a war vetaran who learned english just because he wanted to show the world the cruelty of war. His story was extremely touching and well spoken. Dont be in a hurry, but take your time and listen to the stories. I hope Soun (our guide) will write a book someday....
