War remains.. Sad history. CC ( 2014.07.27 ) This museum was made in the garden with war remains. There were many artillery, tanks, antiaircraft cannon, etc. In Cambodia, many people hurted by landmine with sad war history. This place was very calm and solemn, but the atmosphere was not bad. Take your time with slowly walking around there. That's good, I think.

Dont miss this place. One of the place to visit if you are travelling to siem reap this reminds us how cambodia was looking during the war. The guide are the victims of those terrible land minds/veterans that still located in fertile land of cambodia. Location is with in City limits after the military camp est 8 mins. From old market. Lesson learned negociate with tuktuk driver before proceeding asking price is 15 usd old market to war museum to market. Entrance fee 10/person. Just give tip to guide though they say that its for free tip box is also available at the main entrance.

Impressive. Next to all the beauty of Siem Reap the war museum is a stop you cannot and do not want to skip. It's important, especially for teenagers, to be made aware of what happened in Cambodia just so recently. Most impact full are the guides, who share their personal stories. The pictures tell a cruel story. And still today, the country is not clean from mines. The museum is build and maintained with care and is only a little outside of the city. Quickly there with a Tuk Tuk. Very very impressive!!!

A must see in Cambodia!. My friend and I decided to go to the war museum and we were both very shocked as to how terrible the Cambodian people have had it here. Up to two million people died, many from exhaustion or starvation, while others were tortured and executed, until an Vietnamese-led invasion ended Khmer Rouge rule in 1979. There are still over two million mines left in the country. It's a real eye opener, you have to go. Our tour man was called "hour", a really nice guy to talk to.

Must be seen.. As a history teacher I understood a little of what Cambodia suffered over the past half century. Nothing prepared me to hear the history from someone who lived it. Thom was our complimentary guide after the $5 entrance fee. Well worth the price. I've read the poor reviews panning the rusting and unkempt feel of this historic place. I believe it added to the ambiance. It drizzled the entire time we were there and I think that added to the experience. There were little covered areas to seek refuge. The guides were knowledgeable and they are the survivors. They cannot find work in other "good" jobs because their wounds make them "unlucky".They will ask for a donation at the conclusion, in addition to what you already paid, but it is well earned and I didn't feel as if I was duped.Please go and learn and support this place.

Not to be missed. My friend and I spent 12 days travelling around Cambodia earlier this month. We had both read about the War Museum in our Lonely Planet's. I can't speak for my friend but my history on the Civil War and the Khmer Rouge is pretty sketchy at best. We took a tuk-tuk from the Angkor National Museum to the War Museum which only cost us US$3 and got more than we ever expected from this place!!Despite the terrible atrocities that the Cambodia people and it's country endured less than half a century ago, this is the only War Museum in the whole country. If you come to Siem Reap please make the effort to go to the War Museum. For US$5 you can look around by yourself or you can be taken around by a guide. Our guide was Tom, a lovely, soft spoken Cambodian man who grew up near Siem Reap. Tom lived through the Khmer Rouge, lost his family when he was 12 and his left arm to a landmine not long after. Tom gave us an insight into this conflict that you can only get from a person who was there. All of the guides at the musuem are victims of the war. Like Tom many of his colleagues have also suffered the loss of a limb. Because of this, Tom and his fellow colleagues are no longer employable in the normal job market. However, the War Museum shows that they have a lot to offer and we have a lot to learn from them!!! So if you are in Siem Reap please visit the War Museum, and keep Tom and his friends in a job. You won't regret it!!

i think important to know!. this is a different option to the temples and i think its important to know the history of cambodia and not only the angkor temples history this is not a slick well funded museum but a group of local war veterans who had opened a small museum a collection of old tanks and guns mines and such from the local cavil warthe guides are a must to inform you what your looking at and the story behind it, if you like an impressive well lit A/C museam with fancy gift shop then this is not for you, but if you want real with real people and a lasting memory of what really happened then its a must

Worth visiting. The museum is a very emotional and honest portrayal of some of the horrors in recent Cambodian history.Our guide walked us through some of the exhibits and outlined some of his experiences as a child soldier and landmine/war survivor.Many exhibits of apc's and tanks which have met their ultimate fate, some of which still have their bone fragments of their final crew in them.Honestly a must see exhibit, get a guide first otherwise you will not get the full experience. You will not regret it.

Moving experience.. We have all heard/read about the Cambodian civil war but many (including myself, before coming here) don't know too much about it. This was a very emotional and moving experience. My tour guide, named Hour, is a landmine victim himself. His english was good, and hearing about the Cambodian war from him was fascinating. He took me to all the exhibits and explained the role other countries had in this horrible conflict. If you have a few days in Siem Reap, try to swing by here. It's a short tuk-tuk ride away from the town and only takes about an hour to thoroughly go through this outdoor museum.

Modern history layed out. Was really looking forward to seeing this display of war relicsWas great to be able to walk around, see and touch the items. It was a museum which offered a free guide which was great but we all know this isn't a "free" guide. I would much rather pay a set fee for a guide than to be asked at the end. The tanks and guns are certainly rusting away and I was surprised that there didn't seem to be any work on maintaining what was still there.Well worth the visit but would have been better to see 5 years ago.

Cambodia war museum, must visit if in Siem Reap. Just visited, 27 July. Fascinating and moving experience and not to be missed. Our guide, Sophorn, gave us a clear and detailed account of the entire history of the series of wars from 1970 and also of events since. He was able to describe life during the Khmer Rouge era eloquently, having lived through and having been injured during the war. The mines, weapons and fighting vehicles displayed in the quiet tree shaded compound provided the perfect backdrop.I had read a little about the war, and am old enough to remember it in the news, but have a much clearer picture now. Definitely a place to visit if you have any interest in the recent history of Cambodia, and of it's neighbours, which is still relevant today.

The guide is worth a 1000 photos.. I love that everything on display was used and has a story. Weapons from the 1940's to the end of the civil war. Seeing what happens to to a 35 tonne tank when if hits a land mine, storys of why they use anti-aircraft weapons with no planes to shoot at. My guides story and the history was worth the visit.

It can be so much more. For a country with a tumultuous past and the terrible sacrifices of its people who still manage a very friendly attitude, the war museum in Siem Reap is an insult to the memory of those who died. The word basic is too strong to describe the place. Rust is eating away at the exhibits, 95% of which are exposed to the elements. The information signs are handwritten and offer little detail apart from the date and location and year of manufacturing of the military equipment part of which was removed or "permanently" borrowed.I am glad I visited the museum and I was moved by the section dedicated to land mines and their silent victims but with just a little work, that place can offer so much more.

A great insight into humanity. the museum is a hands on excursion into how cruel people can be. the guides are fantastic and a very reasonable $5 fee. for boys it is a great opportunity to see and hold the deadly weapons from Cambodia's past.

Personally loved this more than other museums I have seen. First off, I can probably see where the bad comments come from, if you were to just walk around this place with no guide or a poor guide, yes it would most likely be just average.I barely even saw most of the items as the entire time I was asking my guide questions and he gave me great answers as to his life, his kids life and what it's like dealing with PTSD and post war problems. At one point, the guy literally sat down with me, and we chatted while my gf (who wasn't into the war exhibits as much as I was)and he and I just talked about stuff he remembered.I will say, yes these guys are doing this as work. And yes, they are probably underpaid. The problem comes when you have to distinguish if donating at the end is worth it or not. My guide never once asked for money, never gave me some sob story about how he needs to feed family etc.. I willingly asked about how the govt compensates veterans and he said matter of factly that pensions are usually about 30$ a month for some, himself included. He talked about the struggles of being alone and how he only recently started sharing his story with his kids. I ended with a 5$donation that I approached him about. Not the other way around(o can agree I'd feel odd if approached by them about it.)Overall, whether I got lucky with the guide or not, I had goosebumps half the time talking to him, and because of that this may have been my favourite place after 4 months in Asia.

Authentic, enlightening, shocking experience!!!. Wow......What an enlightening experience. We squeezed in a visit to the museum just before our flight left. Our guide, Tom, former Khmer Rouge child soldier and landmine victim, led us through an emotional, at times horrifying recount of the Cambodian Civil War. I highly recommend visiting the museum if you are in Siem Reap. Having history recounted by somebody that was actually there was a truly authentic experience.

Educational and Moving. For $5 dollars a ticket this is really worth while. My history knowledge is fairly poor and I learnt so much from my visit. You get a free guide - ours was an ex soldier, who had stepped on a land mine causing him to lose a leg. The museum is strangely peaceful and it was an saddening experience but I would say to everyone coming to Siem Reap, definitely visit this war museum!

Eye-opener. War museum originally wasn't in our itinerary, but I'm glad that we had time to visit this place. Hearing about the Khmer Civil War back in the 1970's, and knowing how a lot of innocent people died back then--truly an eye-opener.

Insightful and interesting experience. We thoroughly enjoyed our experience here. Arrived and met our guide (can't remember his name) but he provided us with an amazing experience and explained everything from the different types of landmines and how theyre set off to who provided them with weapons during the war etc. It was very informative, the guide was fantastic, and is a must do if you are in Siem Reap!

Must see. At the entrance we meet our guide Sempora. He not only showed us around but provide us with a great insight into the sad history of Cambodia over the last 40 years. Very moving to hear his story.

I challenge you not to be moved.... Mr Tom you are a true hero. To of lived through such a dark time and we thank you for sharing such history with us...We ( 2 adults 1 teenager) arrived not knowing quite what to expect. Well, we were not disappointed. Our guide Tom took us around various vehicles/aeroplane/helicopter/armoury and living tales of those involved. We were so moved by his own personal story and of those who work there too, that you find yourself asking lots of questions and finding things out you never knew before. A short trip from Siem Reaps centre. $5 entrance fee and a guide showing you around. Go see and breath in history....

Excellent!. My son and I visited the War Museum today (7/10/2014) with a group of friends. While the museum is small, it was well worth the visit! They offer free guides and this is a must! Our guide was wonderful. It was touching to hear his personal story of how he was affected by the war, and he had so much knowledge to pass on. He was so excited and grateful that a large group of Americans came and had an interest in learning about his country! They have big plans for the museum in the coming years (including new, air conditioned buildings). We thoroughly enjoyed our trip and learned a lot! I would highly recommend a trip to the museum!

Eye opening and moving.. A very somber experience of the war. Our tour guide Tom (not sure how to spell, sorry!) did an excellent job. The sights were not as moving as the stories from Tom himself. I wouldn't recommend young children, but think anyone can learn from a trip to this museum. It took less than an hour but was worth our time.

A harrowing memorial to cambodia's struggle.. We went early morning, and were welcomed by the incredibly friendly staff here, got our guide mr thom (sorry if I spelt that wrong mate!) And he took us for a really detailed tour round the weapons and vehicles stored here. Its a shocker to be honest as so well detailed by other reviews, but so so worth it. The kit on display is worn out (thankfully) but most of it has real battle damage hence missing parts. Its a worth while trip to see the weapons, but most importantly to talk to those who were forced to endure them.

An Education. Don't pass up the chance to visit this monument to the effects on ordinary people of so-called super powers playing their horrible games using smaller countries as testing grounds for their weapons, which even today they are still extracting money from the Cambodians for!Our guide was the manager of the museum, an ex-soldier and landmine victim called Sophorn. I thought I was quite clued up about the war in Vietnam and Cambodia being old enough to remember it happening, but what Sophorn told me was truly eye-opening and made it easier to understand the cynicism and lack of trust in the USA, Russia and China felt by many smaller developing countries, who just want to sort out their own affairs.The museum itself was a graveyard of rusting military vehicles, ordnance, small arms and landmines, all supplied of course by the afore-mentioned. The museum is run by ex-veterans from different sides of the Cambodian War, which raged in different forms between 1970 and 1998. It is a tribute to the people of this country, who despite the horrors they suffered, are able to move on and through this museum inform the rest of the world.

Amazing. This is a must see. Upon arriving at the museum, we were greeted with a warm welcome by a war veteran who lost his leg to a landmine. As he guided us around the museum, he shared his personal stories and was very knowledgable. The museum is absolutely fascinating with a lot of war remains. Take the time to go out and see it.

A visit to understand the recent past. Our visit was a sobering reminder of the years of war endured by the Cambodian people. Our guide a landline survivor and former Army Major shared his first hand experiences of a war that concluded just over a decade ago.

Sobering but very worthwhile visit. After the splendour of Angkor it was important to get a more balanced view of the very recent tragedy of Cambodia. The rusting hulks of war machinery seem appropriate and hopeful that that is how they will stay. The immense human damage caused (and still being caused) by land mineswas made clear by our very helpful guide, Thom, himself a casualty. Recommended.

Historic. This is a good tour. Takes about 30 mins to get from the centre of Siem Reap to the place. Cost about 7 USD by Tuk Tuk to and fro.I took up a tour guide by the name of Huo (not too sure on the spelling). The majority of the tour guides in the museum are former soldiers and mostly mine victims. This is one of the few jobs provided to them and if you take the time to ask them about their lives and how it was in the war, you will gain a greater understanding and sympathy towards what the Cambodian people has gone through.By learning about the history first hand, I find it an invaluable experience and information. The exhibitions are mostly rusted out due to the low budget of the museum. The exhibits are not properly cared for.However, when you do do this trip I would advise taking on a guide to give you info about the museum and ask them personally about the hardships they have to go through.A little tip also go a long way as like most people in Cambodia, they earn very little.All in all, a worthwhile trip. I would advise people to go visit!

A Good Experience and I'm Glad I Went. This place is really interesting. It isn't for everyone though. I didn't bother getting a tour guide because I'm very familiar with the war, but just walking around and seeing the weapons of all shapes and sizes, seeing the photographs of the consequences of war and reading what information was there made this a worthwhile experience. $5 is a good price in a city where everything seems to cost $15 or more, and you have the freedom to take all the pictures you want and touch (some of) the weapons. I would go back for a guided tour next time.

Wars that plagued Cambodia. Our tour guide was looking for this guy on a prosthetic leg, a war veteran who speaks fluent English. His entire family was killed during the wars (civil and foreign invasions), thus has plenty to tell including the origin of each scars he suffered from bullet wounds. Give tips (he'll truly appreciate that). See some old and rusting Chinese ammunition and artillery; you could imagine how intense the war was with the Russian rocket BM14 (16 cannons).

Total waste. I guess I did not get Mr. Tom as other reviewers did so my guide was total waste. He stayed with me for total 5 mins and after that left making up a story to leave. He said he is known as some Mr Cat cause he almost died 10 times in war but had nothing more to tell regarding war etc. Also the place is not worth 5$. A small ruin with nothing to offer. Total waste of time and money.

Very interesting! . A great visit! The history of the war is extremely sad and interesting. Make sure you get the free tour guide, we got Tom who was a child soldier at the age of 14 and lost his arm in a landline accident. He has great stories to tell. Is just $5 to enter and donations are welcome. A great insight into where Cambodia used to be just 16years ago.
History on Landmines. Very interesting, make sure you do take the time for a guided tour from the locals, who some have been victims of war / land mines .. heart felt knowledge
Tom was a Great Guide. Amazing history stories behind the artifacts by Tom (Mr. Mean Sothom). Tom is a land mine victim who is open about his story and the Cambodian history. Highly recommended.

Cambodia war museum. A number of antique war artifacts, most rusted out. A number of graphic photos with explications. The place would definitely had been of a greater historical significance had there been personnel available to provide additional information.
Worth the time to visit. Free guides. Cheap entry fee. The entire museum is outdoors and allows you the extraordinary opportunity to see the war relics up close.
Great guides. Free guides. Cheap entry. Get along and support post war programs and see what military occupation did to these people.

Interesting and worth the visit!. Cycled here early in the morning but was a bit surprised to be the only group there (during our whole visit). While it appears to be an infrequently visited tourist attraction I think it is definitely worth a visit. Takes about 30mins-1hr.Get the free tour guide, was the best bit about the museum. He was informative and very willing to answer all questions. I believe the majority of what we were told was accurate and factual. The whole tour was interesting and we were happy to tip.

The guide makes the museum. I came there at 4 o'clock in the afternoon with a friend. Eventhough the guide is free, they told us we couldn't get a guide because the guides are warvictims them selves, and the guide there today had walked so much on his prosthetic leg that it was paining him. This was a really difficult thing to argue with, but I wish they would have told us about this before we paid 5dollars entry. We walked around on our own for about 15minutes, but to be honest: unless you like to look at rusty tanks and guns, it is super borring.Then we sat down a bit at the entrance and talked to the guide and we started asking him questions about the war, and for some reason he decided to give us a small tour anyway. The 15min. we spend with him were super interesting and moving. He told about the machines, there history, but most important answered all our questions about the war, the museum and modern cambodia.My advice: This place is really interesting and I would recommend people to go, but only with a guide, which means you have to go earlier in the day, while the guides can still walk.

Authentic and real. Thom explained the different war histories and his own personal tragedies Very informative relaxed away from hordes of touristsIn lovely setting vast amounts of authentic war memorabilia on show Glad I went

Must do in Siem Reap!. I didnt know a whole lot about the war and thus museum definitely opened my eyes to what the cambodian people have been through! I would definitely recommend getting a guide (they are free) as ours spoke great english and new the answers to all of our questions. Heaps of guns, tanks etc to look out. Very sad but amazing place to visit, totally recommend it.

Not to be missed!. I found this museum to be fascinating! It's a nice break from Angkor Wat and the crowds at the park. Thom was my tour guide and he took the time to teach us about the war and the terrible atrocities that occurred. Bring a tissue, as Thom's recount of the war brought us both to tears. It's an eye-opening experience and I wouldn't miss this spot. The museum is outdoors on a former land mine, which is incredible in itself. Take an hour, learn about this history and culture of Cambodia, you won't be sorry!

Very interesting to see and quite emotional. Just cost a few dollors entry. And the people were really friendly. The tour guide Tom was brilliant. He knew every detail of all the exhibits and told us his personnal experiences from the cambodian civil war. I really was moved and left the museum with a deep feeling of respect for the cambodian people. Real eye opening tour. Lots of interesting guns and tanks to see ther and a few aircraft. I even got to hold and sight through an ak47 and Tommy Gun..

A must see in Siem Reap. I agree with everything David said. At first I thought the museum was going to a dud but after our guide (Thom) introduced himself to us the entire atmosphere changed. His life story and the information he provided was inspiring and heart wrenching. Whilst listening to his life story I found tears running down my cheeks. I would question anyone who is not moved by this experience. Thom gave a very informative history of Cambodia in the Pol Pot regime which was extraordinary. If you want to see shiny tanks, guns etc and a glossy view of Cambodia then go somewhere else. This has authentic, real equipment and photos with guides whom have first hand experience and you cannot get any better than that. A true living museum. We left feeling sad, and grateful there are people with such a strong forgiving nature, willing to bring this horror to the world so we all realise how lucky we are in Australia. Thanks

good hour or so spent - easy to get to.. Well, I liked it but perhaps others wouldn't. My wife and older daughter didn't come with me and daughter #2. The guide made the visit for me, Mr Thom, an ex soldier who had his left arm blown off by claymore mine shrapnel when 14 years old. He took the time to tell his story which I found very poignant and describe the weapons on site - there was clear subtext to it all of course and behind his smiles. The AK47's and M16's are still in working order if rusty. loads of other stuff too.Without a guide you may go through it in 5 minutes though. Deserving of a decent tip.

Inspiring place. I have been amazed by a few reviews that said this place wasn't worth it, I must say our experience is different to theirs.First off this was perhaps the most inspiring place due to our free guide who gave us such detailed history on the war and the atrocities that happened.I note that a few people have mentioned they didn't have a guide there so maybe ask for one as you enter , we were there realy late in the day and he was available for us.As we found out our guide was actually a prisoner in the war and survived the camps only to lose a leg due to a landmine , he was inspiring and a privilege to meet and talk

Even if it's not true, it's heart wrenching. We did this tour and had no problems paying the $5.00 entrance fee. Yes the tanks are rusty etc, we took the option of having a guide and it brought tears to my eyes. He showed us his gun shot wounds and told us about his experiences it was so sad. At the end do the tour he did not ask us for a tip and we were happy to tip. Even if his story is not true, it's someone's story and l ask certain reviewers who have given poor ratings, how many re enacting shows do you have in your country! Just looking at photos is informative. We enjoyed this better than the cultural centre.

rusty. It's all rusty! The museum is an open space museum which fruit trees like mango trees are planted in between all rusty tanks, guns etc... English speaking guide is provided but do not forget to give tips after that! In my case, no need to have one! A shop which selling souvenir items such as t-shirt, fridge magnet, flag, books, etc also in the museum area. The toilets also provided and clean too...by the way, not to forget the entrace fee is USD 5!

save your money. Wasn't impressed with this at all. $5 entrance fee for what looked like a load of rusting tanks and war memrobilia, very little information and even less enthusiasm from its staff. A few highlights were the small arms and helicopter but we strolled and still was only really 20 minutes worth!!!

Gut Wrenching. After several days touring Siem Reap, we were curious for more information about the politics here, and our driver suggested the war museum. Hubby being a war history buff, we were all in.Admission was only $5, and that included a free tour guide if we wanted one. We opted to start the tour on our own.We were just a bit disappointed because there's very little written information anywhere in the museum. The grounds are filled with rusting tanks, missiles, guns and signs containing info about when the piece was built, who built it, how big, how many millimeters, when it was found, etc. But we were hoping for political history.There's irony in the fact that all the rusting weaponry is positioned for display in a beautiful mango grove.Several museum structures house walls of photographs. The general theme is Pol Pot's "killing fields" and land mine victims. Dozens of photos of limbless adults and children shock your senses in living color, as do piles of skeletal skulls and limbs of the millions of Cambodians murdered by the Khmer Rouge regime 1975-79.Equally shocking are dozens more pictures of 7-10 year old children smiling for the camera while holding weapons, which might have been used to shoot their own parents in exchange for Pol Pot's promise of plentiful food,We later learned that 50% of Cambodians today are under age 22 because half the adults in the country were butchered by Pol Pot. We also learned that Cambodia is still the third highest ranked country in the world for active land mine hazards.After we'd covered the grounds on foot, we stopped in the meager souvenir shop. Several books are available for $8-9 US, which do relate Cambodia's recent political history. You can also buy the documentary "The Killing Fields" on DVD. And you can buy a T-shirt inscribed with a skull and "DANGER Land Mines" I recommend seeing this museum, but first do a little research on the history of Lon Nol and Pol Pot so you have a better background going in. Your experience will be more meaningful.

Good experience. Myself and my partner visited the museum thismorning, we turned up and paid the $5 entry fee and continued inside were we were met by a young lady who asked if we would like a guide we said yes we would. No one came to meet us so obviously we werent goin to get one..its a shame because i really wanted to learn more about what i was looking at and understand more about the cambodian wars but had no one to tell me...so now im watching a doco on youtube. i think the guide makes the experience so if you go make sure you get a guide or come back when one is available. I even had a $10 tip ready in my pocket before we arrived but had no one to give it to..still some amazing things to see and read.

If you see one thing in Siem Reap, make this it. This war museum is managed by a veteran who is happy to take you around explaining the exhibits while telling you his own experience of the Pol Pot regime, donation completely voluntary. His story of hardship and loss is absolutely heart-wrenching. This was the most authentic, touching experience I have had in 3 months in SE Asia; I was fighting back tears. I honestly enjoyed this more than Angkor Wat, and for the $5 admission fee I believe it is completely unmissable.

A Great Experience!. My experience at the war museum was very insightful, and upon inquiring with the manager (myself being shy and in a foreign country, I mustered up the courage), I found this gentle soul full of the complete history of the fatal Pol Pot regime and the civil war after his disposition in 1979, which continued to ravage Cambodia until 1998!Some may say that the tanks are rusty and not kept in good condition. I would think most of the machinery is 60 years old or more, and Cambodia being a tropical climate, metal rusts with the monsoon season, and over many years. The very kind and softly spoken manager informed me that they at last have funding to upgrade the museum and work is currently underway to improve the museum.I was asked if (with no pressure at all) that it was up to me if I would like to give a tip. I found the way this was asked to be in no way intrusive - it was asked very humbly and gently after my guide explained in great details the horror and genocide Cambodia experienced. I was only too happy to oblige and left with tears in my eyes, being thankful I had never had to experience the extremely traumatic affects of War.

Don't miss it!. It astounds me that anyone could write anything negative about this place, and re the person who found the $5 entry fee a bit steep, I am lost for words. The museum deals with the horrific period of rule by Pol Pot, and on display is an amazing array of exhibits located after the war ended, including a range of land mines. The best way to understand this is with the help of a guide, and I was fortunate enough to have the guy who was himself a land mine victim. His account of this experience brought tears to my eyes. Please put it on your list of things to see in beautiful Siem Reap.

interesting re war weapons, sobering re killing fields era. Ok, so it may not look much, but for an exhibition that is neither glitzy nor glamorous and is well off the beaten track it is absolutely fascinating, especially as you have complete access to old weapons and transport of war.Got there about 9-ish with my wife and had immediate access to an English speaking guide. True to what the advertising literature says he is an ex-soldier and is a landmine victim. He was very factual and open about the use of landmines during the various wars and Pol Pot regime and there is series of display boards in relation to the killing fields era. From our brief experiences in Siem Reap provided you struck up a rapport with whoever, especially the guide in this instance and our tuktuk driver, a lot more family history of the Killing Fields era comes to light, which then makes the displays even more chillingThe small landmine exhibit was interesting and you forget how long landmine clearance has been going on because they had photos of Princess Diana and Prince Harry in Cambodia in respect of landmine clearance.There is a little shop there

Tetanus Hazard. I spent about an hour and a half here just wandering around. It's nice to have something spread out outdoors like they have done at the War Museum. All the old tanks on display are in terrible shape, rusty and deteriorating, but it's still nice to see and walk around the place. 5 dollars seems a bit steep for the entrance fee to see a bunch of rusty old tanks though. There are huts along the sides with photo's and displays of all sorts of firearms, mines and explosives used during past conflicts and guides are available for free at the entrance but I'm sure there is some sort of tipping required. Also you need to watch your step around here, not for any landmines or anything but the uneven terrain around the place means it's easy to lose your balance and trip over which I almost did a few times while walking around the place.

Go to land mine museum instead. I desperately wish I wouldn't have wasted my time here and I'd gone to the higher-rated landmine museum instead. This is simply field with tanks in it, and NO written information about the war. I literally left more confused than I'd walked in. The resident guide was ok, but hard to understand and it felt extremely awkward at the end when he asked for donations to feed his family. We paid an entrance fee and he works there, so it just made everyone in the group a little uncomfortable.

Loved it!. The war museum is an outdoor museum filled with old war relics from guns to tanks to a helicopter. My partner LOVED it but he's a war nut so he knew every piece of machinery. Included in the fee is a tour guide who told us his war stories. Fascinating!

Well worth a visit. If you are staying in Siem Reap this museum is well worth the short trip out of the centre. We took the guided tour, which is incredibly moving and informative. All of the guides are veterans who volunteer here to share their stories - we were happy to tip $10 each as they really make the experience (and entry is only $5!) the tour is highly recommended.

easy to make the time. you can get a lot out of this one for the 5 bucks and won't take much of you day, we were here only about 30 minutes and used the free guide. tip is expected and our guide was informative. I would rec taking the guide, u can browse at your will though. we tipped 2 dollars. our guide was also a victim of a post war mine accidentally stepped on. he gave us insight on who supplied who and weapons knowledge. I could tell you what we learned but then u might not use the guide. close to the airport. we did a tuk tuk and the driver took our money and purchased our tickets as we sat in comfort on the tuk tuk. just added that to show some of the classy service in Cambodia.

Must see. 'Terrible' reviews obviously didn't account for the fact they were in a poor, developing country. Entry is $5, I not sure what other people expect to pay, but I think this is cheap! I had an eye opening experience that really put things into perspective. We'd missed the start of a tour with a guide, but he called us over to join his group and was very welcoming. The tanks and guns are interesting to see, and there are many things to see, however the main experience for me was the stories of the guide - an ex soldier and land mine victim. I gladly tipped him $10 at the end of the tour, because to me that's nothing (to lots of us that's nothing), and was missing a leg, was going blind, had been shot multiple times and had wounds everywhere, all because of war in his country.You can take a Tuk Tuk but organise a return trip with the same driver because you won't get one back otherwise.

A sobering education. Our tour guide was a victim of the Khmer Rouge regime, lost lower leg at the age of 17. He led us through the park like setting which held artillery used during the war from 1975-1998, and explained it well, answered questions. Chilling, and to realize that there are still land mines yet to be found in NW Cambodia.

Please visit. The US$5 entrance fee includes a English speaking guild. Please join the tour.The guns and tanks on display are just tools of war and one would get bored with them after a short time. By joining the tour, you get the listen to a persons storey during the trying times. How a person survives and the scars he carries reminds those more fortunate not to take things for granted.Go have a look.The guild is free but of course tips are appreciated.

Bik is the man!. I'm 21, traveling alone, and had a great time at this museum. I was given a one on one tour with Bik Hour and he was MORE than willing to chat with me about the intricacies surrounding the Kmher Rouge and the effects of war on Cambodia. He even hosted me for lunch at a nearby spot and spoke to me about life in Cambodia! If you are looking to get some great photos, learn about the historical significance of the country you are residing in, and connect with a local over some pretty heartfelt stories, then come to the War Museum.

Exceptional, this guided tour should not be missed. My wife and I are from New Zealand, in our 50s. We strongly recommend a visit to the War Museum. Our guide Suon Rottama spoke very good English, was caught up in the war, had landmine injuries and spoke from the heart with great dignity and from personal experience of these ghastly war times. My recommendation is that you don't look around on your own. It will just be a hardware experience. The guided tour is not to be missed and while we did not have to wait at all, I'd say it's worth waiting up to two hours for a guide. The hardware armoury held my interest for only 10 minutes but I didn't go there for that, I went there to learn. It is the guide's stories that are powerful, compelling and important to learn about and from.

Not to be missed. Myself and my son visited the war museum and after reading reviews asked for a guide. So so worth it. Ours was fantastic! He really made a point of connecting with my son. His story was so sad and pretty much had me in tears. My son is 14 and I really think he got a lot out of it. I highly recommend!

recommendable. Was very interesting ther. For 5 Dollars you pay the entrance and a guide is also included. The Guides are all war Veterans and can tell you a lot about the war and the weapons in the Museum. Its also allowed to touch all the things and make photos. I was a little bit depressed after i heard all the details about the dirty war in Cambodia. All in all one of the most interesting experiences at my trip.

Great insight into Cambodian history. The museum is located a short drive from center-city and is kind of secluded. It's arranged in an outdoor field setting with small pavilions housing displays and photos. There are tons of artifacts, especially artillery and tanks, throughout the museum grounds. Definitely take the (free) guided tour. My guide had very interesting personal experiences to share and it helped me see a more personal side of the country's history. It would be best to come with questions as the tour is rather short (about 30-45min) and the museum isn't busy at all (I was the only person there on my visit) but it did make for a very personal experience.

A great lesson about the atrocity of war from a land-mine victim. Bik Hour was no war hero. At 17, he was drafted from his village Chan Kuy to fight the Khmer Rouge. Since 1970, Cambodia had almost three decades of civil war. "I didn't want to be a soldier, but I had no choice!" he emphasized. At age 22, his military career came to an abrupt end when he stepped on a land mine amidst a heavy crossfire between his 15-man platoon and an unknown number of Khmer Rouge soldiers. "They were so many of them, and I just saw my best friend died before a land mine brew my right leg off!" It was around one in the afternoon, he recalled, on July 3rd 1995 in the Chong Kal District in northern Cambodia -- the date and place that changed his life forever. Bik left the military with no service medals. His only award, if you can say so, was a cheap prosthetic leg that gave him permanent discomfort and pain. Nevertheless, he considered himself extremely lucky as many of his friends did not live to see the end of the war in 1998 with the death of Pol Pot, the demoniacal Khmer Rouge leader. Desperately poor and unable find a job because of his handicap, he would work any job that pays the next meal and, if he was lucky, give him a place to stay. And for about ten years before joining the War Museum, he was a tuk tuk (an auto three-wheeler) driver. It earned him a meager income that allowed him to live day-by-day. Despite that, he managed to pick up some working English to communicate with tourists.Last year, an old war buddy told him that the War Museum in Siem Reap was hiring, preferably of a veteran who could speak some English. The museum was small, under-funded and rather poorly maintained. It paid USD50 a month plus accommodation in the museum. But to Bik, it was a dream job. "I also earn tips from tourists if I do a good job," he said cheerfully. And that averaged about USD100 a month. With a steady salary, he's on a mission! He vouched to work there until he has to retire telling people who cared to listen about the horror of war. He showed them the many instruments of killing including the type of land mine that took his leg and pictures of victims under the Khmer Rouge regime and during the civil war. To many visitors, it was their first impression of the atrocity of war. And yes, he said, "some people cry hearing my story."The annual Nobel Peace Prize recognizes individuals who make significant contribution to peace. Regretfully, Pik will never be considered. But let's not forget, it's people like him from all corners around the world who work tirelessly, with little reward and no recognition, to tell us about their cruelty of war. This essay is written with a special dedication to Mr. Bik Hour who awakes in us that peace should never be taken for granted.

Interesting and well worth it!. Entry fee $5 and free guided tour (tip at the end as these guides are war veterans and volunteer - most people tipped $1 which is nothing)Very interesting and highly recommended. Paid tuk tuk $4 return from central siem reap.

Thought-provoking. We took a trip to the war museum in cambodia as we wanted to know more of the history and the atrocities committed by the Khmer rouge, we took the guided tour.. our guide was an inspiration, having been shot 3 times and suffered horrific damage by landmines including losing one of his legs! The tour was very interesting but very sad too. We tipped our guide at the end of the tour, all in all we felt that the $5 fee was very good value for money so felt like we should give more as all the guides volunteer and live off their tips and our guide Said he found it very hard to get work. Definitely worth a few hours out of a day if in Siem Reap.

Go. And take the guided tour.. What a wonderful experience! With a relatively limited set of items on show, this is not the most impressive looking or extensive collection of exhibits you will ever see. However, the guides really make the experience unforgettable. Admission is only $5 and the guided tour is free (you should tip though; more on that below). Our guide, an injured veteran soldier (as all of the guides are), showed us around and stayed with us for an hour while we asked questions about his experiences and about the country, then and now. I read a review here where somebody complained about the guide asking for a tip at the end of the tour...really??! How that person wouldn't spare a couple of dollars when the guided tour was free - and so fascinating and informative - is beyond me. Now I see another review saying it is a bit pricey. It's $5. FIVE DOLLARS.

Out of the way but worth a visit.. Lots of war relics from the late 20th century. Had to take tuktuk from city and worth a visit from 30-45min. The tour guide was a former soldier who lost his leg - made the experience more personal.

Guide was awesome ex soldier and mine victim. This place was great and for $5 well worth it. My tour guide who greeted me at the gate was really informative about the war and the weapons used. The guide allows you to touch some of the weaponry if you want to and there is quite a lot to see. Pictures are no problem either. They have even reproduced what a mine field would look like. Very informative, thanks guys.

Interesting but a bit rundown. A bit pricey given that one finds nothing but junk equipment (in comparison with, for example the American Atrocities Museum in Saigpon/ho Chi Minh City). Nevertheless, this is a must for the curious about the war that lasted so long here in Cambodia. Bring lots of sunblock as you will roam around the park replete with hulks of tanks or whatever is left of them.
Worth seeing. This War museum displays items from the last part of the 20th century of Khmer history. With a little imagination these artifacts show the terror of war.
Well worth a visit. A must do to bring further clarity to Khmer past. Guide very good, and a chance to see lots of tanks, guns etc used until very recently in the grand scheme of things.

Heart felt visit, must do. A visit to the war museum is a must, we didn't know a lot about the history of Cambodia and once we left the museum we had a much greater understanding of the people and the place. Our free tour guide was wonderful he had so many stories about the war. He lost his parents and brother when he was 12 years old when they were trying to flee and at 14 he was forced into the army. He lost his arm at 14 years of age when a land mine exploded and his stories are truly heartbreaking. He wanted to be a tour guide but they refused him as he wasn't a "whole man" in their words and he wouldn't be able to carry tourists bags.... So he now volunteers as a guide at the war museum and only lives off donations. It truly is so sad what these people have been through, but they always have a smile on their face and really makes you appreciate what you have and the world you live in. You should go just to support them.

Great place to learn about anti-personnel land mine. The museum itself is an open field displaying many destroyed army equipment such as tanks, artilleries, mortars, etc. surrounded by barracks. If I would just go by myself, I would just look at those equipment and go out with disappointment. I found a message “free guide is available” at the entrance, so I asked for help. He took us to one of the barracks and found that it displayed lots of pictures. He took us through several barracks all displaying pictures and real land mine, guns, shells, etc. He explained what happened to the country and its people during Pol Pot / Khmer Rouge regime, and how the country remains poor and struggling to restore the land and helping victims. My guide was one of the victim by anti-personnel land mine and he lost one leg. His father was the victim of massacre as well. I saw a couple of other guides also did not have leg or arm. So, my recommendation is that you need guide who is very knowledgeable about the history and the museum display. Otherwise, you may not learn the most important message from this museum. The museum wasn’t like to have enough fund to maintain and update the contents, but this is one of the important place to maintain for the world peace. His word “all weapons are bad. They are made to kill people” still remain heavy in my heart. This is simple truth which many people knows but doesn’t want to face its reality.

Heartbreaking and a must see. We read the reviews and decided to go. We grabbed one of the tour guides who walked us through the museum but more importantly, shared his story. A story that is heartbreaking, his family killed, forced into the army at 14, fighting in wars and losing a leg to a land mine, becoming an outcast and then saved by a foreign charitable organization.It is fascinating to see the war relics (and was the first time we had actually handled these old guns), but the highlight was the history from the guide.A must see. It was as good as the temples.

Interesting history of the wars.. We visited here, not sure what to be expecting. We paid the nominal $5 entry fee, but who can complain as it goes towards the people working here, and they are all injured war veterans who can't get a job anywhere else due to injuries. Our free guide, included in the ticket price, was very knowledgeable about the guns, missiles, grenades, mines and tanks on display. Yes, they are all rusted war relics, but it is a first hand insight in to the atrocity of war and the brutality it inflicts on societies. It takes about an hour, and all the members in our small group were visibly moved by the stories and photos and things that we saw. We all offered our guide a few small additional $ as well.

Moving and interesting history from guide. I has little interest in looking at tanks and weapons and was concerned this would be the focus of the museum. There certainly are tanks and weapons but the guide (Tom) is what made this museum come to life. He shared history and his own personal story and it was moving and sad. I would highly recommend a visit to this museum to better understand the impact the wars of the last century have had on the Cambodian people.

Junkyard of rusty war machines. If one is interested in seeing old and damaged rusty war machines, then this is the right place to go. The machines, mainly from China, Soviet Union and the USA, were used in the war. I'm not keen in looking at these worn out machines but my presence here helps me to understand and appreciate what the country and people have gone through. There are many interesting places to visit around Siem Reap and I would prefera to spend more time visiting other places like Ta Prohm, Bayon Temple, Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Banteay Srei, Banteay Samre, Baphoon Temple, etc.

A Must Go experience. Having been to the famous war museum at Ho Chi Minh city in Vietnam some years ago, I just about swore off any kind of such places in the future where I was simply revolted by the rhetoric and glorification of war. This war museum in Siem Reap however, is a completely different kettle of fish.It was an easy afternoon where our tuk-tuk driver suggested the war museum. I was not interested at all however, we did go in the end and it was an enlightening experience for me. The museum looked more like an open air park with displays set up in a shack like structures with old planes, tanks and heavy vehicles from USA, Russia and China on display in the middle of the area, depicting the conflict era from the 60's and 70's.Unlike most war museums, everything featured here were stockpiles of old and rusty machines of war which included guns, bombs and land mines. There is a US$5 entrance fee per person and it comes with a free guide for the tour. Interestingly, all the guides were war veterans who suffered some sort of disability such loss of limbs.Our guide Soon, came forward with a slight limp and offered to take us on the tour. He was dressed in army fatigues and I did not know what to expect. He spoke very good English although he apologised for his "poor" command. When asked, he said he endeavoured to learn English as much as possible so that visitors could understand him clearly.Soon was "conscripted" into the military at the age of 14 which also saw his parents killed before his eyes. He pointed to my 12 year old nephew and remarked that he was very fortunate not to have to experience such atrocities in life. It was stirring and moving as Soon described his life or the lack of quality of life rather with virtually lack of emotion or so I thought. Soon began to show the different land mines and how they worked, I could visualise the cruelty that man has created to maim and kill other human beings.At the end of the tour which took about 30mins, Soon sometimes looked vamp and unemotional as if just telling a story but I could see the emotional scars left on him and the rest of the veterans. However, I was left feeling shaken and then enlightened with a positive message from Soon that war serves no purpose and no benefit.This "boneyard" of machines may look very sorry looking and dull but the revelation is in the people working there, promoting a very important message for all of us to share.
War museum. We had an amazing guide today, my husband, myself and two teenage boys were very moved, me to tears by the stories shared and photo displays. The boys also enjoyed the planes, tanks ect
Interesting !. Was glad we went to this museum. Make sure you take a guide to appreciate everything you see. Definitely learnt a lot about the history of the Khmer Rouge.

Excellent History. wanting to know the history behind the Cambodian Civil War, this is a place to visit only $5 for entrance and with a free guide which will give you so much information. You can spend as much time as needed to read about the mine victims as well...

Remnant of Cambodian History. If you are a fan of history, this place is worth a visit.This museum houses some battle gears from the Cambodian civil war.It has entrance fee of $10 which includes a guide who will show you around the most interesting stuff in the museum. The guides are volunteers who were war victims as well. Our guide is a landmine victim who lost his one leg.

More like a junkyard. Frankly, it is not much of a museum ... while the grounds were generally well-kept, the exhibits were not well-maintained, if at all. If you go expecting to see lots of refurbished military equipment and weapons on display, you will be sorely disappointed. Lots had been written about the 'free' guides but surely any well-traveled tourist should know better. For me, my guide was the 'main attraction'. His accounts of his life from a child soldier to a veteran fighting for different sides and his post-war trauma were believable. We chatted as we strolled around the place. He did mention that his income came solely from tips but at no time did he asked directly or pressured me to make a donation. In short, if you just wished to take some snapshots posing in front of a tank or other military hardware, I suggest that you give this place a miss. However, if you want a wider perspective of that very turbulent period or having visited the Killing Fields or S-21 in Phnom Penh, then a visit will provide a clearer picture of the events from 1970s till the 1990s.

war museum. We decided to goo here after doing all the temples, I took my mates son who is 13 with me and chose a free guide offered to us as we walked into the main area .. don't do this by yourself take a guide ...MY mates son loved the experience.... whilst I enjoyed the informative guide who without his input I would of defiantly been disappointed in the Museum ..you are able to see old battle armaments and physically touch and hold relics guns etc , I recommend this Museum as a great side visit and for $5 is good value and doesn't hurt the hip pocket .

Lots of War Trash, Some Original War Photos, Little War Information. I think I read in past reviews that this museum is free. If that was the case, it is no longer free now. There is now a $5 fee per person to enter which, considering the fact that everything inside is just battlefield rubble, is way overpriced. If the cost was a dollar, maybe two, it would probably be appropriate for what you get to see. The only reason we even paid to enter was because we had spent half the afternoon trying to find the place. Inside, there is one badly damaged Hip helicopter, a partially disassembled jet, the destroyed hulk of a T-54, several destroyed BTRs and other armored vehicles, and numerous artillery pieces, small arms, and landlines. When all was said and done it only took us a bit over 30 minutes to see everything inside and we were back on our way.
Museum. We found the museum guide very informative. He told us stories that gave us an insight into the history of many of the machinery displayed.

Excellent Tour, Learnt So Much. Went here on Saturday as part of a tour and were shown around by Tom, a former soldier who lost his arm in a landmine explosion. He was very friendly and chatty and gave us a lot of the history of the museum, the war, and Cambodia in general. You get the feeling there is still a lot of animosity towards other countries like Vietnam, but he still had a welcoming smile and even cracked a few jokes. When he took us to where some landmines were still in the ground, and told a member of our party, "You first", you had to smile. We're going back again tomorrow to see more of the museum

A Must see in Siem Reap. This was not a tripped I planned but after two days of temples I was ready for something different. I hired a Tuk Tuk to take me to the "new market" and he asked if I would like to go see the land mine museum? Or the war Museum? On A whim I decided to go here to theWar Museum. It is a small outdoor museum with many many tanks, cannons and various artillery. The guide comes with the 5$ entrance fee and the guide is what makes this museum! You must accept the guide and hear their personal story and the story of Cambodia from the 60's through the nineties! even thou it was heart wrenching it was very personal and each guide is a veteran of the war with a missing limb. I was so touched that I donated all of the money I had with me ..... sure it was only 20 bucks but that is a miracle because I am not the type to donate to people during my travels.

Lost of rust and not much else. We came here on the basis if tripadvisor reviews however it appears that having a guide makes or breaks the experience. No guides were available and no one seemed to really care that we were there. All of the vehicles have a sign telling you what they are but that's it. One tip if you do go - make sure if you get a tuk tuk that you arrange a fee for him to wait off you to take you back as there are no other tuk tuks waiting around. As we didn't have a guide we didn't think much to this museum.

Take the guide. This is a must see, make sure you take the Guide for real insight to what it was like in the war. Our Guide Sinat could show you how each mine worked then, with some, could show what had happened to him when he'd fallen victim to them. You can get on the tanks and touch the guns, much better than other war museums where everything's behind barriers.
Worth a visit. Glad to experience this, a strong chilling place that gives a real Insight into Cambodian war history.

For Real Experience - A REAL War Veteran is Required!. For many an enoumoured tourist to this Museum of unspeakable horrors, recently one of it's most popular "actual war veterans" - who started soldering as a child, in order to eat food, is no longer working at the museum. Such a shame. For the REAL experience this war veteran has expounded to tourists for many years (I have revisited on a number of ocassions - once with my Mother, who had the guide Keo Visna), and has many a heartrenching tales and accounts of the civil war in Cambodia (concluded in 1998), this is a sad loss! I hope he decides to work at the museum once more! The first time I visited and heard Visna's account of the war, I was tearful, and without question I voluntarily and happily provided a tip to this man with amazing courage, with a "no-nonsense, honest" & "this is what happened" guided tour. The complete opposite to my experience in other SEA war museums. I would think that many a foreign tourist after having a tour from Keo Visna, have seen first hand, the affects of "Post Traumatic Stress Disorder". And yet Cambodian Govt. soldiers fighting the Khmer Rouge, retired, have no psychological support at all, due to the ravishing affects the war had on a country built from scratch afterwards, unfortunately! They only have each other! A highly recommended experience with Keo Visna!

Great Museum Must Visit!. This museum wasn't part of my "tour-list" before I visited Siem Reap Cambodia, but boy, was I glad that my tuk-tuk driver recommended this place to me. When I got there, a war veteran tour guide welcomed me and asked If I wanted to listen to his experience during the war, he started talking about his life and the history of the Cambodian war. He also mentioned about the how Cambodia is doing as a country today. This was a great learning experience for me and I think that you'll find it amazing to hear their stories and get to see and even touch all the machinery they used during the war. This museum is Awesome! Please visit. This is real stuff!

Siem Reap War Museum. If you grew up during the Vietnam war era this museum is interesting. Also go to the Killing Field i Siem Reap if just to honor the horrible things that happened to the Cambodians.

an unexpectedly good place to visit. I only went to this place just to kill time before my next destination and my driver/guide recommended this place to me, and I was glad that I stumbled upon this gem. Like the Landmine museum, the War Museum also gives its visitors a good picture about Cambodia's war history. I was amazed at all the machinery that were used during the war. Please visit this place whenever you visit Siem Reap.

Please visit this place!. Our guide, Keo Veasna, made the whole experience come alive. Sure, all of the exhibits are dated but that's all they had to fight with! It's a realistic portrayal of the truth with no extra jazz. The museum is staffed by war veterans who have all suffered great physical and emotional trauma. They are passionate about telling their story ...and what a story Keo had to tell!Loved this place! Please, please go along. It's only $5 to get in plus an optional tip for your guide (who is otherwise free of charge). Fantastic!

An absolute eye opener and must do!!!!. Visited the War museum in Siem Reap ok so it's not much to look at compared to other museums around the world, but the guides that take you around free of charge talk of their own experiences. We had the most beautiful genuine person Veasna Keo. I would highly recommend you take the time to visit. The exhibits are left out in all weather conditions and looking a bit worse for wear but the information boards tell the story.. $5 entrance fee but please donate to the guides without their time and knowledge you won't get a true picture of the heartache people have suffered.

Far better than I expected after reading mixed reviews here. Went with my girlfriend and after reading some reviews on here expected the worst to be honest. Left feeling not only surprised at a nice tour but also very glad I went. Paid $5 at the gate and we walked into be met by a guide Tom. Who asks you if you want a free guide or not. The guide is a must. He took us to an area where there were information boards and explained to us about the war which we knew nothing about.He told us his story and it was certainly from the heart and an eye opener. Guy lost his arm, family and everything he owned. The museum is sad in the fact that the tanks, guns etc are left to rot but to be honest they are making the most of what they've got. His story's and explanation of the area, weapons were spot on and we both really enjoyed it.At the end of the tour we gave him a donation which he happily accepted then he left us to do our own thing. No problem or harassment at all.Well worth a visit. It certainly is no great museum and I feel sad that in the future the weapons and machinery will go to waste but with no funding they really are making the most of what they've got. Definetly a must visit but get a guide!
khmer rouge suck!!!. this was really creepy!!!to see first hand to what extend a man can be brutal, inhuman and insane!!!food for thought!!!

Worth a visit.. It's not your average museum with glass cases and audio visual displays everywhere but it's definitely worth a visit. The staff here have experienced the civil war first hand and have a compelling personal story to tell. I think it's important to have an understanding of cambodias history as it was only 14 years ago that this terrible war ended. So make the effort to go here! (maybe even at the start of your trip)

Must see!. Our tuk-tuk driver took us to this outdoor museum, which is not a pristine, organized set-up, but worth visiting. We linked up with a tour guide who explained how some of the weapons and artillery were used and the damage caused, talked about the land mines display, and finally he talked about his own experiences in the war, and how it had affected his life. Not pretty, but well worth a visit to help understand the horrors of war.

Wow. We have been to a few war museums around the world and this one would have to be the worst. We asked about getting a tour guide and were told to look around and then find someone at the end if we had any questions. The content in this open museum was mainly scrap metal. It is not worth the $5 or the time it takes to get there and look around.

Had high expectations that are not met. I read reviews that this place is a must go, with a guide. I planned to go to get a guide as well to help explain the significance of stuff and share their experiences but when I was there, I was just told to walk around on my own and that there are "English signs, you can read". And when I went to read the signs, it just mentions on when and where each machine or weapon was made and destroyed. The things I was attracted to were the guns you can hold, pose and take a picture with and the cute stray puppies playing around the place. It took me 10 mins to finish the tour(I cut short cause i didn see a point reading the "signs" that I don't understand) and I feel like I wasted my 5usd at the end. I wouldn't say not to visit this place but I think unless you can ensure that there's a guide for you when you are there, you're better off not going because its a little off the city and it'll cost you quite a bit for the tuktuk trip there and back.

History. Spent abt 1 hour wondering around here, entrance 5 US dollars, very interesting looking at the various tanks, helicopter etc used in the war, you can wonder around with no hassle, pick up rifles etc, well worth the visit.

Very personal experience. The museum is full of guns and machines and bombs. What makes this an amazing experience is the personal attention by one of the gentleman working there. He fought in the war. He lost his fingers. He lost his friend in one of the tanks. He keeps the femur of his friend on top of the tank and he showed us the ashes in the tank of his friend who died there. He explains all the dates and people associated with the war. It was quite an emotional experience.

Interesting and disturbing. 5$ Entrance. We were there for one hour without a guide. It was late and we were the only ones in the museum. I climbed into the helicopter and the jet which was great fun. The rest of the tour (which was less than an hour) showed destroyed tanks, artillery and guns you could take out and "try". They also showed land mines and photos of amputated people. It gave me a good view on how disgusting war is and how much we should appreciate that we can visit Cambodia these days. For the value you get it's quite pricey but its a nice short activity. No need for me to come back but would recommend if you are interested in history. For the full experience you should probably pay more and take a guide though.

A humble experience. Coming from a former war torn country, It's humbling to see what the Cambodian people have gone through. Different nations and war mongers, for selfish reasons absolutely ravaged this beautiful country and this experience brings some of that to light. Worthwhile experience. Any tips left are nothing compared to what some of these guys had to endure for decades!

Decent collection. Not a very large place, and all the supposedly ''voluntary'' tour guides all reminded the tourists to leave donations once their tour was over. He called himself ''Cat'', showing us his prosthetic leg, and parts of his body where he was supposedly shot as well as pieces of shrapnel from mines still embedded under his skin.Pretty decent collection of old tanks, mines, guns, an almost intact helicopter and plane on display as well. Short visit, and a bit pricey if you ask me.. when you factor in both the entrance fee and the tourguide's ''donations''

Must see if you are looking for Cambodian history. Very few tourists were there. My wife and I spend about an hour there with a leaving miracle guide, the place is just full of bombed or destroyed tanks and a couple of war flights and grenades,old weapons and land mines. The guide is a must in this visit although he was annoying us with his personal life details and is always asking for money as u must give him a tip as he is not payed by the museum but that guy had several wounds from war and gave us a great detail lesson about the Cambodian war.

It was good to see. It was good to see. The guide really helps with his own war time stories. It is run mostly by amputee war victims who were tossed aside after they were injured. They have plenty of old tanks, old mines. Takes about half hour.

felt like a tourist rip-off. I seriously question if the guide had been Khmer Rogue as he claimed. His dates didn't line up (he said he was captured by the KR at age 15 in 1975, but based on his current age claim he had to be 11 then), and he sat down at the end of the tour, made a big show of rubbing and showing me his artificial leg, which he said was lost by a landmine. He certainly had an artificial leg, but his entire tour and demeanor made me feel as thou he was only after my money, reminding me to leave a donation, even thou I paid $5 to get in. None of it rung true, although they did have a collection of rusty tanks and weapons.

Moving Experience!. We visited this museum with low expectations. After a full day of touring the temples in the hot sun, we were looking for a different type of experience. This turned out to be a very moving and informative experience. Our guide who we "hired" (donation expected)at the entrance was named Keo Veasna. He is veteran who told a heartfelt story of his experience beginning as a 16 year old soldier. Landmine injuries and loss of friends as well as a loss of his parents under the khmer rouge made for a genuine experience that my family will never forget.

Good but pricey at $5.00. Most things on exhibit are Soviet made from the 70s when the Vietnamese rolled through after kicking out the US. Tanks, jet, helicopter, munitions, various weapons and a land mine display. They will guide you or you can walk the area alone as there are signs and boards in English. Check out my photos. You can pose with some of the weapons on display. Immature but in a cool way ; ) One hour or so is enough time to see all on offer. Worth a look-see and better than the Landmine Museum.

Great guides. Visit this museum and experience a former soldier's life story. It it a great place to visit with teenagers. All young men who are thinking of joining the army, wil change their mind when listening to stories of the guides.

Simple but gut wrenching. If you are travellign with kids this might be the best way to introduce them to the Khmer Rouge without all the gory horror of S21 or the Killing Fields. Our guide, minus fingers from a land mine, guided us through and gave a frank and simple explanation of the horrors of the Khmer Rouge regime but also what happened up until 1999.

MUST VISIT!! Use a tour guide. We weren't expecting much when we arrived to the museum but as soon as our guide started telling us his story we knew it was going to be a very special experience. I HIGHLY recommend this to anyone who has any interest in Cambodian history and personal accounts from the men who fought in the civil war. The tour guide was free but these guys deserve the donation that is requested at the end both for the fact that they volunteer their time to educate others and the fact they are willing to share such personal and tragic stories. Not to be missed.

Well worth the time. We visited this museum yesterday. An eye opening and confronting experience brought to life by our guide who was a child soldier and a land mine victim. I highly recommend taking up the offer of a guide as the descriptions and explanations provided really added to the experience for us.

Rusty old display. I enjoyed this display, but I think they could spend a few dollars putting wheels and tracks back on the armoured vehicles and paint them up. Overall a good experience. Well worth the trip.

A humble, eye opening experience. A museum run by war veterans. $5 p/p and a free tour guide who spoke excellent English. Our tour guide Tom showed us around and spoke about the history of the war and did so in a very humbling way. A donation is requested at the end and so it should be as they do a wonderful job there.

Eye opening. Despite the trek out of town and therefore a (comparatively) more expensive tuk-tuk ride, the war museum was worth the visit. Our guide was something else, full of charisma and charm, and with a remarkable and saddening story to tell. Despite all the hardship, cruelty and misfortune he and other victims of the war and its aftermath had been through he was inspiring in his forgiveness, positivity and good humour. The museum is made up of huts with displays and outdoor exhibits of tanks and other machines of war. There is a helicopter and plane also. A pretend minefield with tripwires makes for another interesting and nerve-wracking experience. Well worth a visit, mostly for the first hand accounts of the guide.

Interesting. As we walked in, we were greeted by a tour guide (entry is $5p/p, guide is free of charge, but tips at the end are appreciated), you can choose to walk around without the guide, but I recomend you do.Its interesting to see and have a feel of the very weapons used in the war. It was a little bit hard to understand our guide, but he took his time to tell his story (he lost his leg on a landmine) and answer all of our questions

Incredible experience. After asking our tuk tuk driver a bit more about the history of Cambodia, he recommended we visited a war museum which was not far and only cost $5. It is very much worth every penny but I would definitely recommend the tour guide who only charges in tips. Just looking at the museum, you don't think much of it; located outside with a dozen tanks and military equipment. You soon learn the field is what used to be a land mine, and the tour guide who is a war veteran will give you a detailed personal story. It is an extremely humbling experience and if you go in holding no judgement, you don't possibly come out the same. I highly recommend this trip. Worth every penny and more.

An experience not to be missed by any age group.. We basically were looking for things to do as we had visited all the temples, the national museum and seen enough market stalls for a while. Thank god that we did as the experience saw us lean as much about the more recent pain of the Cambodian people in the last 2 centuries than those 1000 years ago.We were led around by a guide who was himself a victim of a landmine and had lost his family to through KR. What we learnt gave real substance to our visit to SR. The guide is free, entry is $5.....but we tipped him $40USD...which is nothing when you hear the story....If you have kids take them as it's not confronting like the killing fields, but educational enough to gain a valuable outcome.

A must do experience in Siem Reap. An out if the way location that was well worth the visit. We chose to have a guide who is a soldier and who lost his arm fighting for the Khmer Rouge when he was only 14. Hearing of his own experiences and the wealth of his knowledge brought the experience to life. Fees for the guide was by donation with the money going to help land mine victims.

Visit NOW - eye opening experience. I went to this museum expecting nothing, down a little dirt track that looks utterly hopeless, $5 entry looked steep at the time but I wish I had paid more. They had an enormous range of old military machinery and guns, tanks, sub marine cars etc. all old USSR stuff but quite well preserved. Walked around alone but should have asked for a your as I got chatting to Keo Veansa afterwards. He is a guide there (volunteer) and ex army. He told me all sorts of incredible things and showed me videos, talked with me about his family and opinions, translated for me to talk to an ex Khamer Rouge soldier who's legs had been blown off in a land mine. It was incredible and a very personal experience. I sobbed in the tuk tuk home. Would do it again in a heart beat.

Informative experience. This place used to be a landmine and which has now been cleared and declared safe. It costs $5 for an entrance ticket and guides (all war veterans) offer their services for free but you are more than welcome to offer donations at the end of your visit which will go to supporting other war veterans or landmine victims who are unable to find employment. We got Tom as our guide, a war veteran who was very friendly and really wanted to share his story with us. He talked us through the different displays of weapons and tanks, and then left us free to wander around and absorb everything at our own pace.My friends and I have found during our trip to Cambodia that many locals who are old enough to remember the reign of the Khmer Rouge are very eager to educate tourists on their nation's history and are happy to answer questions. After our tour, we had some questions but did not want to interrupt his tour so we approached another war veteran sitting near the entrance. Unfortunately, he did not speak English but our TukTuk driver came to the rescue and acted as our interpreter. Even though there was a language barrier, the veteran's willingness to entertain our questions was evident as he told us of his experiences and the extreme efforts to find missing family members after the war.I would strongly recommend other travellers to make a visit to this museum as there is so much more to Cambodian history than the magnificence of Angkor Wat.

visit if you are tired of temples. After a long day visiting temples around Angkor Wat. We have decided to have a light schedule before departing Siem Reap. After reading some positive reviews from Tripadvisor we picked War Museum as it's just a 15 mins short ride with tuk-tuk from where we stayed.We were told the US$5 entry ticket per person will include a tour guide and we were more than happy and ready to pay for tips if we do get a decent experience.
