Unfortunately, right immediately when we entered the site, a healthy guy (probably uninjured war veteran) asked us to buy drink. When we said no maybe later he just walked away. I went over and asked him where are the tour guides and he straight away answered me that I will have to pay separately to get one. That pissed me off and I simply walk away and decided to tour it on my own. The whole site is not crowded (less than 10 tourists including us) and there are a bunch of "war veterans" sitting there drinking and playing cards. These people just need to be more genuine and sincere to get their tips but they don't seems to bother.The whole site is filled with metal junks which are left out under the severe weather, heat and rain over the years. There are small huts with those old weapons which anyone can touch freely. I am sure some can even steal it without being noticed. There are some printed old photos with plain explanation pasted on boards but all in very poor condition.It is a pity that those are valuable history for the country but were left to rot. US$5 is not a small amount and I am sure the management can do better to maintain and promote the site properly.

highly recommend a visit here.... My visit to the War Museum i regard as a definate highlight of my visit to Siem Reap. I would encourage every visitor to make the time to visit. The entry fee is only $5 , & the museum is staffed by tour guides who have their own personal experiences from the 'war years'. The museum has a collection of weaponery and artllery from the war, but more so offers a unique insight into what happened during these years through personal documentation of tour guides at the museum. Our guide Keo Veasna was ju

Informative and interesting place. The war museum was an interesting place to visit and very educational. Although it was heartbreaking to visit, it is good to remember what has happened. The entry fee was minimal and we had Tom as our tour guide (it is free but make sure tip at the end!). Tom was an excellent tour guide. If you have the chance and time to go here it is worth it.

If you've seen enough temples. If you've seen enough temples and what to see something of Cambodias more recent history, then I would recommend a visit to the War Museum at Kaksekam Villiage, Siem Reap.Only $5 pp entrance and you get a free guide, though it's expected to give a tip at the end of the tour, which these guys need since they're all injured veterans who work here unpaid but still have families to feed.This site used to be a minefield, which was cleared by the Cambodian Mine Action Centre, and now has a selection of weapons from the 30 year civil war from small arms to Tanks and aircraft. There was also a mass grave on the site. The bones and skulls found have been relocated to the Killing Fields memorial.The guides are real life victims of the war, forced into conflict as child soldiers, both Government and Kmer Rouge. Take time to visit and support their mine clearing programme and help support these veterans and their families.

Small Museum. Nothing much to see but there has a lot of mango trees. My tour guide picked a lot of mangoes for me for free... haha...The entrance ticket is US$5 / person. Opening hour start from 8am to 5pm.
Great Insight!. Very helpful ex soldier guide who has many story's on all the weapons and life during the war. Only just outside town too.

Highlight of our SE Asia trip. We've been throughout Thailand, Laos, Vietnam and Cambodia for a couple of months - this museum is on the top of our list.People who have given this place a terrible/poor rating have obviously just quickly walked through the place, without a guide, and aren't impressed by its small size and weathered displays.The thing that did it for us was the "free" (donations greatly appreciated) guided tour by one of the few veterans of the civil war. Ours had his right leg blown off by a land mine, two bullet wounds to his other leg, and a bullet wound in his stomach which had taken out his gall-bladder. After his parents and siblings were killed, when he was 13, he joined the army. Even through all this, he joked that he didn't do much in the war, as he spent most of the time in hospital beds!!When travelling, I always find the most rewarding experiences to be those where you learn and experience something about the local culture/history directly from the locals. That is why this museum is so good.

Every visitor to Siem Reap should visit here. Our visit here was incredibly powerful...having a first hand account of the brutality of the Khumer Rouge regime was very moving. It only costs $5US per person, which includes a personal tour guide. I would strongly recommend the tour guide as his story was the must valuable part of this visit.

sobering. We were a little daunted when our tuktuk first dropped us off at the entrance of the museum, as it looked very isolated and abandoned. Entry was US$5, which we are told goes towards the upkeep of the museum, as well as to the war veterans who run it. Many of the war veterans were injured during the war, and you see them around the entrance of the museum dressed in their uniforms, but missing limbs. A guide for the tour is free, but donations are appreciated (which we were happy to give as well). Our tour is conducted by one of the above mentioned war veterans, who shared about his own personal experiences and also about how he lost his arm. Was amazed by how he managed to keep his sense (dark) humor despite the horrors he experienced. The weaponry and machines displayed here may not be as impressive as those of other museums, but the stories the guides have to tell are worth a listen.

Amazing. We went to the war museum as two 19year old girls, upon arrival it's not as what you expect a museum to be like. However our tour guide, Tom, was an absolute inspiration. Having experiences the Cambodian civil war, he has a in depth knowledge of the background and the effects it's had upon the Cambodian people. Very peaceful area and as you wonder through the orchard it's hard to imagine that all the machines around you have killed countless people. We've been staying in Siem reap for a week and its been one our favourite things we've done, most definitely get a guide as you make a donation at the end but its really worth it.

History left out to rot. The many tanks, guns and other long range weapons on display (some dating from the 20s/30s)are fantastic to see. Unfortunately they have been left out in all weathers and are deteriorating badly. The museum appears to be privately owned by the veterans of the late 70s civil war and pay somewhat towards their upkeep.. Unfortunately this comes at the cost of the weapons and vehicles themselves which will doubtless be gone in a few years

War museum Siem Reap. I was disappointed to see that some visitors had scored the little war museum at Siem Reap 4 for 'poor' and 10 for 'terrible'. The contributors obviously went there thinking that they were going to see a museum on a scale and size such as ones in maybe Hanoi or Ho Chin Minh City. Do not go with the expectation of something comparable. It's not. The contributors couldn't have talked to any of the guides there either otherwise they would have learned some very important facts, i.e. this museum is basically a small, privately owned facility set up by solders discharged from the Cambodian Army, for the most part with severe injuries and NO financial compensation from the Cambodian Government. Go spend some time with, for example, one of the guides Suon Rottana who was forced into the army by the Khmer Rouge at the age of 14 years and who had his two parents shot in front of him when they resisted..... discharged after 20 years, only one leg after a landmine took the other one, no payout or 'superannuation'... he like others at the museum survive on what they can glean from visitor entry fees. Or go talk to Suon's friend....no legs and confined to a wheel chair, again after a landmine incident. Yes, the museum is a little disorganised, but they have some interesting military hardware and weapons and a sad illustration of the bad days in Cambodia under the terrible rule of Khmer Rouge. Visit, talk and learn. It a valuable 1 - 2 hours of your time at Siem Reap.
Learn about Cambodia. No better way to learn about the country than to hear first hand what has gone on hear internally over last 40 years.

Remembrance of the grim past.. Beware of the location star on the map - it is wrong!The War Museum is situated on Highway 6 - not that far off from the Airport.Kaksekam Village, Sra Nge Commune.Opening Hours due to the leaflet given is 8:00 - 17:30.Well - it was kind of an educating visit, where I found the pictures displayed the most informative, and a real good reminder of the grim past.My friend though found the tanks etc. to be "fun" to look at.Opposite another post here, we weren't given a guide to take us around. Which I though think could have kept us there for ages.It was ok, nothing more.5 USD - well with a western salary it wouldn't be too much, but for local visitors (including neighouring countries) I find way too much.

Good to see!. We visited the Siem Reap War Museum and there was a $5 entry fee and it was definitely worth it, especially for Gary and my brother in law Brett who have 45 years army experience between them. This fee includes a guide however we did not use him as we just wanted to take our time looking around.There was so much to look at and play with, tanks, anti aircraft guns, rocket launchers, planes, etc. If you have a Military history you will like the War Museum, we found it very interesting and really enjoyed our time there.

Good to see. It was good to see. The guide really helps with his own war time stories. It is run mostly by amputee war victims who were tossed aside after they were injured. They have plenty of old tanks, old mines. Takes about half hour.

Eye opening on what took place in Cambodia.. We took a very early flight from Phnom Penh to Siem Riept a day trip to see the Temples and we were collected at the airport by our pre arranged Tuk Tuk driver.We were all Templed out by mid afternoon and as our flight back to Phnom Penh was not till latter in the day we asked the Tuk Tuk driver to take us to the War Museum he was not that keen as he wanted us to go to another placeWe said no and were off to the Museum about a 10 minute drive from town,on arrival we paid our admission $5 each and a guide came up to us and offered us a guide around the Museum and said it was free.He was most informative telling us about the dreaded land mines and the different types of weapons used in the long war and the countries they originated from were very interesting.He told us that he had been wounded three times and had lost his fingers on his left hand.Looking around all of staff had missing limbs as a result of the war that did not end until 1998 not as we thought in 1979.He told us about all the different types of land mines made of metal and the plastic type that can not be detected by mine detectors and finally he took us to a tank that had been blown up killing his 21 year old friend.The name of this knowledgable guide is " Keo Veasna "

Living History. it is hard to believe that till 1997 people in Siam Reap where still fighting, now you can not find any nicer people around then in Cambodia. we had a very well informed guide (Veteran) that gave us allot of inside as where the arms came from, and how live was during this horrible period of there history. well worth visiting, but had to under stand that humans still did not learn anything.

Another view of the war. As with most museums you really benefit from having a guide, particularly one with first hand experience. Our guide was Mr Keo Veasna who had been injured whilst fighting in the war and he also lost his best friend. The guides are free but you are expected to pay them a tip.The museum focuses on landmines and the awful damage that they do. It was interesting to see the large variety although the damage they do is horrific. Some even seemed to be designed to encourage children to pick them up because they looked like a small ball. Others looked like pencil cases. The museum has plenty of photographs from the war and many damaged tanks, etc. There's even the remnants of a bomb made in the UK!!!!!

Interesting but $5 entry fee too steep. This is a proper museum like we used to have at home before they took out all the old stuff and replaced it with hands-on exhibits and picture boards. The vehicles are in a terrible state as most were literally taken from the battlefield and laid here to rest. I must admit to be disappointed there was not an actual museum building with exhibits, just a few shacks containing shells, weapons and photos. I liked it but it is more for history buffs and no good for kids.Remember to take plenty of drink as they charge $2 for a small bottle of water!

Must see! Our guide Tom was wonderful!. If you like history or weapons, or want to learn about Cambodia, visit this museum! We were going to explore on our own, but luckily Tom convinced us that we would enjoy the museum more with a guide. He was so right! There is a $5 per person admission fee. After you enter, a guide will offer his time free of charge and you can make a donation to him at the end if you want (but there is no pressure). How could you not take advantage of the real-life knowledge of a veteran who experienced the history you are viewing.The museum is outdoors, set in a small forested area which used to be a mine field, and there are chickens milling about. You will see tanks, artillery, guns, defused land mines/bombs, and photos. There is also a former mass grave – the bodies now are entombed in a memorial in Siem Reap. You can pick up and check out some of the weapons and even climb on the tanks. There is a small gift shop with books, shirts, and ice cold drinks.Our guide Tom was conscripted at age 14 in the infantry and lost his arm in the war. He told us about some of his experiences and his family. He answered all of our many questions and was a gracious host.Please do visit this museum and accept the services of a guide. You will help the veterans and learn first- hand about this terrible time in Cambodia’s history.

Fantastic guide. My partner an I went to the war museum as he is very interested in these sorts of things, I had no expectations of it only that it would be sad. We had also herd alot about scamming at the gate. We arrived and we were the only people there and there was no signs if anyone trying to scam us. Just the one ticket booth.Upon walking in we were approached by a lovely man asking if we would like a guide, Mr Keo. He said there is no cost just that it would be appreciated if we made a donation after. We agreed to have him as our guide and it was definitely worth it.Without a guide the museum is more of a collection of artefacts from the war, so I would reccommend if you go there get a guide. Mr Keo was a very gentle person who had unfortunately been through alot. He had scars and 3 fingers missing from where he had experienced mines blowing up. He took us around explaining what everything was, telling us general information about the war but most memorably he shared his storey with us. He talked about how his parents were killed and he joined for food at the age of 16. He spoke of his friends, many of which died and even showed us a T 54 where one of his friends were blown up still containing remenants of his bones. He also told us of his general life and day to day hardships.At the end of the tour he was not pushy but only said any donations we gave would go toward helping his boy (an landmine orphan who he takes care of as he has no wife or children of his own) we gave him 15 but would have loved to give hundreds. I feel that without him this would have been a fairly mediocre experience but I am greatful that I got the time to meet and talk with Mr Keo and appreciate him sharing his storey with us, whilst it is very obvious how much it had afftected him by the pain in his eyes. I would definitely go back and have this experience again and I intend to on my next visit in the hopes to speak to him again. Do the meuseum and ask for MR Keo as your guide!

Sad. Its not so nice to think about war when you are on vacation but it is a good wakeup call as a reminder how evil some folk are. The guides, who I believe are all disabled veterans, are passionate about their stories and their conribution to the war effort. Facinating tales.As for the displays - I am not so positive. Really, its a collection of scrap metal going rusty which detracts from the carnage they have caused. There are some interesting displays of photos and story boards in the sheds on the perimeter of the museum.Felt uneasy giving the guide a donation of cash - would have preferred a collection box.

Take a Review of Your Life - And Feel Lucky!. Firstly: I find Mr Wilson C's review a little disappointing to say the least. In a place where wet season/monsoon rains prevail for a better part of the year, it is impossible to keep these pieces of used war material up to 30 years old in some cases, in shining condition. It is far from a modern day "New Car Sales Lot". A little insensitive is my thinking.Secondly: My review! There is nothing better or therapeutic than having a beer with Old Soldiers! Albeit they were not drinking beer because they were working - I was. Cold beer is available from their shop. Nice on a hot day after a tour and explanation of the horrors that gripped this country. Through my guide Sna, I was astonished (even after researching what I thought to be decent research) that the civil war didn't end in 1979 and the end of the Pol Pot Regime - IT ESCALATED and continued until 1998! The Khmer Rouge still having enough backing and power to resist Phnom Penh until this time.After Sna's very honest and at times heartbreaking account of the civil war, I was emotionally and physically beaten, so I opted for a very cold Heineken from their shop store. I was invited to sit with some of the guides, Sna, Mr Khom and Mr Ratanna. The sense of humour these old soldiers display after the horrors of combat astounded me! Genuine, lovely people who made me laugh until I was crying, with their highly developed and combined sense's of humour!This is a MUST see, DO ask for a guide! You will definitely appreciate how lucky you are after hearing first hand accounts of what it would be like to face and stare death in the face - EVERYDAY! It will make you appreciate your own life so much more. If you are up to it, you can even ask Mr Khom and Mr Ratanna to show you how to play Cambodian Chess if they are not busy.Mr Khom will say he is the best, Mr Ratanna will strongly oppose his opponent! All in the nicest friendly environment and in the nicest possible way!!!!!!

Disturbing but a good place to visit. We visited the land mine museum and was affected by the depth of history of violence and senselessness of war.Our guide was Mr. Keo, who himself is a landmine victim who started to serve in their military at the age of 17, being an orphan and with no other option in life.He was able to show us the atrocities of the regime of Pol Pot, and how Cambodians were eradicated whimsically to further Pol Pot's ambitions.The museum shows actual mines, tanks and armory used in the war, with pictures depicting the sad state of war.Please look for Mr. Keo, he will surely make your tour there meaningful.

a raw, visceral experience of what Cambodians have been through. While it's just a field with old tanks, guns, helicopters and mines, the cowboyness of it also lets you get closer to these things than you would anywhere else. I could even cock the barrel of any gun i saw, and get into the cockpit of the helicopter.Also, the guides here are all people who were there, so their personal experiences really paint a complete picture of what it was like to be there - pretty horrible.Our guide shared how he worked for the military for 14 years while his family was butchered back home, and how he finally retired when he lost his leg to a landmine.The photos in the exhibits need no words as well.While not recommended for children, i highly recommend this site as a raw, visceral experience of what Cambodians have been through.

Looks a bit run down. Before entering the site, I was asked if I needed a tour guide. I kindly declined because I preferred to walk around on my own w/o any interruptions. It was basically a junk yard of decommissioned tanks, weapons, artilleries, and a few flying planes. It's worth going only if you wanna see oxidized metal objects and able to identify the differences among all the different landmines and grenades. otherwise, skip it. I paid $5USD for the entrance fee.
Not big but interesting!. This is a little distance out of town but a nice tuk tuk ride. The tours are given by injured war veterans who can tell you quite a bit.

Fascinating experience. Our family visited the war museum and found it fascinating. True, there were few information panels, and much of military hardware was well past its best. But what made up for that was the opportunity to get so close to the exhibits - we could pick up many of the weapons, touch the tanks, peer inside the Chinese-built fighter plane and the Russian transport helicopter. The kids were particularly taken with the Kalashnikovs. It was great to be able to wander around freely and explore. We paid a small fee (a few dollars each) to get in, and declined the offer of a tour as we prefer to explore at our own pace. Before we left we bought some t-shirts, books and drinks at the gift shop, which we hoped would go towards supporting the museum and/or the ex-soldiers. If you don't know much about recent Cambodian history I'd recommend you read the history section in your guidebook before you visit - it will make the experience all the more meaningful.

RIP OFF. DO NOT GO, IT IS A WASTE OF TIME AND MONEY. DON"T TRUST ANYONE THEREdon't go it is a waste of time, read other reviews and you will see , it's a metal graveyard, nothing interesting and the people there just want to take your money, there is n no fee, you should only give a donation if you feel like it, but no, they make up the price as they feel, we got asked for $8 and realised soon that the person was a con and had no idea what he was saying. do not go there , even if the hotel or taxi driver recommends it, its rubbish, go and spend your money on a nice bottle of wine or whatever you fancy.

moving, eye opening experience. Our family visited the war museum and found it one of the most educational and touching experiences that we had in Cambodia. It was fascinating hearing the first hand accounts of the atrocities from the view of a ex-Khmer rouge soldier. Keo our guide was brilliant and we were humbled and greatful that he had the courage to share such personal heartbreaking stories. Well worth the visit and a great place to leave a donation to the victims of such horrific injuries from war and landmines.

I liked this more then Angkor Wat. Mr Keo Veasna let me start by saying you are a hero in your own right. You are the most amazing person ive ever met. To people reading this there probley just thinking yeah yeah same old stuff as the killing feild yada yada. NO this is more touching and emotionally draining than listening to the decide they give you in Phenom Pehn. This mans story is one of the hardest stories ive heard my friend and i and Keo were all about tearing up while he spoke. I would like if everyone that visited Siem Reap would come here and learn just how lucky we all are to come from stable countries. The work that Keo does here is outstanding. he has dedicated his WHOLE life to educating you and i to the horror of Pol Pot. PS my friend i put in $15 between the 2 of us. Please find 2 hours to go it was life changing for me and something i will never forget.

A must tour. very educational tour, our guide is an active servicemen that was in the action from the age of 14 years old, and lost a limb during combat, I've only heard of these things, it's a real eye opener, listening to him and then looking at various war machine is a shocker in it's self; but the mine field ( been made safe) really is horrific, This trip is a must, if you want to know more of the true facts of those dreadful years. It's a must to let the guide take you round, your gratitude is of your own choosing with no expectation, we found it greatly appreciated. The level is flat and everyone can visit.

Worth the trip. This is a very good place to learn more about the war from people who were actually involved in it rather than just reading about it in books.They have a lot of weapons and tanks which have quite literally been lifted from the battle fields. There aren't many details attached to any of them though so the 'free' guide is essential. We walked around with Mr Keo Veasna who was very informative and shared many of his own experiences of the war.The 'free' tour guide should really come with a museum specified suggested minimum donation as it is difficult to know what to give and must be very awkward for those who are confronted by their guide for not giving 'enough'. It's admirable that these veterans have chosen not to beg to survive and it must be harrowing to have to relive their horrific war memories several times a day for the entertainment of tourist but we should not be made to feel guilty for not 'donating' enough. Donations are supposed to be anonymous and should be gratefully received no matter now small.For the record we had no complaints regarding our donation to Mr Keo Veasna but have had unsatisfied receivers before.Also it's all outdoors so no good on a rainy day.

Amazing!!!. This is quite an eye opener, we had Tony as our guide and he was the most amazing person we have ever met and his story is quite sad, he lost a limb due to a land mine accident, its a very interesting museaum and the sad thing is the people there are still suffering from these land mines, mostly children and there are pics to show what they are going through. A must to see!!!

Very interesting, lots of exhibits , guide was good. Most of the guides are missing limbs, etc from the conflict, so have some harrowing stories to tell. Very interesting museum, 5US entry p.p., tuk-tuk is about 10US return (for up to 4 people, ask them to wait)Guides are a bit cheeky, suggesting an appropriate tip could be 20-30US p.p (And put the group in an awkward position when asking for this), I would suggest something more like 5US p.p. tip, which is what we did.

Sad stories told by its protagonists.. After a couple of days visiting the archeological sites, we thought it was time to know more about the painful more recent history of the country. Our guide was a former khmer rouge combatant who lost a leg with a personal land-mine. He described most of the horrors he personally suffered and explained in detail how mines work. It was simply breathtaking.The museum itself consists of a great deal of deactivated mines, some armored vehicles used during the wartime as well as some exploded bombs. They even have an helicopter and a Chinese airplane. They also have a large amount of pictures of the killing fields and khmer soldiers. I guess that the most valuable part of the visit was being able to hear the stories from a person who actually suffered the atrocities of the war. As far as I can tell, there were several guides in the museum in the same case.It is an experience that makes you think.

Sad mixed feelings. Soooooo sad what happened during and after the war. Agent Orange - cant believe human beings would use such an awful killer chemical against other human beings. Death and deformity. Sick!!!This was such an eye opener for my husband and I. We were drained after touring,reading and taking in what happened.

painful stories but one of the best experiences. it is quite small place but really full . we didn't spend there more than one hour but we had so much in this hour . we met one of the guides who works there who was a soldier and has great personal stories to share . the museum itself has so many weapons and even the burnt tanks there still have bones and skulls of whoever was there and got killed . the area was a mine field and still lots of spots there have mines still and you seriously need to stay out of them . we went through the place with aching hearts to see the weapons that were used in the very sad stories we heard . you can get so close to the items and touch them , you can still see inside and see the burnt cloths and sometimes parts of whoever inside . all that takes you back to that time and make you feel the pain and the experience of being there . i hope to this country to never experience anything like this again and the wonderful people there to live in peace and prosperity

Nice Collection But Not Maintained. I'd have given this five stars but sadly all of the exhibits are just kind of left under the weather to rust, rot and fade away. I'm not looking to see everything shiny new as it's all come from wars but I think they need to at least apply some preservation to everything if they want it to still be view-able in another 20 years!Anyway, the number of vehicles, plus the helicopter (very impressive and way larger than expected!) and the fighter jet make this very worthwhile. I didn't take a guide as I was with my 3 year old daughter and don't want to traumatize her with having to explain why there are limbs missing. I don't feel a guide is necessary here anyway because most exhibits are well labeled, sometimes with a tiny snipped of background information that makes it interesting, such as where they found a tank and some more context.Finally worth a mention is that they don't seem bothered about people interacting with exhibits. I wouldn't recommend climbing all over them but there was no one or no sign saying you can't. This includes the hand held weapons, so if you are not feeling too solemn and sober then why not pick one up for a photo op?Did I say the fighter jet (Chinese made Mig if I remember correctly) was really cool and a rare to see find?

worth it. I learnt more from a tour at this place than I did from going to S-21 and the killing fields in Phnom Penh. It was very informative and eye opening. As sad and confronting as it was I would recommend it for anyone visiting Siem Reap to gain a deeper understanding of what this country has been through. Yes the "free guide" is by donation only, but considering what they teach you and how much they've been through, they definitely deserve it! Very moving.

Falls short..... A small place hastily setup with some hardware from the war and some photographs. The tour guide is free and the guide is usually a soldier injured in the war. The guide speaks more about himself and his sad past and instructs you not to put your money in the donation box and wants you to hand over the donation directly to him. I consoled myself saying he deserves it. This place is of very poor value, historically and other wise. Alternatively I would recommend that you make a donation to a service organisation for the welfare of the war affected people.

Free guide... Yeh right. Very interesting and worth while exhibit however it is very rundown and unkept. The guide Tom started out with some interesting facts and stories, it was at the end when he asked for a donation to help him through university and his friends that had fought through the war... We were more than happy to assist but were taken back and left with sour taste after he confronted us and advised our donation wasn't enough.... free guide !!!

Well worth a look, lots of relics.. We visited the museum and found the guide Veasna, who took us around more interesting and informative than the relics from much fighting in the country. There is a lot of guns, mines, and vehicles that you can touch. Nothing is maintained so don't expect immaculate machines, their straight from the battlefield.

real museum , real weapon plenty!!!. plenty real guns, bazooka , russian, USA , tanks, planes, canons, you can touch everything , so this a paradise for adult boys !!! Go have a knowledge and fun, Remember have a car,or tuktuk to come back to town, no bus , no taxi, no phone, its jus 3- 5 km from city, but yopur personal vehicle is necessery.

Reality not virtual reality. I can understand some reviewers comments, initally we thought that $5 entrance fee was steep. The impression is of a lot of rusty old equipment. Our guide Mr Keo Veasna however was entirely real. An ex Government soldier who fought in the war against the Khmer Rouse brought the site to "life" or more accurately death. This place is a lesson in the horrors of brutalities of civil war. He explained the weapons, how they were used and in partcular the different types of land mines and the injuries that they inflicted, he himself has some fingers missing and ball bearing in his body. Do not feel that it is a depressing place, it isn't; it is in many ways an example of the powers of human strength in the face of appaling mental and physical injuries. I felt that his description of the realities were a cathartic experience for him and indeed some of the stories are not ones that anyone could possibly recover from. It is well worth going if only to contribute in some small was to some people's recovery and to learn about this aspect of Cambodian history first hand.

Lots of weapons shells - little information. $5 to get it is a bit steep. That's what is charged at the Killing fields in PP though this is nothing like the experience you have there.Free guide - well that's a bit of a laugh. I was taken to the shop where I was told I could browse the books for sale (all over priced fakes) and then the man who was my 'guide' sat down to play cards and drink beer with his friends.I walked around for about ten minutes, but not knowing anything about warfare to me it was a whole load of tank shells and big guns. Which was interesting but not very informative. As I was walking out I saw a foreigner talking (and it seemed quite in-depth) to another of the 'guides'. I didn't want to be rude and interrupt but maybe not all the guides were as useless as mine!Give it a go if you're interested and you have a half hour/hour to kill, but don't break your back getting there.Probably not a good place for prams/children who are likely to wander as it is not paved and doesn't have any enclosures around the displays.

A must see in Cambodia/Siam reap. Didnt know what to expect but wasnt disappointed. We were met by tom who was in the army during the conflict and had one arm blown off by a land mine. One of the loveliest people you want to meet. The museum is outside with lots of war relics such as tanks ,guns,and lots of ordnance like grenades, land mines, and a lot of nasty stuff. Heaps of photos etc. A small cost to get in but well worth it and leave a donation when you leave as this place is looked after by volunteers. It isnt very far out of town and we did it in a tuk tuk, fun ride with Mr Thea No 1.

Truly unforgettable!! You must go!!. Anyone who's says they dislike or tells you not to go here seriously has no soul!! The history and horrors of this glorious country is something that can never be understood by a single mind! The free guide here is by far the reason to go! The stories of what they went through are truly unforgettable to listen too... Tom my guide, a landmine victim of the war, was amazing! A lovely kind hearted friendly and funny person who went through so much and still is able to come back to such a place too tell you his story, I actually have no idea how he does it! I truly don't! I'm not ashamed in the slightest to say I cried there with him! Go see this place for yourself and listen to horrors and stories of heros (which they all completely deny being) they went through and fought alongside and it'll change your attitude towards everything in life! If they can carry on, so can you!!Go! It is a must!

i wont recommend it to others. though many rated this place as an eye opener and interesting, i stood with those that rated it terrible. we went around 4.30pm, close to their closing time, and after paying the enyrance fee, were happy to see that there'd be free guide. Before we even got down from our van, we saw 2 guides entertaining two groups of visitors that arrived 2 mins before us. One left with 2 ppl, the other one was left with 3 others. I could be wrong, but i swear i saw the last guide gave our van a look, saw that more ppl are coming, and he tried to hurried the 3 tourists to follow him so as not to let us catch up with them. Why I suspected this? coz as he was pulling one tourist's arm to hurry him along, that tourist actually turned back and pointed at us, as if telling him that he should wait for us as well, since we just arrive and he's the only guide left. The guide shook his head and continue to tug at the tourist's arm, encouraging him to move on. At this point, we've actually walked up to their group, and by all means, this guide avoided eye contact with us, as if we werent there.We were stunned, as we've checked the office and it was empty, and thinking that this last guide would be the one leading. Anyway, we kept to ourselves and started taking pix on our own. After about 2 mins, the guide finally came over, asking where we are from. Our answer made him rolled his eyes (I WONDER WHY), and very reluctantly, he asked if we want to join the other three. Of coz we said yes. But what happened next was unacceptable to us. He didnt introduce himself, didnt look at us when he talked and didnt care if we couldnt hear him. All the while, he talked only to that three tourists, and from the first stop he moved to the next, without waiting for us. There were 5 of us in our group, and since we were walking behind, he didnt bother to wait for all before started talking bout the exhibits! is that what a tour guideshould do? The next thing shocked us. Only at the 2nd stop, he was mad that my friend was still snapping pix behind, he actually scolded us and said we should pay attention to him if we want to follow his group! This is plain rude, coz first of all, we were all in a large group, so even taking pix takes time too. And it was only the 2nd stop! And like i said, he acted as if we werent there at all, so why said we werent focusing when he didnt even acknowledge our existence? Some how it just confirmed my suspicion that he wasnt happy we tagged along in the first place.I just told him to go ahead with his group, and we would be more than happy to walk on our own.Other travellers mentioned as well, the place isnt well-kept, and many of those exhibits are in very poor condition. With the $ from our entrance fee, more could've been done. Even photos and charts on the noticeboards seemed to be printed ages ago, at least that would have been the easiest to keep i supposed, if tanks and guns and the other metals go rusty easily!will not go back (so forget bout the saying if u pay $20, it's for life, coz that's a cheat. im sorry to that visitor that got robbed $20 coz i only paid $5)

Good to See, but pretty average. Well worth seeing, just to see all of the armoury and amunition that has been used in Cambodia and all the deaths and disabilities caused by the horrors of war.Quite a eerie sort of calm as you walk around

Very worthwhile. While some of the exhibits are a little rusted, the real value in this place was our guide (Tom I think was his name & ex soldier) & his personal story & that of others. Worth experiencing

Very eye opening. As previously mentioned the displays of weapons, tanks, guns etc is old and quite rusty, but the value is in the tour guided by a former soldier. I had Veasna Keo whose life story is an eye opening insisted into life in Cambodia, and the destruction of war and political ambition.

an eye opener. we visited the war museum and were guided by a young man who had lost his arm in a land mine explosion - what an amazingly brave and optimistic person he was. i do not feel we in australia were aware of the devastation caused by pol pot to the lives of the cambodian people. we were grateful to this guide for his time and his story. i urge people to take the time to visit here - old weapons from the war on display in this quiet overgrown part of siem reap. to hear about landmines is one thing but to see them and see what they do is quite another. i thank this young man for remaining positive about the future and not appearing to be bitter about the awful things that had happened to him. there are also books written about that time in cambodia on sale at museum and well worth the investment.

Informative, Entertaining and Heartbreaking. This was one of the most memorable stops on my trip of Vietnam and Cambodia. Yes, the tanks, guns, and weapons are run down and busted but that just added to the appeal. Plus you can handle many of the weapons (don't worry, they are nowhere close to working order). What made the museum memorable though was our guide. He was nicknamed Cat Man because he was living on his ninth life from all the injuries he has sustained throughout 3 decades of war. His story was one of the most captivating and heartbreaking I've ever heard. Experiences will vary depending on the guide; however, I would not miss this place.

Gem in Siem Reap. Must ask for Tour Guide. Most tourists only go to Angkor Wat temples when they're in Siem Reap. But you would be missing out on understanding the livelihoods and context of Cambodia, if you didn't visit the war museum, which is only a 10 minute tuk tuk drive from downtown. The entrance fee is $3 and opening hours is 7:30am-5:30pm. If you visit the war museum, be sure to ask for their volunteer tour guide. All are ex-soldiers so they personally lived through the war. The volunteer tour guides gets a base salary of $50/month, so they mostly live on tips. I was fortunate to have Mr. Keo Veasna be my tour guide. He joined the Cambodian army to fight against the Khmer Rouge when he was 15 years old and most of the items in the war museum were collected in his home town, so he told many personal stories. Veasna lost both his parents when he was two years old because Pol Pot's regime was killing a lot of people towards the end of his regime. He was adopted by a man who became his godfather, but when his godfather passed away, he joined the army. Veasna is able to tell you what each weapon is, where it's manufactured, and also personal stories of how many of his friends died or got disabled during the war. I couldn't believe when Veasna told me his friend died in one of the tanks that were on display. He collected his friend's bone and displayed it on the tank because he wanted to share with others his friend was a good man, who shared his food with others during the war. Veasna asked me when I thought the Khmer Rouge war ended. I told him 1979. I was shocked to learn that the war officially ended in 1999! Pol Pot died in 1998 of heart attack and the Khmer Rouge official surrendered in 1999. That was only a little bit more than a decade ago. After Veasna left the army, he heard about the war museum and decided to work there because he wanted to spread the word to prevent future wars. He started as a cleaner, but with the small tips tourists gave him, he went to study English and now speaks fluent English after taking 1 hr lessons every day for a year. Please visit the war museum when you're in Siem Reap, and request for their volunteer tour guides, especially Keo Veasna. It's really a worthwhile visit and you won't regret it.

Emotional and profound. The museum is a little out of the way, located between the airport and the city. Glad we went though. The guide, Mr. Keo Veasna, was a 16 year old soldier who fought against the Khmer Rouge. His stories and still visible scars from landmines provided a very emotional and human side to the war. Listening to him made me feel extremely lucky to be born in a peaceful country. His story of our children chose to be soldiers in order to get food showed that not everybody gets a choice of their path in life. Definitely a must visit to understand Cambodia in a deeper way.

Our excellent guide made the experience great. Out near the airport the museum is only a short tuk tuk ride from town. We arrived and accepted the offer of a guide around the museum. We were really glad that we did so as there it really made the experience for us and our guide was excellent. Really friendly and knowledgeable - I would definitely recommend a guide if you make the visit. I'd recommend a trip to the museum for anyone visiting Siem Reap.
makes my hair stand up. i dont really like seeing this kind of thing. to me it is a bit weird that terrible things that happens become an attraction!

The other history of Siem Reap. One cannot only admire the beauty of Siem Reap and not know the brutality it has undergone. The War Museum is dwarfed by the Angkor Archeological Park, yet in its unique way stands out to people who are curious about the materials used during the wars in Cambodia. The War Museum could be considered as a junkyard for old military pieces, yet for those who have never gone close to any Warsaw Pact small and heavy weaponry, this is a treat.I hope that the museum administration could make it accessible for people on wheelchairs, improve its visual presentations, repair or rehabilitate the existing museum pieces, include during their walkthrough the ill effects and the lessons learned after conflict. For the 5 USD entrance fee and if you buy anything from the museum shop, consider it your in help to sustaining the livelihood of victims from the conflict who are working there.

Waste of time and money. The entire museum is just a large patch of grass with rusty old tanks and guns. It is insult to the name it holds and I learnt nothing from the experience for a relatively hefty $5. The sign at the information desk said that tour guides were free of charge but when I asked the staff about it, they said I would have to give them tips. I wasn't bothered about giving a tip out of my own initiative but didn't like being told about it.

Take the guide. The museum itself is a collection of scrap iron, really none of the tanks, planes, helicopters, guns etc. are in a good state. If you enter, after having paid the amount of US$ 5 per person, and you see this bunch of rusty vehicles, you regret going there. But what made it wellworth was the guide. A great guy, who had lost his family in the Khmer rouge war and who had decided to share his horrible experiences for a fee with others. He really tells you stories, you will never hear, and explains you what has really happened in those bad years.

War museum. It is worth visiting. Be ready to feel the gloom of the place after seeing all those photos of war victims. Guide is provided free of charge. But it would be good to give him a tip as normally those guides are also former military personnels whom lost a limb . Entrance fees is US$5 per pax. It is very hot.

A very moving experience. The War Museum is an open air area with small covered in shelters along the side that house guns, ammunition and photographs. When we first arrived it almost looked abandoned with rusty old vehicles and bombs lying in long grass, however the guide appeared and as our tuk tuk driver had already explained, the guide worked as a volunteer but we would be expected to give a donation. We were more than happy to do that and it was well worth the money (I think we gave him $5 each), plus we were glad to be able to contribute to his income as we discovered later that he had had to leave the army because he had lost his fingers on one hand through an explosive detonating. There was no obligation to use the guide but it made a huge difference to our visit. His story was very interesting and moving, and he really brought the place alive with his explanations of everything. I feel privileged to have had a first hand account of the war and it's shocking that there are still traps and mines like the ones he showed us, all over Cambodia. The visit to this museum moved us so much that we have now signed up to make a monthly contribution to MAG, the Mines Advisory Group, a charity which clears mines and UXOs around the world. If you are at all interested in the civil war in Cambodia, I thoroughly recommend visiting this place.

Very interesting. Our tour guide was really interesting. He told us a lot about the Khmer history, the war as he used to be in the army himself. He told us a lot of stories from his time there. Well worth a visit.
I liked it. Good collection of Tanks, Guns and more. 5USD entrance fee. Everything is outdoor. But there are some small open houses with informations.

Really liked this place. Lots of old remnants from the war, including tanks, artilery a helicopter, jet and bombs... You will probably be asked for a guided tour for the cost of a donation. If you have a larger group or can jump in on a group you can do it for about $5 each as long as you muster up about $20 he will probably be happy. The guide is extremely informative and has a lot of first hand knowledge. The guides were all injured from various UXOs or land mines and this is the best and only job really available to them. The guide I had told us a heartbreaking story of a friend he lost in one of the very tanks that lay destroyed on site. Some bone fragments a still remain inside. You can see it all on your own of you'd like though the guided tour is definitely worth the $5

Exhibits are rusting, but awesome one armed war vet guide made up for it. The exhibits are mainly rusting hulks, but that shouldnt really matter. The guns on display are sometimes in poor condition, but as a trade off you can actually handle all the exhibits (guns, grenades etc). Dozens of authentic guns used in the war, from WWII to late Vietnam era Russian and American weapons. The star of the show was the guide however. I regret that I have forgot his name. Our guide had only one arm, having lost the other to a claymore mine during the Cambodian war. He was a war veteran and a child soldier, and the war stories he told us (Emergency IV administered with coconuts, wire saw amputations) were amazingly vivid and made the museum's exhibits seem a lot more real. He apparently was also personally responsible for recovering some of the artefacts displayed in the museum, for example the Katyusha missile truck with bullet holes in the drivers side. The dead driver's hip bone is still inside the truck! Apparently he was chained to his vehicle when they found his truck at the Thai border. Having a war vet as a guide made the trip really worthwhile. The museum loses one star for the poor condition of the outdoor exhibits (tanks, BMPs, an Mi 18 and a MiG19) though. This museum should have its exhibits properly restored!

Amazing. Very eye opening to view the history of the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia.Great display of war items.Very hard to imagine what devastation and grief these people went through with the landmines and in some places still are.

The best War Museum in the world!. This is the best War Museum have many Guns ,Tanks, Helicopter Mig, Big Area....etcAll the staff very friendly. Everything at this museum you can touch take photos free...There are a lot of souvenir you can buy it is the same you support museum and land mine victimsThe Boss very king that can took land mine victims to work for....I know many place in Siem reap they are no need land mine victim to work..I hope in future here have many tourist who want to know about the history of Cambodia ....culture....etcI love this museum so much because this place gave many landline victims to worksIf you at Siem reap now don't forget go to visit War MuseumEntrance fee only 5$ per-person. Monk. Landline victim, children below 10 years old.......are freeTel.012 658662

Nothing to see there..only a collection of some scraps. After getting tired by kilometer long walk in Angor temples, I decided to take a day's rest. When I gone out of the hotel to buy some items, as usual tuk tuk drivers covered me with offers. As I said I already covered all the tourist attractions, one guy suggested to visit the war museum. Its little away from the city, there is an admission fee if $5. From my point of view, rather than a museum, it looks like a village house where a lot of war leftover scraps were kept. It is not arranged in an order, but only scraps, scraps and scraps. I've seen some cows were tied to the old tanks and lot of kittens playing over the "shells & mines" :). The attack by the mosquitoes are severe. For me it looks like a "family run exhibition (??)" center.I wouldn't tell anyone not to go but don't have any expectations,I will never go again. It is more like a collection of war leftovers rather than a museum, very basic displays and maintenance, I didn't saw any another tourist while I was there.

Interesting but be wary. It was a great set up, the machinery and weapons were interesting but I would recommend opting to wander around the place without a guide. We paid our $5.00 each entry fee and then when offered a "free" guide we said yes. The man starts his speech and it all sounds great till he asks for a $20-30 donation. I hesitated as this is a significant amount of money to be giving after paying the admission price, but proceeded to hand over a 20 dollar note. He then told me it was $20-30 EACH! I told him it was a donation and he should be thankful for whatever he receives and that we had already paid our entry fee and went to put my wallet away when he stopped me and said $20 will be fine. Regretfully I gave it to him and we continued the tour but I was left feeling angry and didn't enjoy it.

Very authentic war museum. I love this museum because it is in the open space with many thanks, guns, missiles, launchers, land-mines, etc. Admission is about US$5 per entries, and you can walk around under the mango trees without many people. if you like old war vehicles, absolutely this is the place for you to take photographs. Is not really like a museum that you think, but maybe more than that, look like a real war zone. This is my favorite war museum so far. IDo try...! And you will enjoy it!

Poor bloody Keo. I met Keo at the front of the museum. I basically said to him, "How much is this going to cost me?" He just said it was up to me and any donation I made, again, was up to me. Well, what an idiot I proved myself to be. Keo was an absolutely wonderful guide, humble, honest and made me feel like I didn't even deserve to be in his presence. He explained how he felt and just what had happened to him and his fellow soldiers in the past. I looked at the shrapnel in his face and could see the pain and hurt in his eyes. This guy was the real deal. Make you realise what a bubble I live here on the northern beaches of Sydney. I am actually a cop and have some tragedy but this guy just made me feel so humble. I gave him @20.00 and feel I ripped him off $1,000.'s. His insight, frank and honest answers to any questions I had to ask and the truthful, no holds barred answers have left me gob smacked. Do the tour. I was fortunate to have this wonderful 37 year old veteran to myself for over and hour. One of the best things I have ever done in my life, even though it leave me with tears and a heap of mixed emotions. Thanks again Keo. If I come back to Cambodia, which I hope to do some day, may God(or whatever you believe), give you some internal peace and a brigher future than you horrid past. Mate, you have been ripped off so far. Chris Papallo

Orchard of War. As others have said, this is a strange place and set up for a war museum.No one offered to be my guide and I was happy for it to be that way. As an ex-infantry man with an interest in aviation I found the museum very interesting because the range of weapons from home-made hand guns to large caliber artillery pieces and a "Katushka" ,plus the armoured vehicles, despite their condition, are not a common sight.I have included a photograph of the "Mig 19" which I believe is actually a Chinese built Shenyang F-6.

A piece of the puzzle but that's about it.. I wouldn't tell anyone not to go but don't have too high an expectation.It is more like a collection of war leftovers rather than a museum, very basic displays and maintenance, however knowing the hardships this country has been through one can only give credit to the operators for trying to make a living. Our visit (we didn't see another tourist while there) was made worthwhile by our guide who was a victim of a land mind explosion...losing three fingers and still having shrapnel in his face and shoulder which he encouraged us to feel...along with a subtle reminder that he does the tours to raise money to have it removed. The photos on display, while in poor condition were interesting, as was the photo of the guide when he was in the army (I think it was the army??) a much younger person of course complete with guns....there must still be plenty of tragic events swirling around the minds of lots of Cambodians still today, perhaps the drivers or the old lady who serves you in the markets, it's amazing how forgiving the people are. If you have limited time in Siem Reap there are probably better options but if you have a couple of hours spare there are worse places to go...the water puppets in Hanoi for example!

If one can get left to wander around on your own its very interesting..... The rating given to this attraction seem to depend on whether you are kind of forced to pay $20 for a "guide" or not. We had a Cambodian tour guide with us who got us into the museum and then left us to roam around - so we were lucky although the other visitors did seem to have museum "guides".The museum deals with a very complex and horrific period in Cambodian history - and to be honest even after reading up on it its still a tad confusing (Other that it seemed to be a Chinese sponsored fraction opposing a Vietnamese sponsored fraction in open warfare). There are a plethora of weaponry on display, ranging from a Mig 19 jet fighter and Main Battle tanks down to small arms, mines, radios and the like. Give the museum due, it has better English signage than many other museums we have visited.In summary if one can shake off the unwanted guides (but give an extra donation if you desire naturally) this is a actually a reasonable museum.

Gives an appreciation of Cambodia's experience in the 1970's war. This is definitely a tuk-tuk ride from central Siem Reap, but driver will wait for you while you tour. It is not a typical museum, but more of an open-air collection of old Soviet and U.S. military equipment and remainders from the war. My guide was a participant in the war and had many great and compelling, though often sad, stories to tell. Westerners should visit this place if they are in the area, to have an upclose glimpse of impact of the war on this country. Be prepared to ask for a small gift of assistance at the end, but it means so much more to them than it does to us. That said, don't put more in your pocket when you go, to avoid giving more than you intend to. It becomes hard to say no or limit. If you do NOT visit this place on your stay at Siem Reap, you haven't had the full experience. Allow about an hour.

Worth the entry fee and "donation". The war museum cost $5 to get in and we were offered the option of a guided tour or to wander by ourselves. We were informed the guided tour would require a $20 per person donation to assist with others who have been disabled by war or landmines. I opted to pay for the guided tour and it was worth every penny. We heard about the personal struggles of our guide who lost his arm to a landmine as well as others then guided through the "3 hectares" of guns, tanks, and other relics of the years of war the area experienced. This is the real deal. Stories and graphic pictures of some of the wars experienced and millions of mines left behind that effected the families and people that live here today. This collection is not prettied up for tourists; this collection is here to tell history. On a more personal note, my son loved all of the machinery and both of my children got an invaluable history lesson.This is a must for anyone with an interest in the struggles Cambodia has been through.

A lot of rusty tanks and guns. The site is quite extraordinary since cows and chickens are running around and are using the tanks for shade. The museum itself is not that interesting and you really need a guide to give some information as the information on the signs is very limited.

Invaluable; Powerful; Well worth going - hire a guide.. I went to the War Museum and honestly, it was invaluable and incredibly haunting.It is a $5 entry fee, which I think is pretty standard in comparison to alot of other entry fees in Siem Reap. At the gate, we were met by a young Cambodian War Victim, who said he would guide us around for a donation. Saying yes to a guide, for this museum, I think is necessary - you can not understand this museum completely, or comprehend the machines, guns, tanks, military items etc. without the knowledge of someone who has bore wittness and been part of this horrific history. Without a guide, this open-air museum is simply a large number of weapons, military tanks and machinery and nameless photographs. You will not be able to understand what you really are looking at; nor see the real power and story behind each piece. He also explained to us in great detail all the different land mines and how they were used in different ways, for different effects during the war. He also had photographs of himself and others during the war. His knowledge was second-to-none.Our guide told us his own horrific and tragic story, gave us real insight and gave us great explanations of the history of the war and the khmer Rouge regime. He answered whatever questions we wanted to know, and was simply a beautiful person to be around. By taking on this guide, we gave him a donation that will go towards his surgery to remove ballbearings still lodged inside his body (which he showed us), which at the present time, he can not afford. He was modest and kind, and extremely grateful for our donation. All I can say is, ignore any terrible review you read below; be sensitive and respectful here (for example, our guide said many tourists ask him offensive questions, or take silly pictures with the guns, which he has seen have killed thousands of people in the past) and most importantly, do hire a guide. You don't have to give a large donation, but it will make everything so much clearer. If you can, ask for Keo to be your guide; I'm sure you'll be as glad you went as I am.
Visit war museum you will get lots of information about the civil war in Cambodia. You will understand clearly about the civil war in Cambodia nearly 30 years,but where the weapons from?

Rushed, expensive and Mosquitos!. The tour took about 15 mins. The guide went quickly through the site showing us the land mine and machinery. I was a little paranoid and the guid told us to watch out for the Mosquitos since he had got malaria a few months ago. It was interesting hearing the guide talk about his family but didn't feel like we saw much except for machines. At the end they were asking for donations for the orphanes. They really make you feel bad even if you give a few dollars. I think they were expecting something over $20-30.

Honest display of war machinery. This museum does not have glitzy reconstructed heroic-looking machinery, it has real time and jungle-worn tanks and guns that give you a much more realistic feel for what those machines really did. It is a much more honest museum than any museum with planes hanging from the ceiling, this is not a hollywood-style hero setup. There is a small area with deactivated land mines that feels eerie to walk across even when you know they are deactivated. We had only a small amount of time left before having to head to the airport and this was a great way to fill our time and get a different perspective on history; none of us are much into war history but we thought we should go and see. This museum was very different in that it didn't display the machines in proud and pristine condition but rather it is an open-air setting with rusty deactivated missiles and tanks, signs that were used to warn people (in Cambodian) of land mines, and veterans that are able to provide a guided tour for only $5USD. There are no gory or sad pictures and yet it was the most sincere and chilling display of war machinery I've seen. For those who are interested in the technical aspects, there are descriptions (hand-written) of where the machines were used, made, their range, etc. It's a very very good display/museum not too far from Siem Reap (10 minutes approximately) and as I say it was interesting even for those without much interest in war museums. There is a very small shop at the end with books and other items, we were free to look without any hassle at all. We did not get the guided tour but wish we had, it was offered to us for $5 when we walked in but we declined and we were not asked again.

Blaaaaah!!!!!!!!!!!! Horrible! Waste of time! Waste of money! Insult for any tourist trying to learn more about Cambod!. DO NOT GO! HUGE WASTE OF TIME AND MONEY. NOT MUCH TO SEE AND POORLY KEPT. NOT SURE WHAT THEY DO WITH THE $5 ENTRANCE FEE THEY COLLECT FROM TOURIST. DEFINITELY DO NOT PUT ANYTHING ON KEEPING THE PLACE. No written information. You don't learn anything from this place. There are a few rotten pictures up here and there. OK, if you insist on going, don't say I didn't tell you. Skip it and do something better with your time. Seriously!

worth an hour but be wary. payed my $5 at the gate and taken aside by a guide who explained that the govt gets the fee and he does tours for a charity donation. he recommended $20-30 and I fixed it at $5 as I don't usually give charity to strangers. he seemed less needy than most, however he does a decent tour and let's you handle any weapon you like so I thought it was decent value. I would have liked a more personal display, some human stories as I'm not a Rambo buff, but hey it was ten bucks....

An eye- opener. A very informative place to visit , all the weapons you can think of in various shapes and sizes, including a helicopter and a mig jet.Makes you realize that this country has not long got over a war and how recent some of the displays have been discovered.

Interesting. We have done this visit as part of a day tour. I do not recommend to go this Museum if you have nothing else to do around.Museum is in a property where most of old war wapon, tanks, etc are diseminated around with no order. The guide is a young man with a very good English who introduces you to the war deatils very well however blend his speach with his personal problems.It is interesting to understand the cruelty and brutality of the human been, and the experiences of this people. It is very cheap and you can do it in 40 minutes.

Amazing experience and eye opener!. Not sure who the other reviewers are referring to, but my tour consisted of a great veteran who only charged for donations in the end (we just gave him a couple of dollars, no biggie). This place has a lot of old weapons and artifacts... you could even pick up the guns and pose with them! The tour guide who took us around lost his wife and daughter to a leftover landmine and he still had shards in his body from the war! He was a very moving speaker and this added significantly to my experience of Siem Reap, where I was "templed out." Just beware who takes you there... After reading reviews here I realized I was scammed -- my seemingly honest tour guide charged us 10 a person, when it's supposed to be 3. Dammit!

Waste of time and our money!!. This is basically a graveyard of old tanks and guns, there isn't really that much to see, we found this to be a total waste of time and money.We've been told that it should be free and then you tip your guide, we didn't get that experience, we were told there was an entrance fee when we arrived and then after entry they then wanted us to pay for the guide separately, the alarm bells started to ring and I decided to ask for our money back or we'll leave, it was then that they said they would take us round, but unfortunately this was a five minute walk half way round and tell us very minimal information on the guns. My advise would be don't go, but if you feel you want to look about, don't hand any money over until you've been taken round by a guide.

disappointing and ripped off.. Be very wary, when you are greeted at the gate by a one armed land victim named Com. His name should be Con. He was more interested in telling his own life story, than explaining about the museum itself. At the end of the twenty minute walk, he asked my husband for $20us, to go to other landmine victims, which we thought at the time wasn't so bad, but then asked me also for $20, which I stupidly gave him. We were taken out of view from anybody else that was around, it all happens so fast you don't realize what it going on till you leave. BE AWARE.

Not Worth The Visit. First of all we got ripped off at this place. The tuk tuk driver who took us there told us the entrance fee was US10 per person. When we reach there the guy with one hand in charge there told us the fee was US20. We were surprised. They told us the money goes for charity. They have donation box but the money he puts into his pocket and signals the tuk tuk driver. I guess he told the tuk tuk driver collect your commison later. The guy also told us if we visit the second time there will be no admission fee even after a few years. How he will know us if we visit after 3 years. No answer from him. Just a smile. In other words they collect money from tourist for thier own and not for charity or land mines victims. We found later there is no fee for entrance.Up to you how much u want to donate by putting inside the donation box. So beware!Nothing much to see there. All rusty tanks and guns there. Looks like a graveyard. Total waste of time.

Rail roaded around exhibits and pressured. Costs $5 per person to visit and you are then offered a free guide who is a land mine victim and will show you the exhibits and give you a personal insight which in theory sounds like a fantastic idea.Exhibits:Examples of a variety of land mines, light weapons, heavy weapons and tanks. All pretty much rusted hulks but to expect different is optimistic. There's also a Russian jet and helicopter outside.Guide:Perhaps we were unlucky with our guide, judging by other reviews.His English was good and he pleasantly introduced himself and explained how he lost his left arm. He then explained that he did the guiding for free and couldn't get a job anywhere or any food. He also informed us that there were 50 other men in the museum in a similar position. This is all relevant and I'm sure his problems are representative of most Land Mine victims. Problem was he kept mentioning donations literally every couple of minutes and was constantly applying pressure comparing his life to our lives in the west. He whipped us round a few of the exhibits in about 10 minutes and then finished by suggesting a donation of between $20 and $30 minimum but more was also reasonable. He also requested that we give it directly to him rather than in the boxes labelled 'donation'.We had every intention of making a donation at the end in our own time and what we felt was right but his constant pressure made it really unpleasant.Also...halfway through his suggested donation speech his mobile rang...clearly not too hard up. We left a donation with him...stupidly but when he was standing between the boxes and us it was hard not to.Not sure if this place is associated with a NGO or what but I would visit the land mine museum as this seems to be a professional outfit keen on helping people. I'm not for one minute disputing the difficulties that land mine victims face in Cambodia but this 'guide' was really pushy and rude.

This must be seen - War is Never Good...... I would certainly recommend visiting this site. In addition to the two aircraft at the entrance, within the open museum there is much too see - in addition to a surprise which will be pointed out to you.The Museum is run by those who have been injured by land mines and really gives you an insight into both the horrifies of war, but also those daily killed or injured by land mines.Ensure you take a hat (for sun protection) and have some DEET or other mosquito repellent. Don't worry about the mossies, they are very small and harmless.When you've finished, there's a cheap bar (beer $1 per bottle) and you can have a friendly chat under a fanned leather sofa to some of those injured.

not much to see. its not far out of siem reap,turn right on 6th road heading to the airport and 900mts is the war muemum.has a russian MIG out the front and a large russian chopper,infact all the gear including artillary pieces where russian built.quite small and rusted relics of a war pasted,AK 47s,small arms,rifles all rusted out and old tanks again all rusted out,Cheap entry fee of $3 just walked around by myself and took about 30 mins,not bad and for me worth the time.

Siem Reap war Museum. Excellent facility to visit if you have any interest in war machines, or Cambodian history.It all looks a bit run down, but then again, so does most of Cambodia.It's down the end of a very grungy side road, 900 metres from the busy Airport Road.I was the only tourist there for most of my 30 minute tour.My guide was Mr Mean Sokham, whose arm was amputated without anaesthetic following a mine blast. His personal story was very moving, and his knowledge of the tanks and other equipment was impressive, although he took care to make it clear that he had never been a member of the armed forces.I was able to handle various weapons, ( M16, BAR, Thompson, AK47, M1 Garand) all of which had been decommissioned long ago and were in poor condition.The T54 tanks on display were rusting hulks, but well worth inspecting.Very low entry fee, so I made a reaonable donation at the end of the tour. It's a good cause.

Don't waste your time. We read about this attraction so decided to visit it along with many other attractions while visiting Cambodia. Fellow travellers "Do not waste your time and money to get there". Firstly we did not mind the very bumpy dirt road but noticed no other traffic along this path. Arrived at the gate and only 2 buses in the car park, that should have warned us. We saw one plane and one helicopter in the car park so thought, ok let's see what's inside and told the Tuk Tuk we should be no more than 1 1/2 hours, but as soon as we stepped through the gate we were set upon by a local 'tour guide' who said we had to follow him, all the while he kept mentioning free tour guide but they need donations. I kid you not, we we not given one minute to read a sign before being whisked down side of an open yard with about 3 dozen rusting old war relics, and back up the other side of the yard, asked for a donation and whisked out the gate all within 15 minutes and no time to reflex on what each relic was for or even read a sign on them. Most of the old relics were no more than rusting castings of former vehicles, the yard was not mowed and it seemed as if the museum had long been neglected and forgotten.

Place to see. do not miss the time to see War Museum,very interesting to discover the history of Siem riep.many useful pictures of the war we need to know,the friendly helpful guide told me a lot of information about the War Museum.

DEFINITELY WORTH THE TIME -- VERY MOVING EXPERIENCE!!!. My husband and I went to the War Museum one day by chance -- we were actually looking for the Landmind Museum and the tuk tuk driver misunderstood us and brought us to the War Museum instead. Boy, what a lucky mistake! This place is amazing -- full of old war equipment (missles, land mines, tanks, etc). The part that was the most moving was the tour. Tours are offered for free with a requested small donation of a few U.S. dollars. Our tour guide, like most people in their mid-30s in Cambodia, has suffered not just by losing their parents to the KR, but also then by being dragged into the war, physically becoming disabled by loss of limb and vision, as well as later losing his own wife and daughter to a land mind. Needless to say, spending time with this man was quite an emotional experience -- he was very detailed and honest about the details of the last 30 years of civil war in his country, as well as specifically how it affected him. Also, because of his military background, he knew EVERYTHING about the pieces on display. A guide is not necessary as there are signs in English that you can read as you walk around, but we highly recommend asking for a guide and taking the time to really take in the small little outdoor museum. We were very grateful for the chance to see it! Expect to spend anywhere from 30 minutes to 1.5 hours here (we were there for a little over an hour).

nice discovery tour. had a guide who experienced war, talked us through the tanks, guns etc then he started relaying his experiences in the war, felt a lot of sympathy initially, but he kept on going and crying i began to think it's probably becoming an ordeal for him to relate that to tourists and earn good tips. tipped him well though as i thought he did a good job. nice musuem to go but definitely need a guide, otherwise you'll not enjoy it.
interesting. a place to go to spend a few hours.most of the gear and equipment is rusted and the place needs a lot of work but cheap enough and if you are into old tanks ect than would go and look

Great place to visit. The admission price of $3 per person was well worth it for what the place has to offer. However, if they would clean it up, paint the equipment, and put ladders on the equipment so that tourists could climb inside the tanks, helicopter, and plane, they could charge more. Most of the equipment is either Chinese or Russian. There's a huge old Soviet helicopter and aircraft setting outside and the tanks, howitzers, and artillery pieces are setting inside. They are old and rusting but still interesting to see. There are sheds where there are rifles, machine guns, and all kinds of military equipment. In fact, I snapped a photo of kids playing with a machine gun. Nothing is off limits here. One can pick up the machine guns and rifles, examine them, and have his photo taken with them. Everything there is very accessible.It's a great way to spend an hour or so, especially if you like military equipment.

Was amazed. I went to the Land Mine Museum in February of 2006 when they are at their old location. We had a young boy who had a limb missing from stepping on a land mine give us a tour. He knew the names of all of the different types of land mines and did a fantastic job as tour guide. He then took us to an area where land mines were and we had to try and find them. It was very difficult. I hope that the museum becomes more recognized and that more people go through it in order to help them continue their work.

Maybe it's changed. Just got back from the museum today. Mostly a bunch of very rusted tanks and artillery. Not well kept. I would say unless you are really into this kind of thing to give it a miss. May be a good idea to see where the money goes as well before going or not. Still $3 person. On the way to the very worthwhile silk farm.

Well worth it.. Great place. Only three bucks to get in and well worth it. It came with a free guided tour, though you have to give the guide a little tip. Our guide had been a soldier in the war and was missing a leg, had quite a few bullet holes in him, and some shrapnel was visible under his skin. He told us a bunch of first hand stories as we went from exhibit to exhibit which was quite educational and enlightening. We were given explanations of how every tank, gun, mine, etc worked and we were free to climb onto the equipment and hold the guns, though it was almost like holding something haunted. The best war museums I've been to in North America and even at the D-Day beaches in France still didn't have the impact this museum did, largely because the war just recently ended and you can still see the effects all around the country.
